course.subject: PHYS
course.name: General Physics I with Calculus
course.description: PHYS 1111 and PHYS 1112 target students who have learned the most basic knowledge in physics in high school. Students with more advanced physics background should consider taking PHYS 1312. PHYS 1112 employs a calculus-based approach. Students without knowledge of calculus should take PHYS 1111 instead. Key topics include motions and Newtonâ€™s Laws, work and energy, conservation of energy and momentum, rotation, rigid body, simple harmonic and damped oscillations, forced oscillations, standing waves and sound waves, kinetic theory and the laws of thermodynamics. Students without the physics prerequisite but who have taken PHYS 1101 or equivalent, and/or without the mathematics prerequisite but who have taken MATH 1012/ MATH 1013/ MATH 1020/ MATH 1023 or equivalent may seek instructorâ€™s approval for enrolling in the course.
course.prerequisites: (Level 3 or above in HKDSE 1/2x OR in HKDSE 1x Physics) AND Level 3 or above in HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1/M2
course.exclusions: PHYS 1111, PHYS 1312

reviews.author: Saber Athena
reviews.title: Freshman/ DSEå†‡è®€M1/2æ—¢å…¥é»è¼ä¸€è¼
reviews.comment_content:
If you are reading this, you are either a) Planning to choose this course, which is required in your curriculum so you don;t have a choice or b) you are enrolled in this course and are panicking.
  Take a deep breath, everything will be OK, I'm here to help.

For those without M1/2: (Or calculus background)
  Let's face it, the teaching quality in UST MATH1012 is so bad it's close to non-existent. You are probably ill-prepared for a Physics course that is oriented around calculus. Things can get really scary really quick here.
  Calm down.
  Here's the thing, this amount of calculus involved in this course is really not high. There is almost no chance that you will ever face any difficult calculus problem. Most of the integration/differentiation (If there is any) that you will face are very easy. All you need to do is to set up the equation and you will be fine.
  So what about vectors?
  You will encounter most of the vectors in the first few weeks of the course. The rectangular coordinates that you were once familiar with will be changed to vectors, and it can get uncomfortable.
  But again, the vector calculations in this course are not difficult, and all you have to do is to spend a few hours to understand what the notations mean and you are all set. If you still find it difficult, search youtube for "Organic Chemistry Tutor Vectors". The video might seem to be very elementary and basic, but that's pretty much all you are ever gonna need!
  Still not convinced? In the Midterm/Final Exam this semester, not a single question involve vectors/integration/differentiation calculations (Maybe there was one or two, but I can't remember, so it can't be that bad.. right?)

=Contents=
  The first half (Up to the midterm) is basically just a revision of HKDSE Physics. From F=ma all the way to circular motion. The main focus is how to tackle the problems in HKDSE from a calculus perspective. (And also vector notations) You will have plenty of time to practice your calculus and to get comfortable with them. They also introduced the new concept of the moment of inertia, which, is really not that hard.
  The second half is different. They will introduce the new concept of Simple harmonic motion and Waves (Which is wayyyy more difficult than DSE waves. Your previous knowledge about wave will not be able to save you in this one). Then there will be the honeymoon period (two weeks long) of revising HKDSE heats (Specific heat capacity, Kinetic Theory etc.) and then they will ones again introduce scary stuff like first and second law of thermodynamics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
=Cheung Man Fung= (Professors)
  Cheung Man Fung is really not a bad teacher. The problem is, he is very smart, and he assumes that everyone is as smart as him.
  If you are not super good at Math or Physics, chances are, you will find Cheung Man Fung's lectures very difficult to understand. You are most likely not going to understand a thing in the lectures and it will leave you questioning your life.
  It's fine. It happens to the best of us.
  The main reason why his lectures are so difficult to understand is that he spends a lot of time talking about the DERIVATION of the formulas.
  When it comes to dealing with the exams, there's really no need to understand those derivations (Well.. unless you are aiming for a guaranteed A+ and want to get the highest mark in the whole class... In that case it would be better if you understand the derivations). The reality is, the exam questions don't require you to know how the formulas are derived. You just need to know how to use those formulas and when to use them.
  I not saying that you should skip all the lectures and ignore the derivation (you can if you want). My recommendation is to try your best to understand the derivations. It is provide you with a slightly better understanding of the topic. If you can't, that's fine. Don't spend too much time in it. The focus is knowing how to use the equations.

=Liu Bin= (TA)
  Why... Just... why???
  He is a sh_t teacher. There is no question about it. The students know it, he knows it, we all know it.
  He does not try to explain the concept, he does a poor job teaching. No one pays attention in his class. We are just there because we need to take attendance. He is perfectly aware of this. He could not care less.
  My advice: Quit trying to be a TA, go do the Physics research that I'm sure he is good at, and learn how to pronounce the word "square".
reviews.comment_grading:
Good Grading.
  Midterm: 25/26
  Finals: 22/27
  Homework: 100% (Raw score is 86.5, after conversion it became 100. I have no idea how it worked. I am not going to question it.)
  Tutorial Attendance: 100% (Though I spent almost all my lectures watching Youtube)
  Final Grade: A.
  Good Enough.
  I have attached the Finals and Midterm Histogram for your reference.
reviews.comment_workload:
=Homework=
  The homework will count 10% of your course grade. It is multiplied by 1.1, so a 90ish mark will give you a full mark in the final grade.
  The workload from the homework is not high. Google is your friend. Slander is also your friend.

=Exams=
  As I have said before, the focus is knowing when to use the formula and how to use them. The only way to achieve this is by practicing, a lot.
  Do the supplementary exercises on the Mastering Physics Webpage first. Those are the essentials but will not be adequate for you to get a good grade.
  To get a good grade, do the exercise at the end of each chapter of you Pearson textbook. If you don't know how to do them, copy the questions and search them up in google. For 90% of the questions, you can find the full solution in Slander.
  The workload is heavy. There is no question about it.
  In particular, the difficulty of the final Exam is not comparable to the midterm. If you are going after an A grade, make sure that you have at least 5 day (No, 3 days are not enough) devoted to PURE practicing.
  To sum up, this course is a good chance for you to reflect your life choices, and think about why you didn't get into CUHK when you have the chance.
  Aiiii.... the sweet sweet taste of regret.

-Saber Athena

reviews.comment_teaching: Cheung Man Fung is the best professor. He explained the theory very well. Even you are not good at physics, you can still understand it easily.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair.
My grade:
midterm : 84/100 (+1 SD)
final : 76/100 (+1.5 SD)
Finally, I got  A
For your reference, I just got level 4 in DSE physics but I have put many efforts into this course so I got A
midterm is fair, if you really put effort and practice more before it, not difficult to get +1 SD.
However, the final exam is super DIFFICULT this semester. I am sure that it is more difficult than that any other semester before.
The final exam includes some conceptual MCs which are not covered well in the lectures, which means you should read the textbooks by yourself to understand it thoroughly. Don't just think that you can calculate the questions and no need to understand the concepts, you can not survive in the final exam!!!
Good news is that this semester is the last online semester, when it comes to normal face-to-face lectures, the exam should be easier.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework of Mastering Physics every week. Each time need to spend around two hours to complete.

reviews.author: Small__Potato
reviews.comment_content: This course contains about 80% new things for students with DSE physics background. The contents are interesting if you are interested in physics. But, The syllabus includes a lot of unfamiliar constant and symbol. I believe more than  90% of students cannot fully understand the topics. But still, even you cannot fully understand the contents, you can still get quite a high grade in the final. The lectures emphasis on the prove of equations, but in the tests and final, they are more about examples. the final have somehow more conceptual questions compared to the tests. But only a quarter of them are these kind of difficult questions. So you may spend more time in the practical questions in mastering physics before test and final.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cheung Man Fung is a passionate teacher. He put much time in proving the physical formula. It is depended on you whether it is good or not. In my opinion, I think it is better to put more effort in introducing the examples instead of proving the equations since most of us cannot understand how the  equations come. Doing more practices may be better for helping us to clarify the concept.

homework: 87.96/100 ( forgot to do hw in both test week)
tutorial (equal to attendance of tutorial) :  full
pre/post course surveys: full
final: 36/45
overall grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: the workload is highest among all the courses if you are an engineering student. We needed to finish a weekly homework in mastering physics. In the test week, I complete nearly most of the practical questions in mastering physics. But the workload is not a big problem if you can survive in S6.  However,  REMEMBER TO FINISH THE HOMEWORKS IN THE TEST WEEKS!

reviews.author: Vincentchan9839
reviews.title: A challenging course, but you can get a very good grade if you are hard-working enough
reviews.comment_content:
The content is so crammed. Almost all of us cannot understand all of them before the midterm exam and final exam. However, as I like Physics so much despite I am from School of Engineering, I think I can learn much and feel fulfilled.

You will learn some new Physics knowledge, like the laws of thermodynamics. About half of them are from HKDSE Physics syllabus.

Here is the syllabus for each lecture:

1)Physical quantities, vectors & Motion in 2D
- projectile

2)Newton's laws of motion I
- Relative Motion
- Reference Frame
- Newton's Three Laws

3)Newton's laws of motion II
- Friction
- Circular motion

4)Work and kinetic energy
- work-energy theorem
- work done by a varying force

5)Potential energy and energy conservation
- gravitational (mgh) and elastic PE
- conservative and non-conservative forces

6)Momentum, impulse and collision I
- impulse-momentum theorem
- conservation of momentum
- elastic, inelastic, and completely elastic collision

7)Momentum, impulse, and collision II
- elastic collision
- center of mass

8)Dynamics of rigid bodies I
- angular displacement, velocity and acceleration
- rotational kinetic energy and moment of inertia

9)Dynamics of rigid bodies II
- calculation of moment of inertial
- torque

10)Dynamics of rigid bodies III
- rigid body rotation about a moving axis
- work and power in rotation motion

11)Angular momentum
- conservation of angular momentum
- gyroscope

12)Gravitation I
- Newton's law of gravitation
- gravitational force and potential energy
- satellite motion

13)Gravitation II
- Kepler's laws of planetary motion
- spherical mass distribution
- apparent weight due to earth's rotation
- black hole

14)Periodic motion I
- simple harmonic motion

15)Periodic motion II
- various types of SHM, pendulum
- damped and forced oscillations
- resonance

16)Wave motion and sound I
- mathematical description of wave
- power propagation
- reflection of traveling waves

17)Wave motion and sound II
- standing wave
- beat
- Doppler effect

18)Temperature and heat
- thermal expansion
- heat capacity and latent heat
- heat transfer

19)Thermal properties of matter I
- equation of state
- kinetic theory of ideal gas

20)Thermal properties of matter II
- heat capacity of gases
- molecular speed distribution

21)First law of Thermodynamics I
- first law of thermodynamics
- heat and work in thermodynamic processes

22)First law of Thermodynamics II
- typical thermodynamic processes
- heat capacities of ideal gas under different conditions
- adiabatic process of ideal gas

23)Second law of Thermodynamics I
- heat engines and refrigerators
- different forms of the second law

24)Second law of Thermodynamics II
- reversible processes
-Carnot cycle and engine
reviews.comment_teaching:
Here is the website that introduce Professor Po:
https://physics.ust.hk/eng/people_detail.php?pplcat=1&id=613

Professor Po is a new, local professor this year. This course is the very first course he taught in HKUST. Before he entered HKUST, he finished his undergraduate degree in the Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), and his doctorate degree in Harvard University. Before he came to here, he has been a Pappalardo Postdoctoral Fellow in Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)  for three years.

Given his outstanding achievement background, his teaching was no doubt very well as he passionately wanted to help us to grasp all the knowledge of Physics despite this was a tough course for all freshmen like me and other classmates. He tried to answer all questions raised by us both during the class and after the lessons. I remembered a few classmates and me has asked him for over an hour after classes (Please note that this period should be lunch time for all of us), and still he was willing to answer all our enquiries and all of us could really understand all the difficult concepts. I have also asked some questions through emails and he could answer all of them clearly within a few hours.

For the in-class teaching, due to the extremely massive amount of things we need to learn in this course, he had no choice but had to cram all things into our brains, but still, I could feel that he was trying his best to let us understand all of them in a very short time. You can still take a look at his hand-written notes after the lessons as he would always upload them on Canvas.

For the TA, my TA was called Top Archie Dela PeÃ±a. He was a Filipino. Please bear in mind that sometimes his accent was a little bit unclear, so you might not be able to get what he said initially. He was not that good at helping us to learn the things as you know, the tutorial session was only 50 minutes, which was totally not enough. However, you may ask him through emails as he could answer my questions quite clear and detailed.

You can see more information about my TA in the following website:

https://tadppublic.wixsite.com/my-site
reviews.comment_grading:
I would describe this course by one sentence: "You will get what you have paid". If you are willing to pay some time to do revision and understand how all equations are derived and their meaning, you can easily get A-, at least.

Given that this course is really hard for most of us, therefore the mean for this course is very low when you compared this course with other 1000 series courses.

Here is the grading policy:
-Assignments:10%
-Tutorials:5%
-Midterm exam:35%
-Final exam:50%
-Bonus (If you have attempted Dynamic Study Modules (DSM), for in HK students only)

Here are some statistics:

-Midterm exam
Average = 10.9 (out of 24)
S.D. = 4.2
Highest = 24
Median = 10
Lowest = 2

-Final exam
Mean: 17.26 (out of 40)
SD: 6.68
Highest: 38
Median: 16
Lowest: 4

My result:
Assignments: all of them nearly full marks
Tutorials: all full marks
Dynamic Study Modules: all attempted and finished
Midterm exam: 12/24
Final exam: 25/40

Grade: A-

For your reference, here is my 2021 HKDSE result for M2 and Physics:

M2: Level 5
Physics: Level 5**
reviews.comment_workload:
One assignments and one tutorial every week.

Each assignment involves around 7 to 10 questions. Each of them takes you 1 to 2 hours to complete.

Each tutorial (attendance counted) consists of 2 to 3 questions. The TA allows you to copy the answers at the end of each tutorial.

The majority of workload comes from revision of the course materials (this also depends on whether you can easily understand all the things).

reviews.author: Plusle
reviews.title: This course is not easy.
reviews.comment_content:
Topics:
Newtonâ€™s laws of motion, Work and energy, Momentum and impulse, Dynamics of rigid bodies, Angular momentum, Gravitation, Periodic motion, Wave motion and sound, Temperature and heat, Thermal properties of matter, First law of thermodynamics, Second law of thermodynamics.

Textbook:
Young, Hugh D. & Freedman, Roger A. (2020). Modified Mastering Physics for University Physics with Modern Physics in SI Units, 15th Ed, Pearson.

(Note: Buying a textbook (electronic or printed version) is compulsory as the online MasteringPhysics license is needed for homework submission. The same textbook and license can be used in PHYS1114, so no additional cost if you take it in the next semester.)

About half of the content is included in DSE Physics, but never think that you can rely on your previous knowledge. You will NOT survive. Calculus is required sometimes, but not so frequent. Most of the problems you will encounter are just formula-using type, although there are many formulas which can confuse you.

To be honest, this course is very tough. Many physics concepts are introduced in a relatively fast pace, and if your physics background is not solid, you may find it hard to follow (especially for rigid body and thermodynamics). The ability to derive algebraic formulas in complicated situations is also very important (e.g. derive the formula for energy loss in completely inelastic collision), as you may consider preparing a formula sheet for exam (online exam mode).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Bei ZENG

Her accent is not heavy to understand. Explanation is quite clear in general. She is also willing to answer students questions. Sometimes multiple choices polls will be given through Zoom, which can clear up your concepts. She tried to make the class interactive, although not so successful in online mode.

Ziting Chen

He has adequate preparation for tutorials and generally clear explanation for questions to discuss. More difficult questions in homework will be discussed in tutorials, and attending tutorials can help with your homework. But those questions are less likely to appear in exam because of their difficulty.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading system:
Assignment: 10%
Tutorials: 5%
Mid-term exam: 35%
Final exam: 50%

Assignment is given through MasteringPhysics. Some questions may be difficult, but most of them just require you to be super careful. Each incorrect submission would deduce some marks, so you have to double check each answer if you aim a high grade.

Attendance on tutorials counts to your grade, so remember to be present. As we have lesson on Zoom, attendance mark will only be counted if we can answer a super easy MC question correctly. It is just for testing if you are actually paying attention.

Mid-term exam coverage are mostly overlapping with DSE. However, almost all questions cannot be answered by using DSE knowledge only. Never think that you can rely on your previous knowledge. Questions are in fact not difficult, but the time allowed is very limited. I prepared a formula sheet for exam, and found it quite effective. But doing this can be time-consuming. Final exam covers all topics (except entropy), but the difficulty is slightly lower than mid-term. Again, preparing a formula beforehand sheet is very useful.

In fact the mid-term and final are straightforward, but time allowed is quite insufficient. Thus the mean score is very low. By preparing a formula sheet for both mid-term and final, I managed to get a high score, and turns out got an A+. But I will not say this is a particularly good grade course, as much effort is needed to do so.

Data:
Assignment: almost full
Tutorials: full
Mid-term exam: 24.67 / 30
(Mean = 11.0 ; SD = 5.2)
Final exam: 39.17 / 42
(Mean = 17.8; SD = 7.6)

(For reference: DSE physics 5*)
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignment on MasteringPhysics is given on a weekly basis. Each one consists of around 10 to 15 questions. The tutorial may cover 1 to 2 questions of the difficult ones. For each assignment I spent 1 to 2 hours to do. Or you can rely on online sources and finish each within an hour. But make sure you understand them before exams.

There are also some additional exercise not does not count towards the grade. I personally did them just before the mid-term or final.

Another workload comes from preparing the formula sheet, which I do it when finishing the homework and additional exercise. Actually the homework is more difficult than exams, so if you can understand them well and give the explicit formula for the questions, you will be able to manage the exams.

In conclusion, the workload depends the grade you aim at.

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is high if u want a good grade.
Preparations
The workload of this course is heavy since u need to learn so much in this course with each topic requires the understanding the underlying principles and plenty of exercises.
Assignment
Also, there will be one assignment launched once a week in Person Masterphysics website. And with one incorrect answer submitted, there will be a 55 point deduction and there will not have a total of 6 attempts per question blank

reviews.author: Aaaaaaaaa
reviews.title: Not a hard course
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers mostly mechanics, some about waves and thermodynamics. If you have good understanding of physics learnt in high school/ DSE, this course should be very easy for you as most of the topics are just the extensions of those covered in the DSE.

As the topics are not really complicated, reading the lecture notes alone could already help you understand the contents. Doing the exercise in Mastering Physics is the key. Even if you do not attend the lectures, you can still get good grades by completing all the exercises in Mastering Physics.

I didn't attend lectures. I read the lecture notes while doing the weekly assignment, which basically consists of questions extracted from Mastering Physics. Before the mid-term and final exams, I completed all odd numbered questions in the thick book Mastering Physics as it only has answers to the odd numbered ones. Although you are not required to do crazy maths to derive the provided equations/formulae, it is a good practice to try to derive them yourself to test your understanding. I sometimes went to the weekly Helpdesk session to ask the TA some problems in homework/ Mastering Physics that I couldn't solve.

For the content, make sure you understand how everything works. Do not just memorise the formula. Don't worry if you did not study m2 in high school as the maths required are not complex and most of the time you only need basic differentiation/integration.

Scores:
Mid-term: 27/30
Mean: 18.5
SD: 5.5 (above mean 1.55 sd)

(Online )Final: 32.5/40
Mean: 20.7
SD: 6.3 (above mean 1.87 sd)

Final grade: A+
I got 5* in HKDSE physics FYI.
reviews.comment_teaching: Chen Tian Wen is from Hong Kong so his English is quite clear and easy to understand. He also held some optional tutorial sessions before mid-term exam to answer our questions and solve our problems.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grades I guess.
reviews.comment_workload:
Complete the online assignment on Mastering Physics every week. The questions are not hard to do. Search the key words on google to find the exact problem if you happen to find the question difficult. Just try to ensure you got the correct answer before entering it in as you may lose course marks for incorrect answers.

You are also required to attend the weekly tutorial.

æƒ³fulfil requirement æœ‰åº•æ‡‰è©²å””æœƒå¥½è¾›è‹¦ï¼Œæƒ³æœ‰å€‹éšgradeå°±è¦ä»˜å‡ºå¤šD

Assignments:
Weekly online homework(MasteringPhysics)
90% of total marks will guarantee a full 10%, as the marks will be scaling with a factor of 10/9.
If you meet some difficult questions, don't hesitate to open the textbook(the gift of buying code) to learn some more, and that may help you to have new way of thinking
You can also try to ask professor/tutor.
Learning to solve the problems is a key to get good grade, though it may increase your workload to this course a lot...

Tests:
Both tests have first-take and re-take. Formula sheets will be provided so the workload is reduced for memorization.
3 ways of calculating scores:
1. First-take
2. Average of first-take and re-take
3. Retake * 80%
So if you get ~8/9 marks in first-take and you are not striking for the best grade, you may consider skipping re-take.

Final Exam:
45 Multiple-Choice questions within 3 hours. Focusing more on topics not covered in the 2 tests. Formula sheet will also be provided.
A bit more workload than tests for revision of lots of concepts.

reviews.author: Semajolty
reviews.title: åªè¦è‡¨è€ƒfinalä¹‹å‰ä¸€å€‹æ˜ŸæœŸç˜‹ç‹‚åšæ›¸å˜…é¡Œç›®å°±æœƒæˆåŠŸ (åˆ©ç”³: DSE PHYSICS 4)
reviews.comment_content:
Textbook:
Modified Mastering Physics for University Physics with Modern Physics in SI Units, 15th Edition
Author(s):
Young, Hugh D. | Freedman, Roger A.

It is a MUST to buy the textbook because you will need the access code from the book to activate the online homework.

Syllabus

1 Physical quantities, vectors & Motion in 2D
- projectile

2 Newton's laws of motion I
- Relative Motion
- Reference Frame
- Newton's Three Laws

3 Newton's laws of motion II
- Friction
- Circular motion

4 Work and kinetic energy
- work-energy theorem
- work done by a varying force

5 Potential energy and energy conservation
- gravitational (mgh) and elastic PE
- conservative and non-conservative forces

6 Momentum, impulse and collision I
- impulse-momentum theorem
- conservation of momentum
- elastic, inelastic, and completely elastic collision

7 Momentum, impulse, and collision II
- elastic collision
- center of mass

8 Dynamics of rigid bodies I
- angular displacement, velocity and acceleration
- rotational kinetic energy and moment of inertia

9 Dynamics of rigid bodies II
- calculation of moment of inertial
- torque

10 Dynamics of rigid bodies III
- rigid body rotation about a moving axis
- work and power in rotation motion

11 Angular momentum
- conservation of angular momentum
- gyroscope

12 Gravitation I
- Newton's law of gravitation
- gravitational force and potential energy
- satellite motion

13 Gravitation II
- Kepler's laws of planetary motion
- spherical mass distribution
- apparent weight due to earth's rotation
- black hole

14 Periodic motion I
- simple harmonic motion

15 Periodic motion II
- various types of SHM, pendulum
- damped and forced oscillations
- resonance

16 Wave motion and sound I
- mathematical description of wave
- power propagation
- reflection of traveling waves

17 Wave motion and sound II
- standing wave
- beat
- Doppler effect

18 Temperature and heat
- thermal expansion
- heat capacity and latent heat
- heat transfer

19 Thermal properties of matter I
- equation of state
- kinetic theory of ideal gas

20 Thermal properties of matter II
- heat capacity of gases
- molecular speed distribution

21 First law of Thermodynamics I
- first law of thermodynamics
- heat and work in thermodynamic processes

22 First law of Thermodynamics II
- typical thermodynamic processes
- heat capacities of ideal gas under different conditions
- adiabatic process of ideal gas

23 Second law of Thermodynamics I
- heat engines and refrigerators
- different forms of the second law

24 Second law of Thermodynamics II
- reversible processes
-Carnot cycle and engine
reviews.comment_teaching:
If you see Cheung Man Fung is one of the instructors of the course of your semester. Don't hesitate, just choose his lecture section. Even you finally cannot enroll in it, you can attend his lecture( sit å ‚).
His explanation to the concepts is very clear. The most difference between him and the other instructors is that he literally writes his own notes during the lessons, while the others just tell the words on the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Tutorial (5%)
â€¢ Must attend registered session
â€¢ 3 lowest score to be dropped
How to earn the score
-Answer Poll Questions during the tutorial session
-0 pt for no answers, 0.75 pt for wrong answers, 1 pt for right answer.

Homework (10%)
â€¢ 11 graded HW sets (HW1 â€“HW11)
â€¢ 2 of the lowest HW scores will be dropped.

Midterm (35%) (Include MC and typing answers)
Content: Lectures 1 - 11

Final (50%) (Include MC and typing answers)
Content: Everything

The grading is good. In my semester, there is a new grading scheme.
"Make the Midterm to be optional and take the higher score of (Midterm scaled to 35% + Final scaled to 50%) OR (Final  scaled to 85%)"

Homework: All correct
Tutorial: 11.5/12
Midterm: 12/27 (Mean: 11.95, Upper Quartile: 15.25)
Final: 25/39 (Mean: 18.78, Upper Quartile: 23.5)
Final grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
For me, I think the content is difficult because lots of the topics were just taught a very little during in secondary school.
If you are not good at physics, the ONLY way to obtain a good grade is to put tons of effort on the practice problems of each topic of the textbook. Especially you should pick up the questions that are dotted twice(â—â—) and choose 1 to 2 questions with 3 dots(â—â—â—).
The difficulty of the exam questions are around the questions with 2 dots, nearly 3 dots.

reviews.comment_teaching:
TLDR: Choose Prof. Cheung's session, not Wong Kam Sing's.

Prof. Cheung's teaching is wonderful.
He will derive complicated formulae step by step in lessons so it is easier to understand.
He has his own written notes on canvas, which are much better.

Wong Kam Sing is one of the worst lecturer I have ever seen.
He teaches by only reading the ppt and he would even stumble while reading.
He used iPRS in the first few lessons. I think it is completely useless since his explanation on the answer is rubbish.
I was first assigned to his session in pre-reg, but I couldn't stand him and I swapped to Prof. Cheung's session.

reviews.author: Sarah7
reviews.comment_content:
The lecture covers very basic concepts of Physics and I suppose all of them are quite easy for mainland students if they studied a bit more further in high school.

The instructor delivers official lecture notes and instructor writes key points on whiteboard step by step while giving detailed explanation, but you have to be very focused on what he is talking about since this physics instructor speaks a little fast, which also shows that he has a clear logic of what he is teaching.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructor is very NICE!!!!

He is very clear about what he is saying and his writing is explict--as eveyony knows, writing style sometimes determines whether you wanna have a look at the whiteboard in class and have a further thinking about the knowledge while you're a bit confused, so it helps!

Besides, this instructor replies emails in extremely details!!!! Even though the reply is not that timely, you won't get any angry as long as you see his logical explanation with examples :))))
reviews.comment_grading:
the grading is good as long as you keep focused on what he is saying in class or if you're mainland student and have a rather strong command of physics in high school then you can directly skip all the lectures and the only thingh you need to do is getting through the lecture notes online and reviewing some classic physics models which we had already met and known very well in high school time, and then you can get good grades. but also NOTE that Tutorial is a must!!!!

2 quizzes (each contains 10 questions, which can be very easy and many people get 9 or 10, you just need to be careful.)

1 final exam (40 or 45 questions in total i forgot sorry.......can be a little bit difficult since you need to apply various concepts within a not long period of time, get familiar and then you can make it!!)

attendence in tutorial (just follow what the TAs tell you to do, practice question is not hard as long as you do not rely on others--you teammates)
reviews.comment_workload: rather low. you just need to understand all the concepts after lecture and know how to apply them into use.

reviews.author: USTAsiaNo1
reviews.title: Great content with kind a huge workload
reviews.comment_content:
A LOT OF  CONTENT

/

For Mathematics, it used a lot single variable calculus but sometimes included partial differentiation and some differentiation equation, it might be challenging to those new to it. Also, included vector.

/

For Physics, it included Newton's law, Energy, Momentum, Dynamics of rigid body, Angular momentum, Gravitation, Periodic motion, Wave, Heat, Law of thermodynamics

/

Warning(tips): NEVER TRY TO THINK YOU CAN LEARN ALL OF THESE EVEN YOU GOT GREAT RESULT IN DSE

For those interested in Physics, it might widen your horizon; if you are not, you might be deadly flooded with tons of knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching:
GOOD

/

I attended total about 4-5 lecture only since the class is too early...
btw, the lecturer will explain and prove the theorem in the slides clearly
It might be helpful if you want to build a solid foundation.

For me, I basically learn all the thing from reading the textbook and slides, it is enough.
reviews.comment_grading:
FAIR

/

I am a business student but I reg this class course due to my interest in Physics.(and I believe I can get a good grade easily due to my great DSE result in Physics)

HOWEVER, in HKUST, there're tons of crazy people, getting an extreme high, even full score in anything. So... GG

/

Assignment(HW): 10%
Test 1: 20%
Test 2: 20%
Final: 50%

/

For me:
HW: 100/100
Test 1: 6/10, mean: 5.5
Test 2: 10/10, mean: 5.2
Final: 25/45, mean: 21.8
Grade: B

So, the grade is not good :(
GGGGGGGGGGGGGG
reviews.comment_workload:
HEAVY

/

Before every test, I strongly suggest you finish the exercise came with the textbook.
Before test1, I didn't do anything and therefore got a fair result
Before test2, I did a lots exercise and therefore go full mark

Since the course included tons of topic, you had better do some revision few days before any test or exam.

Also, the assignment is tricky, I spent average 2 hours in each.

What I learned in this course was pretty much same as what I learned in AP Physics 1 class in high school, so I didn't feel much difficult. Just a little bit of calculus skills are needed? reviews.comment_workload: The workload is a bit harsh. It requires you to finish a weekly assignment online which deduct your mark when you do it wrong. Also there is tutorial that also takes attendance and the performance of the quiz is also marked. While the content of the midterm and final exam is large, I think people need to input more time in this course.

reviews.author: wwiiiing
reviews.comment_content: The jump from IB SL physics to this course is gigantic. I didn't think that my first semester would be spent understanding close to nothing about the syllabus even after getting a good grade in the IB. A fair warning for IB SL physics students: despite the HL students getting a credit transfer, a lot of the topics in this course are beyond what they learned during the IB. Why do they give the HL students credit transfers again?
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor teaches like a text-to-speech, and his handwritten annotations are difficult to comprehend or even read. Maybe I should've went and attended another time slot (This should be possible. Attendance is counted only for tutorials.)
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterms and finals count a lot. Really, if you don't get a good grade in both of these things your homework/tutorial attendance hardly matter at all.
Assignments 10%
Tutorial attendance 5%
Midterm 35%
Finals 50%
The final grading ended up being more lenient than I thought. Even though I ended up with around 30% in both midterms and finals, I still received a B- for my idiocy. I suppose it's because the average score was around 42% both times.
reviews.comment_workload:
One assignment per week, deadline on Sunday. Rather manageable as it's always at the same time unless the website breaks or needs maintenance, for which extra time is given.
If you're the kind of person who has a hard time with the homework, attend all the tutorials. They give you answers for two questions and you can ask the tutors for help with everything else provided you have the courage.

reviews.author: Hintho
reviews.comment_content: Normal physics with some calculus. If you study and finish almost all the questions in the textbook you may get a good grade, but you get to spend a lot of time in order to get high grade.
reviews.comment_teaching: Absolute trash, the professor have no passion in teaching, just skip his lecture and go sit Cheung Man Fung lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: Normal, If you get mean then u get B-, but for the mid term and final is hard.
reviews.comment_workload: One homework per week and the homework is easy. Sometimes you can get answers from the tutorial.

reviews.author: DiesalT
reviews.comment_content:
Newton's Laws of motion
Work-Energy Theorem
Momentum and Impulse
Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum
Gravitation
Simple Harmonic Motion
Wave Motion
Temperature and Heat Capacity
First and second law of thermodynamics
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Po is the best professor in this course I guess. It's good to finally have a local professor who could actually speak English well after having so many mainland professors in other courses. HIs explanation to the concepts are very good and logical, so his lecture is worth attending. Though do expect the lecturers be doing proofs and derivations of the formulas and theorems in lectures rather than explaining exam-type questions with you.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is very fair.
Your grade is directly proportional to your effort spent in this course.
Grading Scheme:
Assignments 10%
Tutorial Attendance 5%
Midterm 35%
Final 50%

Mid term:
Mean: 10.9/24
SD: 4.2
Highest: 24
Lowest 2

Final:
Mean: 17.26/40
SD: 6.68
Highest: 38
Lowest: 4

Assignment: Almost Full
Tutorial Attendance: Full
Midterm: 17/24
Final: 32/40
Letter Grade: A

FYI: DSE physics 5*
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very heavy.
1 Assignment per week which took me 2-3 hours to finish it
Plus a very very broad syllabus
Mastering DSE level stuff will NOT help, unlike most 1000 level course. Therefore you got to familiarize yourself with the calculus approach to physics problems and the new topics.

If you want to get A range in this course:

1. Buy and READ the Textbook thoroughly
2. Do all the hardest questions, examples and the hw assignment yourself, many of these questions will appear in the final exam with only the numerical figures changed.

reviews.author: lancelot
reviews.title: Great course if you like physics
reviews.comment_content:
Only 30% are learned from DSE,  others are new content. Don't trust other who are saying that most of them are DSE content. Actually a DSE student can answer less than 10% of the exam.

The most difficult part are angular momentum and thermodynamics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Don't attend the lectures, lectures are rubbishhhh
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading only if you are really good at physics,  and solving difficult problems

Midterm max score is 24 but Mean score is around 10-11 only, so it is easy to get B- ~ B,  you just need to know 30% of the content

Final is easier than midterm, but you have to remember 10-20 new formula. It takes longer time to study the final exam but questions are not as tricky as midterm.

Also remember to study the heat engine and different cycles, it is not just about the calculation but the process detail and definition.

***************************************************
Don't Trust The Sample Paper !!!!

Difficulty level
Sample paper : 1/10
Midterm : 10/10

I think this maybe the most difficult course for SENG year1.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload

but study midterm and final exam need a lot lf time

reviews.author: An225 Mriya
reviews.title: Not that good, Not that bad??
reviews.comment_content:
Some said that PHYS1112 is basically an advanced version of HKDSE Physics. That's partially true in my opinion.

Course includes:
*Basically everything in HKDSE Physics until Wave Motion
*Calculus definition of certain Physical properties
*Dynamics of rigid bodies
*Simple harmonic motion
*Wave equation and Doppler effect
*Thermodynamic laws (including simplified 2nd Law of Thermodynamics)

Contents from MECH1907 actually supplements the teachings of PHYS1112 in terms of equation derivation by calculus and thermodynamics. For MECH students, after studying PHYS1112 you'll also (momentarily) find everything in MECH2020 and MECH2310 easier, as you've touched these topics in 1112 before.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Some reviews criticized Altman's teaching is boring and does nothing more than reading out the PPT. Is him really bad? At least, his teaching is clear to me TBH. He also tried to maintain interaction with the students by replying to questions (in-lesson and email) and asking MC questions. So... he's not that bad??

Contrary to the overwhelmingly good comments on the TAs, by all means I must give bad comment on my TA, Hailin Yuan. Not only the questions he give are superficially easy (and without further harder questions), his English speaking is also terrible, probably the crappiest lecturer in terms of English-speaking I've seen in UST for my first semester. Moreover, he just shows the answer of tutorial questions in assignments without much explanation: there's only a few tutorials where he gives time for us to solve tutorial questions before he shows and "explains" them (Before I screenshot them for further reference, LOL).

Also did I mention I have COMP1022P lab section 10 minutes later after his tutorial? Yeah, he always overrun with his tutorial section, forcing me to scavenge for other TA's explanation on tutorial questions.

In general, consider avoiding Hailin Yuan at all cost.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments 10%
Tutorials 5%
Midterm 35%
Final Exam 50%

->Which means the exam results are the real game changers of the course. Actually I think my effort on studying for the final exam saved my grade in this course.

Midterm: 14/30
Final: 21.17/42

Ultimately I get a B in PHYS1112.
reviews.comment_workload:
An assignment per week, to be handed after 2 weeks. They've got a help desk session for assignments, which is generally helpful (albeit in some occasions, the TA can't understand the questions well). Leave spare time for the help desk in case you stuck on some assignment question. There's also a email Q&A running on weekdays, but my opinion is that the email Q&A is less useful than the help desk session.

Harder supplementary assignments are also available, and personally, they should be attempted (by all means) to increase your understanding. That's what I did for a week before the final exam.

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: Read this if you have not taken DSE physics
reviews.comment_content:
Writing this review from the perspective of someone who has not taken DSE physics, but have taken PHYS1001. I felt the need to write this because I don't see any reviews aimed at people like us.

First, note that PHYS1001 does not help with this course, the contents in 1001 are so basic and simple that it has no effect whatsoever for 1112.

The main point is that the school essentially just leaves you alone to suffer, so you must try hard yourself.

PHYS1112 covers most of DSE physics, with new parts such as thermodynamics and so on. It's a lot of content for people with no background, but with effort you can pass this course.

For detailed syllabus check other reviews.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lectures (and the lecture notes) expect you to know DSE physics, so they are pretty meaningless if you are like me.

To really learn the content I suggest online resources such as Khan Academy and Organic Chemistry Tutor, they explain the same content, but are much more beginner friendly than the lectures. Spend about an hour or two every week watching their videos and you will not suffer as much.

If you do know DSE physics (Then why are you reading this?) The lectures are fantastic, professor Leung explains concepts very well, lessons are interactive, and he even does live demonstrations over Zoom which is incredible. But again, he expects you to already know DSE physics, so if you didn't take it in high school, no point in attending.
reviews.comment_grading:
Tutorial: 5%
Just join the zoom meeting, and answer one question (very easy question, 10 tutorials in total with 0.5% grade for each, if you answer the question correctly you get 0.5%, otherwise 0.375% only.

Assignments: 10%
Very easy since you can google all the answers, try to get at least over 90% in every assignment.

Midterm: 35%
30 questions, around 10 or so were MCQs, the rest short numerical questions, the midterm did not cover much topics, but the questions were quite difficult, the mean score was 11/30 with a standard deviation of 5.2.

Finals: 50%
42 questions, 15 questions were MCQs, the rest short numerical questions again. The course claims to cover all areas for the finals, but this is a lie as the final focused on thermodynamics, gravitation and harmonics. Again questions were highly difficult, with the mean being 17.8, standard deviation being 7.6. (Consider also this being an online exam, cheating is rampant.)

My grades:
4.75/5% in tutorials
9.4/10% in assignments
mean in midterm
below 0.5sd in finals
Finally got a C+, which was expected
reviews.comment_workload:
For people like us, it is obvious that the workload will be large compared to others, but it is still pretty OK.

Again, you need some time every week to catch up on the course content through watching videos from the aforementioned channels, about an hour or two maybe.

As for the homework, about 1 hour every week since 99% of the questions have full answers on the internet if you google around hard enough.

Midterms and finals, if you have done the above, spend more time going over the notes (you should write your own), focus on thermodynamics for the final in particular.

reviews.comment_teaching:
I only attended lectures from Zeng and Cheung. Both of them teach fine, and they try to use a mathematical approach to derive the formula, but Cheung's derivation is more detailed because he is local prof and he knows our standard, but Zeng just joined ust and she just goes through those proves quickly. Therefore I arrive at Cheung's lecture if I don't understand the part Zeng explained

However, Zeng 's lecture is quite interactive and some of us will answer the qs she raised.

And tutorial is rubbish, it is just for attendance. He couldn't really explain very well.

hw: full (mean 91.8)

One homework each week catching topics reviewed the week before. Quite annoying

But in order to get higher marks in tests, you better finish all 3-star questions in books

reviews.author: S. Kenneth C
reviews.title: Grade is not bad but don't overestimate yourself or underestimate this course
reviews.comment_content:
DSE stuff add on some calculus.
Hard part start from rigid body and rotation KE. SHM, Wave function are very abstract.
Finally thermal dynamics accounts for quite a large amount of final.
Content is not easy and quite useful although some are similar with high school knowledge
reviews.comment_teaching:
Don't expect anything from mainland lecturers
Just read out power point and notes with barely understandable tone. Go for Altman or Chen Tien Wen no doubt.
reviews.comment_grading:
My mid term was all MC but I kind of screw up and getting a poor marks below mean for 1sd, with all HW done with full marks
Final exam, I just got below mean a little bit. Turns out B- which is better than my expectations
But I have seen some people with just few more marks higher than me in final but end up with a B+ OR even A-. That is because only part of the students are high-scorers, the marks range is narrow. Don't make stupid mistakes then you can have high marks.
So, in fact it's quite good grade just that my midterm fxxk up so hard.

Honestly, getting a 4 in DSE means nothing in this course. You have really think carefully whether you really good at physics or not and make sure you have time to revise and do practice problems then a good grade can be expected
reviews.comment_workload:
Usually 1 HW per week. One set of HW have 8-13 questions which some questions are taught by TAs in tutorial sections. Tutorial sections are important because it take attendance.
The concepts are not easy especially when the content go deeper in the late of the course. You need to spend time doing practice that I have to emphasize once again otherwise you may end up getting a B- or C+ which may affect your GPA.

reviews.author: offergod
reviews.title: suggested
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm: The first part is about mechanics and it is not difficult. A little bit new stuff but its easy to understand. I hadn't attend lecture but I can still understand the concepts quickly. I've only study one night before the mid term, just recite all the formulas and understand when I should use these formulas, and this already ok.
Final: The second part is wave and the third part is heat. These two are more difficult than the first part. Really have to work hard to understand them. I think the last part of heat is the most difficult part and I'm quite regret that I should go to lecture. I spend two days to understand the last part xd
reviews.comment_teaching:
I dun know about the lecture because I skipped almost all lecture xd
I've only attended the first two lecture and its really boring.
This course has tutorial session and there tutorial will count your attendance. During the tutorial, TAs will give some worksheet to do, and also will discuss some of the questions in mastering physics (mostly is the question 2/3 haha). And actually you can just do your own stuff in the tutorial, its okay
reviews.comment_grading:
I got a level 4 in DSE. I used one night to revise my mid term and I can still got 23/25->it is not so hard!!
For the final, I think it is pretty changeling, I dun know my marks yet so i can't share now, but I guess I will die
reviews.comment_workload: Quite heavy I think. Every week mastering physics, even you have source, you still need at least one hour to finish. There are12 homework and every hw is around 10-12 questions.

reviews.author: bbbbbbel
reviews.comment_content:
Newton's laws
  - Work, KE and PE
  - Collision and momentum
  - Rotational motion and moment of inertia
  - Angular momentum and energy
  - Gravitational force and energy
  - Kepler's laws, apparent weight and black holes
  - Simple harmonic motion
  - Real pendulum, damped and forced oscillation
Waves
  - Transverse waves, power and reflection
  - Standing waves, beating and Doppler effect
Thermodynamics
  - Thermal expansion and heat
  - Ideal gas law
  - Heat capacity of gas and energy
  - First law of thermodynamics and types of thermodynamics processes
  - Second law of thermodynamics, engine, refrigerator, Carnot cycle and Otto cycle

At first, the content was similar to what was taught in secondary school, but it became extremely difficult after mid-term. You really need to work hard and spend some time on supplementary homework to  get a good grade.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Altman just read out the powerpoint with literally no explanation.

But the TA was really nice and willing to teach us to how do the homework.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite fair. You can probably get an A if you score 35 out of 45 in the final.

Grading scheme
2 tests (20% each)
final (45%)
tutorial (5%)
assignments (10%)
For the two tests, the grading policy is quite complicated. First, the final test grade would be the highest of the following: your 1st-take score/ average of 1st-take and re-take/ 80% of re-take. And then, your grades could be scaled (only up) according to the difficulties of the questions you received. You will get a raw score, scaled score for each take of a test, but you just need to look at the finalized score, which would be released through canvas after the final exam. So, don't worry if you get a very difficult set of questions.

My score
test 1:
1st take: 6/10
2nd take: 9/10
finalized score: 8.21/10
test 2:
1st take: 8/10
2nd take: 7/10
finalized score: 9.15/10
homework: 10/10
final exam: 35/45

grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: Heavy workload. Mastering Physics homework every week, and you only get 6 attempts for every question (2% mark reduction after every wrong attempt).

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: A very rewarding course if you work really hard understanding concepts and drilling exercises
reviews.comment_content:
This course, I would say a more advanced Physics course in Calculus approach comparing with the DSE syllabus.

Test 1 Mechanics:
Vectors
Projectile and Circular Motions
Newtonian Mechanics
Work- Energy Theorem
Momentum Impulses, Collisions and Center of Mass

These are the topics mostly covered in DSE, however new concepts are added, like types of friction, relative velocity, EPE, center of mass etc.

Test 2 Rotational Motion and Waves:
Rotational Motion and Moment of Inertia
Torque and Angular Momentum
Gravitation and Kepler's Laws
SHM , Pendulums and Oscillations

All stuffs appear new, need steps by steps understanding and calculations, require mathematical application and some differentiation.

Wave Equations, Doppler effect and Beats
Temperature and Heat
Thermal Properties of Matters
First and Second Law of Thermodynamics

The most important chapters of this course, need clear undertstanding and require integration and some simple partial differentiation, involve lots of equations and situations.

The content can be demanding if you are lazy or not willing to study Physics/Engineering-related major in the future. But these are the solid foundations for future study in other advanced courses, which are really useful and rewarding.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Cheung is a very handsome and passionate lecturer that I have seen in my first semester study in UST. He is the youngest instructor among the teaching team of PHYS 1112 (should be a young man around 30), very responsible and well-prepared for every lecture, tests and exams as a course coordinator.

Dr. Cheung prepares his own notes in addition to the formal lecture notes (prepared by the Physics Department which I find useless). Before every lecture, he upload his notes on Canvas for students to review. During lectures, he introduces what we are supposed to understand for every topic and explain concepts well in a logical and rational manner. Every single formula and equation required in each chapter are derived in detail, which is easy to follow and noticeable. He explains the key concepts in calculus approach and in verbal sense, formulating a clear picture for each section. He makes lectures interesting and interactive by raising questions and mentioning how these concepts can be applied in our daily life. I have seen some students (especially the foreign students) often respond his questions and raise useful questions) , making lectures more exciting and rewarding. To facilitate learning, demonstrations and experiments are prepared, which are interesting and funny :) I really look forward to attending his class :)

Prof. Leung substituted one of the lectures, he is the vice dean of the Science School and also having long teaching experience. His teaching is more like stick to the formal lecture notes but still explain things logical. He hates students using electronic devices during classes and always asks  students to response his questions. He likes making a metaphor, saying that all these knowledge covered in this course are easy to handle, " You learnt it in kindergarten :) "

Comparing the two instructors, I prefer Dr. Cheung more than Prof. Leung, since he is well-prepared and always ready to make useful responses for any matters in this course. His English is  very fluent and easy to comprehend. Requiring a strong foundation in Physics and attractive teaching, I did spend a lot of time in this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is very fair and reasonable, which reflects your ability and hard work in this course.

Marking rubrics :
Assignments 10%
Tutorial Attendance 5%
Test 1 and Test 2 (each test 20%)
Final exam 45%

The first two tasks should not be a problem for students who never skip classes. For the tests, you are required to register the test date and time on Canvas. Please register immediately after the timetable is released, this can ensure you to choose a better time slot, having more time preparing for the tests.

Each test consist of 10 questions with an hour and 5 minutes to complete. Generally there are calculations and MC questions asking the key concepts of different topics. If you prepare well, getting 7 marks should not be a difficult task.
You can make a retest after the first attempt to get a chance scoring higher or simply have more opportunities drilling the questions.

Final Exam:
The Final covers all topics in this course which is very demanding with very abundant concepts. I strongly advise students to prepare the exam as early as possible. Working on the exercises, past paper and understand the key concepts is a must !

The final consists of 45 MC questions with varying difficulty for different questions. About half of the questions are thermodynamics which require you to work on multiple steps and calculate carefully. Some questions ask the definitions of different principles and equations.

The questions covering Waves and Simple Harmonic Motion can be very difficult, you need to sketch the waveform and identify the multiple usage of equations to obtain the answers. The Mechanics problems, I would say some are easy and some requires you to think carefully before answering.

My score (scaled)
Assignment: 10/10
Tutorials: 5/5
Test 1: 7.72/10
Test 2: 8.73/10
Final: 32/45
Overall: 80%
Final grade is A-.

I strongly advise students to enroll in this course in Fall rather than Spring, the grading in Fall is better and students are generally locals and internationals. Those science students who are required to meet the school requirement, please take this course in Fall if you took DSE Physics. Don't let yourself to be a stupid guy taking those LIFS and CHEM courses you are not familiar with, those will harm your GPA.
reviews.comment_workload:
This course requires you to be a very hardworking person with good understanding of the content for every chapter and good time management for preparing frequent exams, finishing weekly Masturbating Physics and attending the tutorials which I find completely useless and wasting my precious time, as well as spending extra time reading textbook  and drilling additional exercises.

Homework:
You are required to purchase the "University Physics" textbook on Day 1 of the semester at the bookstore in order to obtain an access code for the "Mastering Physics" online assignment system. Assignments are offered weekly and questions provided cover the topics learnt in previous lectures. Each assignment include around 10 questions and take really long time to finish, since you need to first understand the concepts and read the examples, then apply them to the exercises. The assignment system makes everyone exhausted because students received questions with different numbers and the answers vary among students. There's a penalty system for answering wrong, usually 10% mark deduction, so make sure you check your answers and steps before entering the numbers and signs. So, find your friends to work on the assignments together. A warm reminder is that make sure you complete your assignments on time and score more than 90% for each task, to ensure a full mark (10%) for the overall assignment grading.

Tutorials:
You are required to attend the tutorials weekly except the test week. Every tutorials take attendance and contribute 5% of the course grade. My tutorials are boring and useless. People wait for PRS taking attendance, and wait for the TA to explain some of the assignment questions, which I find time-consuming.

Advice for revision and preparation of exams and tests:

*READ THE TEXTBOOK AND THE NOTES
They are the most useful sources of this course, covering all the concepts you should understand and get familiar with. Calculations and examples are very useful for understanding the concepts and please read every single word of the textbook in detail and make some key notes and reminders for yourself.
After understanding the deviation and proofs of the equations, use it often and understand the meaning of each symbols and their units conversion.

* WORK ON TEXTBOOK EXERCISES AND PAST PAPER
The assignment questions are NOT ENOUGH AND ONLY COVER SOME PARTS OF EVERY CHAPTER.
To get familiar with the key concepts and calculations, work on the exercises at the end of each chapter, calculations and graphical drawings are required in this course. I strongly recommend students work more further problems on thermodynamics which cover about half of the final exam paper.

Being a student who only received a Level-4 in DSE Physics, I strongly advise students who are not smart but diligent and hardworking to spend more time on this course, hard work really pays off for this course :) Since topics are the solid foundations for further studies in engineering and physics.

å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†ä¸­å­¸å­¸éæ—¢åŠ›å­¸åŒHEAT AND GAS éƒ½æœƒæ•™
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Cheung is a good teacher and professor, he will listen to our question and answer us patiently. During his lesson, he will give out a lot of demonstration. Although some time he skip the lesson ( I remember one time he went to America and didnt flight back on time.), he still give us an extra lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
I didn't attent the tutorial because of the time conflict, so I do the exercise by myself. Just remember to do all the question in the book, than you will get a high gread.

P.S Got an A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much webwork to do
If you don't know, try to google it (You are already a university student, you should know how to use this powerful skill)

reviews.author: Ar Mong
reviews.title: Hard, but hard-working can save you
reviews.comment_content:
Even though everyone taking this class should have taken physics and M2 is secondary school, but this class is still too fast and difficult for most of us.
The content is always started with something that seems we learnt in secondary school, but in a more advanced manner(i.e. involving a lot of calculus, especially integration). The content will usually become very difficult in the second part of the topic, consisting more concepts, new methods and difficulties.
Also the topics in a semester is not really related, from gravitation to force and motion and to gas. The content may confused people when taking a quiz because of don't know what equations should be used
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Cheung is good at explaining difficult concepts and very clear about it. But sometimes he may goes a bit too fast for students hard to keep track on.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is fair and not difficult.
The tutorial class is required for attendance and count towards your final grade.
There are several quiz which  has to be done out of class time. The quiz is quite difficult and the mean is pulled up by smart student. You have a second for re-taking the quiz and take the average for the final grades.
But the final is very difficult.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are ten to fifteen questions related to the topics each week. The quiz take place once in three weeks. The tasks in tutorial is easy and clear.
If you are not familiar with the content, there are ~forty extra questions for you to practice on.
The final requires a very good study, it is very difficult.

reviews.author: Tanmay1
reviews.title: Difficult Physics Course.. Need to work hard
reviews.comment_content: The course content is very similar to IB Physics + IB Physics engineering option. Rotational mechanics is extremely hard and takes a long time to fully understand. Concepts are hard however the level of calculus needed isn't that hard.
reviews.comment_teaching: Tian Wen Chen was an okay teacher, his demonstrations were sometimes funny however most of the lecture consisted of him teaching from the lecture slides and showing proofs of equations. My suggestion would be that going to lecture is only useful for tough topics and if you have any questions.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is difficult, must get above mean at all times, however the course allows you to take a retake of the midterms which can help improve your grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not that much however the concepts are difficult to understand. To get a good grade in this course one cannot just do the homework and do the exams but must study regularly and keep the physics concept fresh in the mind. Since the grading scheme is difficult and a lot of smart people take this course, you need to work hard to do well.

reviews.author: Lww
reviews.comment_content: Before midterm are just simple secondary school physics knowledge, but after it, you will learn some AL physics knowledge
reviews.comment_teaching: Boring, you can skip the lesson if you want since the teaching style of this instructor is following the notes and read all the things on them again during the lessons.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is not bad and fair enough, I have done all my online assignment with 100% marks and finished the midterm with 90% and the final exam with 70%, finally I got A in this course.
reviews.comment_workload: There is an online assignment each week, it's easy to finish if you get any sources from the senior. But i recommend you to revise all knowledge taught in the lessons immediately since you need to pay double time to understand it if you don't do so

reviews.author: ZHANG Weilin
reviews.comment_content: Not very difficult at the beginning. We can learn some of the knowledge in our secondary school. The difficulty will increase after midterm. We have to understand what we have learnt.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is patient and helpful. Teaching is a bit boring but we can understand the knowledge deeply in the course.
reviews.comment_grading: Not very good, but not bad. We need to be careful and patient in the exams so that we can get a better grade.
reviews.comment_workload: We have assignments almost every week. Most of them are easy. But after midterm, it will be more difficult and more time-consuming.

reviews.author: Gman
reviews.comment_content: It covers quite a lot from what we've done in high school with some additional content in each of the parts. The concepts are understandable but require a lot of practice to really grasp it completely as some of the questions in the tests and exam can be tricky.
reviews.comment_teaching: I found the lectures to be a waste of time. The professor was struggling to make us understand some of the concepts. I'd suggest to study for the course by yourself.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is quite terrible.
reviews.comment_workload:
This course has webwork due very weekend and each mistake you make will you cost a few marks.

There are two mid-terms with 12 mcs each and one final with 45 mcs. You'll have to practice a lot to grasp the content well enough to answer some of the trick questions.

reviews.author: BBHoCute
reviews.comment_content:
If you studied physic in secondary school, the content was easy to you because about 50% of the content was taught in secondary school. If you studies M2 in secondary school, it would be better.

This course had two quizzes instead of a mid-term examination this year (2015 Fall), I don't know whether it will change next year because the course had a mid-term exam but no quizzes.
reviews.comment_teaching: The tutorial class will teach you how to think to solve the problem step by step. And the lecture notes are similar to secondary school textbook.
reviews.comment_grading: if you get mean score in the overall score of the course, you will get a "B-"
reviews.comment_workload: I think the webwork is more difficult than the examination, I took about 1 hour to solve one question...

reviews.author: Akshay
reviews.comment_content:
Level of content isn't too high. Covers everything done in high school. Exams might have a couple of trick questions oherwise it's doable.This course covers the mechanics part of physics -
kinematics
work, energy and power
rotational motion
Simple harmonic motion
Sound
Thermodynamics
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture is a waste of time. First of all it's super boring plus the level of English wasn't up to the mark. The professor was unable to make us understand the concepts in English. It's better to buy the book and do it yourself. It'll prove to be more helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
I took this course in Spring semester and grading was absolutely disastrous.

Homework - 141/141 which was way above class mean of 116.3.
Test 1 -  Mean+SD. Mean - 5.8/12. SD - 3ish.
Test 2  - Mean+SD. Mean - 6.5/12. SD - 2.3.
Final Exam  - Mean + SD. Mean was 25.6/45. SD - 9.5.

And I still got B+.

If you take this course in Fall sem, you'll get around A or A+ for the same score.
reviews.comment_workload:
Webwork every weekend which is tiresome as getting wrong answers will cost you marks. You have to study everyday in order to complete the webwork every week.
You'll have 2 Mid Terms containing 12 MCQs each + 1 Final exam with 45 MCQs.

reviews.author: hayhay
reviews.title: Accidentally a good course
reviews.comment_content:
The first 4 chapter is all about secondary school stuff, so that's easier.
Starting from chapter5 to 11, this is about some forces(moment of inertia, momentum and torque), a bit difficult and hard to imagine what's happening. From 12 to 24(after mid-term), the content is much easier, gravitation, wave, and heat/ thermodynamic. If you can't understand the content, just memorize the formula and do more exercise
The midterm is more difficult if you compare it to the final exam
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Cheung's lecture is very interesting, his notes are definitely helpful, there are demos in the lecture, and you can try some of them after the end of the lesson. The tutorial is compulsory, and it takes attendance, make sure you go to the tutorial on time.
In the tutorial, the tutor will teach you the formula again, and show you the answer of 1 assignment question!!!
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is not bad, getting the mean score means u will get a B(at least, for sure)
reviews.comment_workload: One assignment a week, quite time-consuming, usually spending 3 hours for one homework.

reviews.author: mattmatt_mm
reviews.title: DIfficult content but good grading. Focus on the concept not the calculation
reviews.comment_content:
The course teaches friction, vectors, acceleration, circular motion, thermodynamics, radiation, and gravity.
You need to memorise most equations mentioned and they will provide an equation sheet with some equations and constants.
The calculations for the midterm and finals are easy however the concept behind the questions is somewhat difficult. Half of the questions I did was wild guesses with eliminations.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is all right as the professor explains most concepts in a beginner-friendly manner. But when the concepts get kinda difficult I had a hard time understanding even paying full attention.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very good. I got a mean score but I still get a B-. It is hard to get a C if you work hard enough and understand the major concepts. More than half of the questions in the finals require you to understand the content and I recommend you to read the textbook as some concepts are not mentioned in the lecture but appear in the finals.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite high as there will be an assignment containing 11-20 phys questions and each of them contains abcd parts. Each time it takes me 3-5 hours to finish one assignment.

reviews.author: IDIOTHAHAHA
reviews.title: need to practice and some luck for both exams
reviews.comment_content:
First half contain some dse stuff and some new stuff.
Most content in second half are very difficult. For example, periodic motion, wave, thermodynamic 1&2 are very difficult for me. It took me a lot of time to learn and revise them. There are a large amount of formulae you need to memorize and many of them are not in the formula sheet in the exam.

The poor teaching quality make me hate the content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Take attendance for tutorial but not in lecture. You need to complete the worksheet in each tutorial.

The lecturer in my session is bad. He kept speaking but didn't know witch parts we find it difficult to understand. His lecture powerpoints aren't good at all too.
reviews.comment_grading:
HW 10%
tutorial 5%
midterm 35%
final 50%

28 mc for midterm and 40-1=39 mc for final
closed book exams

my score for midterm and final exams are about 1 sd above mean.
final grade:A-
I expected an A though
ref: got 5 in dse physics
reviews.comment_workload:
There are mastering physics homework for every week that takes 3 hours to finish. Many of them are difficult and each wrong attempt would deduct 6 mark. You have a maximum of 5 attempts only for each question so it means after 5 wrong attempts you will get 0 mark. I would recommend keeping every homework at above 98% mark.

Btw, true or false questions and mc questions allow oneeeeeeee attempt only. If you do them wrongly, you would get 0 mark for that part and no more attempt is allowed!!!!!

I always stuck at those questions that I did wrongly for the first attempt so I took a lot of time to finish. Remember to check carefully when you submit the answers.

There is also a dynamic study module that can give you bonus mark that contribute to homework if you complete 8 topics. I did that too.

As for revision for exams, It is a nightmare to memorize a large amount of formulae and do practices. There are 3 online practice exams in https://lon-capa.phys.ust.hk/ each for midterm and final exam but they are released only 1 week before the exam. Since I was afraid of getting C, I worked hard and finished all practice exams before the real exams. However, for the online practice exams, after finishing them,  there were no steps from question 20 to 40 so I found it super difficult to study some topic especially thermodynamics.

Tips:
1) clear concepts especially in thermodynamic 1&2
2) In the second half, gravitation and doppler effect are relatively easier topic so make sure you can master them
3) memorize equations especially in periodic motion, wave motion

Basically not only do you need to study hard but also some luck in the exam since they are all mc questions.

reviews.author: tianyu
reviews.comment_content: see others.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is quite good and quite interesting. However, his lectures are at 1030am which is too early for me. So I didn't go to the lectures (as I cannot wake up in the morning) nor watch the lecture video ( too lazy).
reviews.comment_grading: My bad for not revising the final exam early. I should have attended the lectures or watched the video. But now I only get 1 SD above the mean and turns out to be A-. Plz don't revise ALL NOTES ONE DAY before the exam or you will just have an A- like me.
reviews.comment_workload: Every week you need to do one homework ( around 1-2 hours). This time there are some extra questions such as the Dyson sphere but not too hard. Considering the tutorial attendance and the homework, I think the workload is heavy.

reviews.author: ccnncmjt
reviews.title: Very Difficult Course
reviews.comment_content: The course material is considerably more challenging than that of secondary school, particularly the section on waves.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is good and writes everything on his iPad and displays on the screen. Attendance is required for tutorials, and full marks can be obtained by copying the answers and submitting the completed worksheet.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading system is fair and it is possible to obtain an A- with a score is 1 SD higher than the mean. The scores follow a normal distribution, with a not-so-high mean. It is feasible to achieve a score higher than the mean, even if you don't comprehend every concept and understand everything.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for this course is quite heavy, requiring approximately 2-3 hours on the assignment every week. Submitting an incorrect answer results in an immediate loss of points. It is recommended to aim for a nearly perfect score on the assignments, as the mean score is very high.

reviews.author: Kingyiu
reviews.comment_content: The midterm and exams in this course were very challenging. They required a high level of understanding and often required significant time and effort to complete.
reviews.comment_teaching: It will have a small experiment after each lesson, pretty interesting
reviews.comment_grading:
Attend all tutorials and finish all the hw will help u get a good grade. I got lower quarter in both midterm and exam, however I attend all the tutorials and finished all hws results in C+. As I only know 4 chapters, I felt satisfied with the grading.

Midterm 9/25
Final 16/40
reviews.comment_workload: One hw per week

Secondary school physics with M2
Mostly regarding force and motion
Thermodynamics:
