reviews.author: HU-HT
reviews.comment_content:
It is a huge extension of high school Physics + Calculus. Make sure you understand how to apply calculus.

Syllabus:
L1 Physical Quantities, Vectors and 2D Motion
L2 Newton's Law of Motion I
L3 Newton's Law of Motion II
L4 Work and Kinetic Energy
L5 Potential Energy and Energy Conservation
L6 Momentum, Impulse, and Collisions I
L7 Momentum, Impulse, and Collisions II
L8 Dynamics of Rigid Bodies I
L9 Dynamics of Rigid Bodies II
L10 Dynamics of Rigid Bodies IIII
L11 Angular Momentum
L12 Gravitation I
L13 Gravitation II
L14 Periodic Motion I
L15 Periodic Motion II
L16 Wave Motion and Sound I
L17 Wave Motion and Sound II
L18 Temperature and Heat
L19 Thermal Properties of Matter I
L20 Thermal Properties of Matter II
L21 First Law of Thermodynamics I
L22 First Law of Thermodynamics II
L23 Second Law of Thermodynamics I
L24 Second Law of Thermodynamics II

No attendance of lectures is required, but attendance of tutorials is.
Buying books is mandatory because you need it in order to access MasteringPhysics, which you need in order to do assignments.
reviews.comment_teaching:
HIs teaching is interesting, with some demonstrations during the lectures. Well... some succeeded while some failed.
Tutorials are extremely boring and I only go there because attendance is required and there are hints to help solve some questions in the assignments.
reviews.comment_grading:
5% Tutorial attendance
10% Homework
35% Mid-term exam
50% Final exam

For tutorial attendance, TA would give you a worksheet to do at about the end of the tutorial. 0 for no answer, 0.75 for wrong answer and 1 for all right answer. Don't worry, TA will give you the answer at the end of tutorial.
3 lowest score will be dropped

For homework, graded HW sets are HW1 to HW11. Total 11.
2 lowest homework score will be dropped.
There are also dynamic study modules, which add as a bonus score to the homework score.

Mid-term exam
Mean = 13.5 out of 26
Standard deviation = 4.47
Median = 13 out 0f 26

Final exam
Mean = 19.38 out of 40
Standard deviation = 7.05
Median = 19 out of 40

My result:
Mid-term exam: 17/26
Final exam: 29/40
(I calculated, could be wrong:
Tutorial attendance: 5/5
Homework: 10/10
Overall score: 74.13
)
Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 11 homework sets that may count towards the overall score. There are 2 optional homework sets: HW0 for knowing how to use Mastering Physics and HW12.
The homework may need you a lot of time to do and only give you 6 attempts per question so be sure to double check your answers! I can't count how many times I solve the questions in my last attempt.

reviews.comment_content:

- Physical Quantities, Vectors, and 2D Motion
- Newton's Laws of Motion
- Work and Kinetic Energy

- Momentum, Impulse, and Collisions

- Simple Harmonic Motion

Waves/Acoustics:
- Wave Motion and Sound

Thermodynamics:
- Temperature and Heat
- Thermal Properties of Matter
- First Law of Thermodynamics
- Second Law of Thermodynamics
reviews.comment_teaching: good
reviews.comment_grading: good
reviews.comment_workload: Quite heavy I think. Every week mastering physics, even you have source, you still need at least one hour to finish. There are12 homework and every hw is around 10-12 questions.

reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching: Mr. Altman is a good teacher and his classes are generally entertaining. Although I'm not good at physics I could understand the theories relatively well.
reviews.comment_grading: The first part of this course was similar to what was taught in IB, and the midterm wasn't too bad. But the finals were pretty difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework every week, is pretty difficult but doable. Spent like two hours every week.

reviews.title: A course that require hardwork
reviews.comment_content: A bit hard, but if you do enough exercise and understand how to do them then you can understand that topic. You can see the content of this course in other review so I will not list it here.
reviews.comment_teaching:
As a general student, some topic that i havn't seen in high school is difficult and hard to understand in the first time. Keep follow up each topic after teaching, the schedule is a little bit tight. Professor Chen is actually a good teacher, but I sleep a lot on lessons.

The tutorial class of mine is like this: half of time doing two difficult questions of the assignment, half time showing how to do them with the model answer. I will say the tutorial doesn't help me a lot.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% for assignment
5% for tutorial classes
35% for mid-term exam
50% for final exam

I should get around 90% in the assignment,
full attendence in tutorial class,
15/26 in mid-term exam,
25/40 in final exam
and I get A- eventually

I would say if you listen every lecture, do all assignment and do about 3 pastpaper before each exam, you can get A or A+. As I really skip the wave part in the exam because I don't really understand this topic.
reviews.comment_workload:
One assignment for each week, it is not a easy job, so I suggest you to finish them as early as you can. Each assignment has about 10 questions.
No attendence in lecture. And the lecture has recording, so do not need to afraid if you cannot go for the lecture. But attendence exist in tutorial class. Maybe this 5% grade can increase one sub-grade. So I reccomend you go all of them even it doesn't really help.
Don't forget having revision before exam.
That's all.

reviews.author: Osmond Ho
reviews.comment_content:
Motions and Newton's laws
Work and energy
Conservation of energy and momentum
Rotation
Rigid body
Simple harmonic and damped oscillations
Forced oscillations
Standing waves and sound waves
Kinetic theory
The laws of thermodynamics
In terms of content, the course was depth than the high school curriculums.
reviews.comment_teaching: You are most likely not going to understand a thing in the lectures. You need to put more time to study yourself.
reviews.comment_grading: Depends on how many time you give. If you want to get a good grade. You need to do many questions and understand the idea.
reviews.comment_workload: Huge workload to get a high grade. Remember to finish all the assignments.

reviews.author: clementds
reviews.comment_content: In terms of content, what was thought in the course was covered in most high school curriculums (DSE, etc.). Though, the depth of the materials is relatively deeper, which makes the exams to be harder. Besides, Prof. Cheung always provided students with various types of content, ranging from theories to practical examples.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Cheung has one of the best teaching techniques I have ever encountered. His approach to both theories and practicals made the class to be easier and more interesting. He and his TA always brought physics props from the laboratory to explain how a particular theory could occur in the real-world setting.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is okay. Even though some people say that the grading is not that good, as long as you could understand all of the theories that are being taught, it is safe to say that you would do pretty well in the exams.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload consists of weekly/biweekly homework/assignment, attendance (tutorial), and exams (midterm & final). All in all, the workload was manageable when the course is being put to a 15-18 credit semester.

reviews.author: terryxyy
reviews.comment_content:
In the first half of the course, most of content are covered in the rigid body , energy and wave sections covered by DSE with the exception of rotating objects.
The second half of the course, we will learn about wave equation, ideal gas and the laws of thermodynamics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Usually, the teacher just repeated the slices and gave a little explain. He would do some demonstrations to make the lecture interesting, but I think it's more important to rely on after-school efforts to get a better grading.
reviews.comment_grading:
quite good
midterm +1.6 SD
final +1.2 SD
grading: A
reviews.comment_workload: an assignment per week, I usually spend 1- 2 hours to finish it.

reviews.author: yyJeff
reviews.title: Not an easy course
reviews.comment_content:
Classical Mechanics
- Physical Quantities, Vectors, and 2D Motion
- Newton's Laws of Motion
- Work and Kinetic Energy
- Potential Energy and Energy Conservation
- Momentum, Impulse, and Collisions
- Dynamics of Rigid Bodies

Waves/Acoustics:

Thermodynamics:

- Second Law of Thermodynamics
reviews.comment_teaching: Zeng Bei and Cheung Man Fung are all nice teachers but Zeng's teaching mode is boring for me and I sometimes don't know what did she say because of her accent. Finally, I choose to watch Cheung's recording video, and I really like the style, We could know how to get the formulas by following Cheung's steps.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not bad.
midterm: mean 13.5/26 S.D.=4.47
               median 13/26
               me        22/26 (+1.9 sd)
final: mean=19.38/40 S.D.=7.05

assignment and tutorial: about full marks
final grade= A (reference: DSE physics 5*)

one week one homework (around 2 hrs)

HOWEVER, you need to do more exercise from textbook if you want to get good grade and the workload is large.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is quite dull. It mainly depends on the ppt. You can understand the concepts by yourself.

There are many powerpoints and slides. You can do your revision by yourself. Concepts are important. Make sure you understand them and try to do the assignments by yourself. Thus, you can make confident of what have you learned.

Some students may not go to the lectures but still can get good grades. It is because they make lots of time on the self-revision.
Some concepts are quite difficult and make sure you understand them before mid-term and final.

Tutorials 5%
Midterm 35%
Final Exam 50%

reviews.comment_workload:
An assignment on Mastering Physics is given.

Each one consists of around 10 to 15 questions. The tutorial may cover 1 to 2 questions of the difficult ones.

may spend 1 to 2 hours to do it
some additional exercise

In conclusion, the workload depends on the grade you aim at.

reviews.author: alph4go
reviews.title: good for me
reviews.comment_content:
didnt pay much attention to that after midterm, but it was mainly force and motion in the first half, and thermodynamics after the midterm.

everything is calculus-based and there are many calculus included computations in questions.

tutorial are not mandatory but appearing there boosts your attendence marks

honorable mention: some tutorial have good TAs but mine was horrible.
reviews.comment_teaching:
professor PANT, Nidhi have strong indian accent and not many of us could understand what she is saying, also the things she taught is not the main testing part in midterm/final exams.

though surely she is a kind professor
reviews.comment_grading:
Tutorial attendance 5%
Assignment 10%
Midterm 35%
Finals 50%

grades of mine: C
Assigenments: around 80%
Tutorial: 7.75/12
Midterm: 11/26 (Âµ=13.50, Ïƒ=4.47)
Finals: 11/40 (Âµ=19.38, Ïƒ=7.05)

pretty good for me cause i never study most topics in final exams until the day before it. luck arises sometimes.
reviews.comment_workload: homework given every week, in which each requires around 60-90 minutes for completion.

reviews.author: 3_n
reviews.title: Can be very frustrating if you are not into physics
reviews.comment_content:
This course works like an extension of HKDSE physics. They introduce classical mechanics from newton's law of motion, conservation of energy & momentum, to kinetic theory, circular motion, laws of gas, as well as thermodynamics.

Calculus is involved in most if not all topics. This course requires calculus more than those in HKDSE M2: nabla operator (optional),  partial derivatives, etc., and you have to be very clear do what these symbols mean; If you believe you can't do so, it's still alright as these are not the majority (but it's still suggested to know those before studying so you know what's happening).
reviews.comment_teaching:
I attended PANT, Nidhi's course. I can tell that Nidhi is passionate about teaching Physics, but her English accent as well as her way of teaching made me confused, not to mention she was behind the schedule for around 0.5-1 weeks. Nonetheless, she still tries her best to explain phenomena to us.

I didn't attend other instructors' lectures and have nothing to say about them.
reviews.comment_grading:
It's quite easy to get a fair/higher grade in my opinion (as long as you are around mean, you should be able to get a B-) but you definitely need a solid physics foundation for that (exams usually cover some basic physics with a little bit of calculus).

Weighting:
Assignment 10%, Tutorial attendance 5%, Midterm 35%, Finals 50%

My grade:
Assignments: 104.24/106 (approx)
Tutorial: 10.75/12
Midterm: 17/26 (Âµ=13.50, Ïƒ=4.47, z=0.783)
Finals: 32/40 (Âµ=19.38, Ïƒ=7.05, z=1.790)
Final letter grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload can be heavy (too heavy for a 3-credit course in my opinion.)

Tutorials are a must and they take away 1 hour every week, not to mention the homework which you might have no idea how to do. The worse part is, there is new homework every single week and you would only know how to finish that week's homework by attending that week's lectures (which makes it more stressful since you only have a few days to finish).

reviews.author: worstUSTstudent
reviews.comment_content:
1. Physical quantities, Vectors, and 2D Motion
2. Newton Laws of Motion - I and II
3. Work and Kinetic Energy
4. Potential Energy and Conservation
5. Momentum, Impulse, and Collision - I and II
6. Dynamics of Rigid Bodies - I, II, III, IV [Angular Momentum]
7. Gravitation - I and II
8. Periodic Motion - I and II
9. Wave motion and Sound - I and II
10. Temperature and Heat
11. Thermal Properties of Matter - I and II
12. First Law of Thermodynamics - I and II
13. Second Law of Thermodynamics - I and II
14. Entropy (not included in Final)

kind of a harder extended version of DSE Physics
reviews.comment_teaching: Cheung Man Fung is actually so nice and makes jokes in class. He is always open to questions after lecture. However, he uses a lot of time to explain the derivations of equations, and then goes on to say that we don't actually have to know how to derive the equations. But he explains the concepts quite clearly so be sure to pay attention even though the chairs and room temperature in the lecture theatre makes it very easy to fall asleep.
reviews.comment_grading:
assignments 10%
tutorials 5%
midterm 35%
final exam 50%

Please remember to go to tutorials as they count attendance despite being quite useless.

Even though I am very dumb and only understood very little stuff in exam papers, I did not fail this course, which was unexpected.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload was heavier compared to other courses because we had to hand in one homework every week from the first lecture until final exam. However, the homework will help you understand the concepts better and are useful for your mid-term and finals. Please do the optional supplementary exercises as they are useful too.

terribly hard, there is a LOT to learn and grasp
quite a umber of formulas and calculations as well

great teaching but content just difficult
the professor focused on deriving formulas which are not needed for midterms or finals so time was wasted trying to understand them
he's passionate in teaching though
reviews.comment_grading:
mean is quite low
for midterms, mean was 13.5/ 26 and for finals, mean was 19/40
reviews.comment_workload:
homeworks every week and each hw takes about 2-3 hours so it's quite heavy
you are required to attend tutorials for it needs attendance but not for lectures

reviews.title: think before you choose this course if you are not interested in physics
reviews.comment_content:
extension of topics in high school.
new topics including rigid body, thermodynamics.
very hard for those who are not interested in physics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
typical lessons, you should have high interest in physics or else you may fall asleep in the lessons.
I didn't pay attention in or attend classes after midterm, done all of them by self-learning.
reviews.comment_grading:
assignment 10%
tutorials 5%
midterm 35%
final exam 50%
easy sample paper hard for real one haha
reviews.comment_workload: weekly assignment with about 10 questions (not including sections) in mastering physics(publisher). if getting below 95% will have an extra assignment with no credits.

reviews.author: Juin
reviews.comment_content:
Newton's laws of motion I
Newton's laws of motion II
Work and kinetic energy
Potential energy and energy conservation
Momentum, impulse and collision
Dynamics of rigid bodies
Angular momentum
Gravitation
Periodic motion
Wave motion
temperature and heat
thermal properties
thermodynamics

Although I have learned some concepts before in A-Level, this course requires the calculus approach to the concepts that are completely new.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecturer Cheung Man Fung is definitely a good lecturer. He explains the concept well in a way that will allow you to understand the entire syllabus. He prepared his own lecturer notes which are all handwritten. Personally, I prefer his lecture notes to the normal lecture notes which are shared between all the lecturers as I found out that his notes are more concise and easier to understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
The midterm and final are difficult but this course is based on bell curve grading so the grade isn't that bad. This course requires tutorial attendance and is counted into final grades.

The grading system:
Assignment: 10%
Tutorials: 5%
Mid-term exam: 35%
Final exam: 50%

For your reference,
Midterm: 22/26 (Mean: 13.5/26)
Final: 34/40 (Mean: 19/40)
Assignments: Almost full marks
Tutorial attendance: Full

I turned out getting an A+ for this course.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for this course is quite high and requires you to put in the effort to get good grades. Every week has to submit an assignment via Mastering Physics. An assignment takes about 2-4 hours to complete. There are also supplementary problems for you to practice but are not counted in final grades. I would recommend you complete all the exercises given every week and the practice exams to get you to familiarise yourself with different types of questions and ways to answer the questions.

reviews.author: Haris
reviews.title: Crammed to Death
reviews.comment_content:
1. Physical quantities, Vectors, and 2D Motion
2. Newton Laws of Motion - I and II
3. Work and Kinetic Energy
4. Potential Energy and Conservation
5. Momentum, Impulse, and Collision - I and II
6. Dynamics of Rigid Bodies - I, II, III, IV [Angular Momentum]
-------- Midterm Topics

7. Gravitation - I and II
8. Periodic Motion - I and II
9. Wave motion and Sound - I and II
10. Temperature and Heat
11. Thermal Properties of Matter - I and II
12. First Law of Thermodynamics - I and II
13. Second Law of Thermodynamics - I and II
-------- Final Topics

14. Entropy [Optional Lecture]

2 lectures every week, along with weekly tutorials where attendance is mandatory. Tutorial begins with basic recap of the topics in the homework, then provides time for students to solve two questions collaboratively before showing how to solve.

Homework over Canvas is due every week consisting of textbook questions covering two lectures.

Only attendance is mandatory during the Tutorials, however noting down how to solve the questions will help immensely on how to tackle most other homework questions.

Both the Mid-term and Final Exams are multiple choice, with Final including Mid-term topics. The Mid-term is a 2 hour exam, and the Final a 3 hour exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This course can be done without attending a single lecture. However, i would recommend attending them to have a set study schedule and to see where the lecturers' expand in the lecture slides.

Tian Wen Chen is an adequate lecturer, with some passion in teaching this course. He writes on the lecture slides with extra information, and solves the examples step-by-step.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments 10%
Tutorials         5%
Midterm       35%
Final Exam 50%
reviews.comment_workload: Due to a new topic being covered every week, just following the lectures and homework is not enough to study for the exams; especially if there's a topic you're weak in. So aside from the weekly homework, one has to actively read ahead to see where one is weak and revise concepts well before the exams.

reviews.author: MCï¼£ï½ˆï½‰ï½ƒï½‹ï½…ï½
reviews.title: Good grade course with effort
reviews.comment_content:
The lectures go through basic mechanics before midterm, such as Newton's law of motion, projectile motion, circular motion, rigid bodies (which did not cover in HKDSE). After midterm, there are some topics like wave motion, simple harmonic motion, gravitation, thermodynamics (an very important topic)
To be honest, most of the topics have covered in DSE syllabus.
A well understanding and practices are necessary. Also, calculus is involved in almost all topics.
You need to buy a textbook for doing hw and practice questions.
reviews.comment_teaching: Wong Kam Sing is definately trash. The first uncomfortable thing is the accent. It is very hard to hear. Another thing is that he read the power point aloud in the lessons with little or no explaination. So, al last I did not attend his lectures instead I revise Cheung Man Fung notes. He will prepare his own hand-written notes which are easy to follow.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not bad.
Mid-term 26MC, Final 40 MC (better practice more)
(I did take DSE M2 and Phy and both got 4)
Hw >80%
mid term 16/26 (mean 13)
Final 22/40 (mean 19.38)
Result B+

To conclude: The content is kinda hard for those who weak in physics but good grade as everyone doesn't know and guess the mc. If you slightly higher than mean then easy to get B range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Total 12 assignment (HW0-HW12), The worst two assignments will be dropped. Each assignment has around 10 questions. I suggest to pay attention to do it all because the exam and mt will have similar question. All tutorial attendance will be graded but lecture attendance will not. 1 midterm and 1 final will be graded.
So, the workload is fairly light.

reviews.author: Erilai
reviews.title: Heavy workload, yet rewarding
reviews.comment_content:
The content before the midterm (Newtonian Mechanics) is mostly DSE stuff with some calculus, and is relatively easy(except the "Dynamics of Rigid Bodies III" part where calculations are quite confusing and require clear concepts). Most of the topics taught after the MT are not covered in DSE  e.g. Thermodynamics. Also the teaching is more 'chur' after the MT, so it is easy to lag behind if you miss lectures.

Syllabus:

1. Physical quantities, vectors & Motion in 2D
- projectile

2. Newton's laws of motion I
- Relative Motion
- Reference Frame
- Newton's Three Laws

3. Newton's laws of motion II
- Friction
- Circular motion

4. Work and kinetic energy
- work-energy theorem
- work done by a varying force

5. Potential energy and energy conservation
- gravitational (mgh) and elastic PE
- conservative and non-conservative forces

6. Momentum, impulse and collision I
- impulse-momentum theorem
- conservation of momentum
- elastic, inelastic, and completely elastic collision

7. Momentum, impulse, and collision II
- elastic collision
- center of mass

8. Dynamics of rigid bodies I
- angular displacement, velocity and acceleration
- rotational kinetic energy and moment of inertia

9. Dynamics of rigid bodies II
- calculation of moment of inertial
- torque

10. Dynamics of rigid bodies III
- rigid body rotation about a moving axis
- work and power in rotation motion

11. Angular momentum
- conservation of angular momentum
- gyroscope

~~~~~~~~midterm~~~~~~~~

12. Gravitation I
- Newton's law of gravitation
- gravitational force and potential energy
- satellite motion

13. Gravitation II
- Kepler's laws of planetary motion
- spherical mass distribution
- apparent weight due to earth's rotation
- black hole

14. Periodic motion I
- simple harmonic motion

15)Periodic motion II
- various types of SHM, pendulum
- damped and forced oscillations
- resonance

16. Wave motion and sound I
- mathematical description of wave
- power propagation
- reflection of traveling waves

17. Wave motion and sound II
- standing wave
- beat
- Doppler effect

18. Temperature and heat
- thermal expansion
- heat capacity and latent heat
- heat transfer

19)Thermal properties of matter I
- equation of state
- kinetic theory of ideal gas

20. Thermal properties of matter II
- heat capacity of gases
- molecular speed distribution

21. First law of Thermodynamics I
- first law of thermodynamics
- heat and work in thermodynamic processes

22. First law of Thermodynamics II
- typical thermodynamic processes
- heat capacities of ideal gas under different conditions
- adiabatic process of ideal gas

23. Second law of Thermodynamics I
- heat engines and refrigerators
- different forms of the second law

24. Second law of Thermodynamics II
- reversible processes
- Carnot cycle and engine
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cheung MF:
Very x N good and friendly professor. Very willing to answer questions and never get annoyed. Explains everything clearly in lectures. Lecture notes are handwritten. Prof Cheung's teachings also includes more in-depth theories, derivation of formulas, which are sometimes difficult to understand (but don't panic since this is not the focus of the course and will not be examined)

Wong Kam Sing:
I am sure I am not the only one who have difficulty understanding his English. He just keeps murmuring to himself and his notes during the entire lecture. That's why I switched to Cheung MF after attending his first lecture.

Tutorials: Just doing exercises(some from textbook) and checking answers. I don't find them particularly helpful and didn't pay much attention in class.

I strongly recommend you choose Cheung MF's session(some say Altman is quite good as well). Even if you fail to register the lecture you want to attend, just feel free to switch to other sessions. Nobody cares.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not too bad. Grading is based on æ‹‰curve.
Score above 1 sd and you have A range.
Both the midterm and final exams are all multiple-choice questions. Some of them are quite difficult and tricky. In overall, the 2 exams are similarly difficult.

Grading scheme:
Homework: 10%
Tutorial participation: 5%
Midterm: 35%
Final: 50%

My results:
Homework: ~10/10 (almost full mark)
Tutorials: 5/5
Midterm: 22/26 (Mean: 13.4, High: 26/26)
Final: 32/40 (Mean:19.1, High: 38/40)
Course mark: ~84.6%
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy workload if you aim for A range
12 assignments (1st and last assignment not graded) and 13 tutorials, one per week (tutorial attendance is counted but you can skip a maximum of 3 tutorials)

Have to admit 1112 is a tough course with tight grading. You have to pay a shyt ton of effort to get decent grades. The teaching pace is increasingly 'chur' during the whole course, so you better attend all lectures so as to not lag behind.

If you aim high make sure your concepts are clear and don't forget to practice problems in the textbook, esp. those difficult ones with 2-3 dots. Most importantly, ask professors questions whenever you get confused. Clear concepts are more than anything else!

reviews.author: alsdkfjlask
reviews.comment_content:
If you studied physics in DSE, then phys1112 should be of no problem to you. The difficultly lies in the calculus that is used for equations.



PHYS 1112 target students who have learned the most basic knowledge in physics in high school. Students with more advanced physics background should consider taking PHYS 1312. PHYS 1112 employs a calculus-based approach. Students without knowledge of calculus should take PHYS 1111 instead. Key topics include motions and Newtonâ€™s Laws, work and energy, conservation of energy and momentum, rotation, rigid body, simple harmonic and damped oscillations, forced oscillations, standing waves and sound waves, kinetic theory and the laws of thermodynamics. Students without the physics prerequisite but who have taken PHYS 1101 or equivalent, and/or without the mathematics prerequisite but who have taken MATH 1012/ MATH 1013/ MATH 1020/ MATH 1023 or equivalent may seek instructorâ€™s approval for enrolling in the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Nidhi should be a new professor, who did a satisfactory job.
One thing great about the course is that you could watch videos of other lecturers. I suggest watching Professor Cheung's course, who taught very well and explained the concepts in detail. He did all the provings in class and walk us through all the equations.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is very unfortunate. My friend is 1 mark higher than me, yet he got A.
Mid term: 19/30
Final: 30/40
Final grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Mediocre workload.
Tutorial is compulsory and attendance is taken. Need not to say you shouldn't miss them.
To get a satisfactory score, doing textbook exercises is absolutely necessary.
Do not stack all the exercises until the exam week. You will die.

reviews.comment_content:
Mainly Focus on Mechanics, some wave and the first two laws of thermodynamics.

Topic:

reviews.author: chingm
reviews.title: A quite hard course
reviews.comment_content:
Other people have written very detailed overview. So Here I am going to tallk about some other things.

Before midterm, both old things that you have learned before and a few new things was taught.

Old things:
Mechanics(just similar to dse with a few other contents, like hooke's law), together with vectors and integration.

New things:
Dynamics of rigid bodies(I think it is not difficult to understand, but it is not easy to apply accurately, so you need practice.)

After midterm, there are much more new things.

Gravitation, not difficult as I have learnt some of the parts before, but again you need some exercises.

SHM, is very new for me, but after understanding it, it is all right to handle.

Waves, more complex but less contents than waves in DSE

Thermodynamics, mostly new things for those who studied phys in DSE. But I think the contents are easier than SHM and waves. Notice that many questions about this topic will be seen in your final.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. CHEN spends too much time to talk about proof, which was detailed but not included in the final exam. I think he can't make me understand the new topics well.

(Recommended)Dr. ALTMAN is much more better in explaining the contents. (Two week before the semester ended, I start to go to his lectures and found that he is good). Love his pronounciation.
reviews.comment_grading:
Think again before you choose it.

homework: 10%
tutorial: 5%
midterm: 35%
final 50%

me:
midterm nearly failed because I failed to understand Dynamics of Rigid Bodies well.

final: over upper quartile.

finally B range, all right as I think I may get C at the start of this sem.

MIDTERM IS REALLY IMPORTANT. STUDY WELL IN YOUR MIDTERM.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy. It is a good course for a fresh university student to get a taste of UST workload.

Each week 1 hw, 1 tutorial with attendance.

Strongly recommand you to complete supplementary ex. as well.

Your workload will be quite big if you want to get a good grade in MIDTERM and FINAL.

But I have to say, you may not receive a satisfactory result if you are not talented at Physics(even you do a lot of exercises).

reviews.author: ykls
reviews.title: Difficult for non-DSE physics students
reviews.comment_content: Basically learning things which are double in the DSE physics syllabus within a semester. The first half syllabus is covered by DSE physics and the other is entirely new. Probably the most "chur" course in SENG yr1.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cheung Man Fung is a relatively good professor in the PHYS1112 course. He can explain the theorem well and catch students' attention. However, the lecture mostly explains how the theorem comes from only. You can only self-learn about how to use those formula.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is good when you are above mean.
Information:
Mean: 3X/100 in both mid-term and final.
Standard deviation: 2X

The exam includes 40 MC questions, which means your grading greatly depends on your luck. Good luck all.
reviews.comment_workload: One homework per week which usually spend you 4-5 hours to finish(it takes longer if you are weak in physics). Furthermore, all students can get relatively high marks (9X/100) in assignments so you must find some way to look for answers and get full marks in this part. That's also why it is the most "Chur" course in SENG yr1.

reviews.author: sugna
reviews.comment_content:
Motions and Newton's laws
Work and energy
Conservation of energy and momentum
Rotation
Rigid body and angular momentum
Gravitation
Simple harmonic and damped oscillations
Forced oscillations
Standing waves and sound waves
Kinetic theory
The laws of thermodynamics

All topics are based on dse background. You will find it easier to catch up if you have good dse phy background. The content is more about explaining the process of proving equations we learnt in high school by differentiation and integration, which is actually not quite related to exam questions but only help you to understand. The more challenging parts are angular momentum, periodic motion, and laws of thermodynamics. Make sure to spend more time on those topics and do more practice as the concepts are harder to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cheung Man Fung teaches very well and explains concepts quite clearly. The handwriting notes are more thorough and detailed than other professors' ppts. It is just that the handwriting notes may be a bit messy when you revise them and you may not know where to start.

However, try to swap tutorials from Wanshun Du as he just read out the poorly made ppts which is difficult to understand. He didn't help me at all but just made me more confused. You may skip the tutorial or just attend it for the attendance question.
reviews.comment_grading:
15% assignment, tutorial
2 grading schemes:
35% mid-term + 50% final / 85% final
mid-term: mean: 12.8/27 SD:5.18 my result: 18/27
final: mean: 18.94/39 SD:6.52 my result: 32/39 (above 2 sd)
Grade: A
Got full marks in assignments, tutorial, and above 2 sd in the final, still cannot get A+ a bit disappointing but still fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are assignments for different chapters every 1-2 weeks. They may be hard if you don't have friends helping out each other or sources.
You may do dynamic study modules to ensure full / higher marks in homework.

reviews.comment_workload: Medium workload, assignments every week and exam revisions and that's about it.

Tutorials need attendance, lecture don't.

reviews.author: Natcha
reviews.title: Challenging course work hard for it
reviews.comment_content:
1. Physical quantities + vectors + motion in 2D + projectile
2. Newton's laws of motion
3. Work and kinetic energy
4. Potential energy and energy conservation (gravitational + elastic)
5. Momentum + impulse + collision
6. Dynamics of rigid bodies + center of mass
7. Angular momentum
8. Gravitation
9. Periodic motion
10. Wave motion + sound
11. Temperature and heat
12. First law of Thermodynamics + engines
13. Second law of Thermodynamics

The first half of the content is similar to what you have learned in high school. The last chapters are completely new to many of us and can be challenging to understand. The content is much more centered around physics and you barely need any knowledge in calculus for the calculations.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Pan Ding doesn't speak good english which makes his lessons extremely difficult to understand. He goes over the slides and scribbles on them. The professor understands the concepts well, but struggles to pass on the knowledge to his students. A large part of the lecture time is used to proof formulas which is not useful in exams and homework questions when you actually have to solve the problem. It is challenging to keep up with the pace of the course since the heavy content is squeezed to only a small time frame. I would recommend going through the textbook and reviewing each practice problem and concept to be able to fully grasp the content. Attend the tutorials because you need to earn participation marks (mini quiz every tutorial).
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two grading schemes and they will choose the better one for you:

Scheme 1:
Homework 10%
Tutorial 5%
Midterm 35%
Final 50%

Scheme 2:
Homework 10%
Tutorial 5%
Final 85%

Here are my scores:
Homework: 10/10 (mean: 9.14)
Tutorial Participation: 5/5 (mean: 4.72)
Midterm: 13/27 (mean: 11.95)
Final: 24/39 (mean: 18.78)

The midterm and final is extremely difficult which is reflected by the low mean scores. Just try to score above the mean and your grade should be fine. I ended up with a B+.
reviews.comment_workload: There's one homework every week with about 10 questions. (with many sub questions).  The homework can take from 1-3 hours depending on the difficulty of the content of each chapter. Points will be deducted each time that you get the answer wrong and there are limited amount of chances for each question. Check carefully before you hit submit.

reviews.comment_teaching: Great teaching, shows clearly how each equation is derived. I only briefly skimmed through the notes and attended several of the lectures though, so you might have to look at other reviews on this lecturer.
reviews.comment_grading:
Tutorial (5%)
â€¢ Review materials in taught in the previous week
â€¢ In-class activities
â€¢ Discuss selective on-going homework problems
â€¢ Must attend registered session
â€¢ 3 lowest score to be dropped (including missing session during add/drop)
How to earn the score
â€“Answer Poll Questions during the tutorial session
â€“For each problem, 0 pt for no answers, 0.75 pt for wrong answers, 1 pt for right answer.

Homework (10%)
â€¢ To be done on MasteringPhysics (need to register with access code from textbook)
Textbook and Registering MasteringPhysics:
https://canvas.ust.hk/courses/42558/pages/purchasing-and-registering-masteringphysics
â€¢ 11 graded HW sets (HW1 â€“HW11)
â€¢ 2 of the lowest HW scores will be dropped.

For exams, the following policy was implemented:

Midterm is optional and take the higher score of the following two:
> Midterm scaled to 35% + Final scaled to 50%
OR
> Final scaled to 85%

Midterm covers L1-L11
Final covers all course content

As long as you get nearly full marks for homework, full marks for the tutorial participation score, and a mean or slightly above mean score for the exams, you should secure a B grade.

I heard it is quite difficult for one to fail the course so no worries about failing it :P
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload. One homework per week, takes about 1.5 hr to finish each. One tutorial per week (if I remember correctly), and you just have to answer a multiple choice question for attendance. If you want to, feel free to leave after the MC question. They will still count your attendance. (This is only applicable for online mode though, don't just leave in the middle of a f2f tutorial class lollll)

reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite big for most people I guess. You need to spend time digesting the materials taught and make your own notes(of course, not complusory, just for better revision). If you didn't have much Physics background knowledge, this course may be quite terrible for you. Every week there is a set of homework and you may need to spend one or two hours on that. Sometimes reading the textbook may help you understand the contents better. BTW there is only one set of pastpaper available, which is quite bad for revision and practice.

reviews.author: yyyyyy~
reviews.title: Quite challenging course ......
reviews.comment_content:
Classical Mechanics:
1. Physical Quantities, vectors & motion in 2D - projectile motion
2. Newton's laws of motion
3. Work and kinetic energy
4. Momentum, impulse and collision
5. Rotational dynamics of rigid bodies
6. Angular momentum

Application of classical mechanics
7. Gravitation
8. Periodic motion - simple harmonic motion
9. Wave motion and sound
10. Temperature and heat
11. Thermal properties of matter
12. First law of Thermodynamics
13. Second law of Thermodynamics

As a student with DSE physics but without M2 (PS: only took math 1012 in advance), the content is quite scary for me. Apart from learning differentiation and integration, I have no idea about other calculus concepts like the Taylor series in SHM or partial derivatives in energy. Luckily, not a lot of calculus concepts are asked in the mid-term and final. The exam mainly includes physics concepts, so don't worry too much about the math. The math just enables you to understand the physics concepts well
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Cheung has good teaching, which was mentioned in previous reviews. One of the good things is he has hand-written notes. His handwriting and notes are also clear and very easy to understand. Besides, he used a lot of math proof to make us understand more about the physics concepts, which is quite interesting indeed. Despite the online semester, Cheung also issued anonymous feedback surveys so as to let students ask questions anonymously about the lecture

However, one major drawback is that a lot of calculus (more than any other professors) is used in Cheung's class (knowing differentiation and integration is a MUST). People who didn't take M2 (like me...) must be aware of that

PS: The professor teaches well. Yet, concepts like periodic motions and rotational dynamics are quite abstract e.g., the moment of inertia, the manipulation of sine cosine functions. Really suggest you guys to pay more effort and be aware of these two chapters. Besides, 1112 is really a math-based course. If you don't understand the physics behind via math, you may not synchronise with the professor's teachings
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term and final arrangement:

Mid-term exam (Topic 1-6)
Final exam (Topic 1-13) (aware of this)

Choice 1:
Mid-term 35%
Final 50%
homework 10% (10/10)
tutorial (*participation) 5%
OR
Choice 2:
Final 85%
homework 10%
tutorial (*participation) 5%

PS:  TAs and professors helped maximize the final score (idk if still have that for next sem...). However, if you don't join the mid-term, you can only choose choice 2

My grade:
Mid-term (14/27) (mean: 11.9/27)
Final (20/39) (mean: 18.8/39)
Homework (10/10) (mean: 9.1/10)
Tutorial (5/5) (mean: 4.7/5)
Grade: B

PS:
1. Rmb to finish the dynamic study module (you can always get full marks there, no worry). Scores in the DSM can be added as bonus mark in homework score
2. Better get full marks in homework and tutorial, coz ur mid-term and final may not be that easy ....
reviews.comment_workload:
workload quite light

one homework per week
(ard 1 hour to finish)
apart from days before the mid term and final, I still managed to finish some of the DSM

Cool-headed crazy prof.

Crazy: he did lots of experiments during classes. Some experiments may expose one to dangers if you sit too close to him

Poor handwriting and drawing
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:

Assignments 10%
Tutorials 5%
Midterm 35%
Final Exam 50%


Attendance is counted in tutorials only. Donâ€™t skip.

Although l pass the course, the course is harsh. The mean for every assignment is high

reviews.comment_workload: The assignments are very very  Very diffficult. You get 1 assignment per week. Do find TA (Chan Yu WAN] by email if needed, he is great.

reviews.author: Andy1229
reviews.title: Maybe a good grade course but need effort
reviews.comment_content: extended knowledge of the DSE syllabus, some interesting physics knowledge is briefly introduced. Yet, those interesting knowledge can be extremely dangerous when they appear in the midterm and final exams, so please be careful my friend.
reviews.comment_teaching: Personally speaking, my instructor did not clearly explain the key points of each lecture with his traditional Chinglish accent, so I prefer watching related videos on Youtube and other instructors'.The PowerPoint note is not that useful as the points mentioned are far not enough to get a relatively good grade. Self-learning ability is the only useful stuff I learned from this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Can be a good grade course as the marks required to get a reasonable grade is definitely low. Midterm and final exams are required, all MCQ, the chosen one with luck can get a high grade effortlessly.

midterm and final mean: around 43% SD is 4.5 and around 6 respectively.

Can get B range easily, but hard to get an A or A+
My result:
mid 16/24
final 26/40
A-
At first, I thought I may have an A grade but I was too young too simple, A or A+ is for the more talented one.T T

I am a local student and only get level 5 in DSE. Most of you have higher grades than mine.
I am not talented in physics and I did not know most of the questions in midterm. Before the exam, we received a sample paper, and my friends and I finished it with ease. It gave me a sort of confidence, but my friend, the fact is cruel. The exam was far harder than I thought. The easiest question in the exam was the hardest question in the homework. That was why we all had a terrible performance in exams.

In my opinion, the extended exercises in the online platform are the most useful help for you. Make sure you understand how to do those homework questions and the extended exercise. Don't try to get any past papers from Peter Gao, they are all the same, don't waste your quota and the past paper are all too easy compared to the real exams. Good Luck.
reviews.comment_workload: quite high for me as I want to understand how to do all the questions from homework. Use your attempt wisely as every wrong answer attempt will deduce your homework mark. I only try to attempt when I made sure all the answers were correct. So how should I know whether the answers are correct or not. Internet and friends are your best partners. Most of the questions have answers with explanations, just copy and paste. Or scarify your friends and let them answer the question before you answer to avoid wrong answer attempts lol.

reviews.author: Rondo_L
reviews.comment_content:
Mechanics and thermodynamics. Think twice if you have a weak foundation in calculus or physics caz there are tons of integrations and derivations. Math concept I've learnt in this course is even more than 1013.
So if you are bad at both, just RUN.
reviews.comment_teaching: The accent of prof. Han is just, you know, epic. Worst still, his tone is flat and boring, which makes you fall asleep in lecture. Took me 3 lessons to switch to Altman's section.
reviews.comment_grading:
I would say is fair. The mean of exams is low but is cumulative, so you work hard enough you will get what you deserved.
I got like A- in this courses with like above 1SD.
reviews.comment_workload: Tutorials required attendances, mid-term and finals.  There are also weekly-based online homework, though you can goggle the answer easily. The workload is heavy only if you try to get good grades.

reviews.author: D____S___
reviews.comment_content:
Most content before midterms are included in DSE syllabus but calculus is added.
Topics included:

reviews.comment_teaching: Altman's teaching is great. He is a really fun professor. He explains the ideas clearly. The powerpoint notes are clear too. There are demonstration too which help understanding

Grading is good. Easy to get A range. ~60% gives A-. Attending lectures can really help you understand the concepts. Quite easy to get good score if you have did a bit practise on book exercise and have good luck as all questions are MCs.

Tutorial participation:5%
Assignment:10%
Midterm 35%
Final 50%

I got an A+ with 84% overall

reviews.comment_content:
The syllabus includes:
- Physical quantities, vectors & Motion in 2D
- Newton's laws of motion
- Work and kinetic energy

- Dynamics of rigid bodies

reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is really good. He tries to make the lectures interesting for us, and that is why the lecture theatre is almost full on every lecture. He uses PowerPoint to teach, and everything is clear. I think that it is very easy for us to follow during lessons and when we are studying. He is a foreign speaker and that is why his English is really easy to understand. He sometimes teaches extra items at the end of the lecture which will not appear on the exam, but those are really interesting. You may leave before that but you will definitely learn more if you choose to stay.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
10% Homework
5% Tutorial
35% Mid-term
50% Final

Statistics
Mid-term:
Mean: 10.9/24
SD: 4.2

Final:
Mean: 17.26/40
SD: 6.68

My results are
Assignment: ~97%
Tutorial: 100%
Mid-term: 18/24 (+1.69 SD)
Final: 21/40 (+0.56 SD)
Overall I got an A-
reviews.comment_workload:
One assignment and one tutorial every week.

For each assignment, there are 7~10 questions, and each question may be split into different parts. 2 of the questions will be taught in the tutorial. It usually takes about 1.5~2 hours to finish each assignment.

For tutorials, you can at most skip 3 of them to get a full mark in the tutorial part of the grading scheme. Each tutorial is 50 minutes long, but it is usually not enough. There is a worksheet that consists of about 2~3 questions to finish. The TA will show the answers and you just need to copy them, then you get a full mark for that tutorial.

reviews.author: Wai Ching
reviews.title: Tough but not difficult to secure B- ; DSE Physics basically no use; revise calculus before mid-term!
reviews.comment_content:
The course taught from force&motion, inertial frame (I could not understand well), review of calculus, wave motion, simple harmonic motion(could not understand what was going on), heat & gas, thermodynamics. Heat & gas where the basic concepts were numerous and complicated but questions were straight forward, whereas others were reversed. Sample papers were provided but the difficulties were under those in real mid-term & final except heat & gas part.

Overall the course was overwhelming but interesting in details & calculations.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecturer Tian Wen teaching was mediocre. Although he tried to use simile and analogy to illustrate the concepts, he could not make it. Yet I still appreciate his effort: At least he unexpectedly linked the concepts with our everyday life e.g. angular momentum: Earth's rotation speed will be lowered when glacier melts.

TA Li Cheung Shun was excellent in explaining the details/ reviewing concepts. This was significant when evaluating the tutorial exercises, where I could understand the shortcuts of the questions: Only state the variables among different cases while the constant quantities could be ignored. However it was a pity that mid-term and final could not use those tricks as the questions were far from those in tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grades were calculated according to: a) Homework(10%) (use Mastering Physics): There were 11 graded homework. Most of the questions were hard even if you were familiar with the concepts. Search the questions into the Internet and go through the steps, but do not input the answers provided directly because the numbers provided may differ from what Mastering Physics gave. Otherwise you may lose 6% marks of that part per incorrect answer. You may find the answers in some websites and pdf files. Do not underrate its importance as HW may save you from low grades!

Here were my homework scores: HW01: 7.88/8 (Mean 7.2/8)
HW02: 3.06/8 (Mean 7.2/8)( I got very low marks as I did not realise that I could find the answer on Internet till HW03)
HW03: 8.61/9 (Mean 8.2/9)
HW04: 10.18/11(Mean 9.9/11)
HW05: 8.84/9 (Mean 8.2/9)
HW06: 9.82/10(Mean 9.1/10)
HW07: 9.65/10 (Mean 9/10)
HW08: 7.72/8( Mean 7.2/8)
HW09: 10/10 (Mean 8.9/10)
HW10: 9.82/10(Mean 9/10)
HW11: 7.94/8(Mean 7.1/8)

Note that HW12 was not graded.

b) Tutorial(5%): Except first tutorial, other 12 you need to attend unless otherwise specified. Yet you may get full marks if you complete all tutorial exercises with relevant calculations or diagrams or keywords written. I suggest you take photo before submitting your tutorial work as you may not get them back after each session for revision. Don't miss any of them!

c) Assessments(Mid-term 35%, Final 50%): Do not trust both Sample papers except heat&gas part as the difficulty was much lower than the actual ones. Although they were all MCs( 24 for mid-term and 40 for final), even if you are clear with the concepts,  most of the questions( around 60-70%) suck as they involved in numerous variables, realising the relevant plus multiple concepts to the questions or being complicated. Remember not to be too optimistic as you may not be able to know which formula to apply for each questions, especially for mid-term since force & motion has infinite variations and calculus involved.

Homework grade: full mark, need to calculate by your self according to the attachment
Mid-term grade:9/24
Final grade:15/40
They were all below mean but I still got B-.

Perhaps my high grades in homework saved me haha!

For overall performance among students please see the attachments.

Oh don't forget to complete Dynamic Study Modules(DSM)(included in Homework(10%). Not only do they clear your concepts but also bonus marks may be given.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework were not difficult if you could find detailed solutions on Internet. It would be disastrous if you try complete them on your own.
DSM would ensure you answered those MCs correctly several times for those you got them wrong at first. Therefore you could get full marks for all DSMs if you are patient.

If you aim B range, workload should not be heavy as you could secure near mean, given that you have a good mathematical foundation. For A range, you may need to complete Mastering Physics textbook questions( I did not go through it ).

Last but not least, review all calculus up to vectors before mid-term as many MCs need calculus to solve (especially MATH1013, which I studied, did not cover it until Nov 2021). My mid-term sucked as a result.

Final : 50%
(40 MCQs)

Me:

(For grading rules of homework, you may see the attachment attached.)

Final : 15/40

Final grade: B-

The grade is good enough, at least not so bad, as my both mid-term and final are slightly below mean. However, the mean mark is super low.

reviews.author: wkwkwkkwkw
reviews.title: Quite a difficult course
reviews.comment_content:
First half of the semester:
- Physical Quantities, Vectors and Motion in 2D
- Newton's Laws of Motion
- Work and Kinetic Energy
- Potential Energy and Energy Conservation
- Momentum
- Dynamics of Rigid Bodies
- Angular Momentum

Second half of the semester:
- Gravitation
- Periodic Motion
- Wave Motion and Sound
- Temperature and Heat
- Thermal Properties of Matter
- First Law of Thermodynamics
- Second Law of Thermodynamics

The chapters being taught in the first half of the semester are easy enough to understand (except for dynamics of rigid bodies). However, the HW questions and midterm questions are on another level of hard.

The chapters taught in the second half of the semester are definitely more difficult to understand. BUT, I found the questions easier to do.

But I would say the content of this course is very good especially if you are in SSCI or SENG. Very worth it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I can't really comment on Professor Wong's teaching because I only attended one lecture (due to it being scheduled at the end of the day, by that time I'm already too burned out by earlier lectures :P). In that one lecture I attended, it was evident that his English was very bad. I could not understand what he was trying to say at all. But I'm pretty sure if he was more fluent in English his teaching would be considered good (?).

I did, however, attended the tutorials. The TA Archie is very good at teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Homework
5% Tutorials
35% Midterm
50% Finals

Homework:
There are 12 HWs in total. Your lowest two scores will be disregarded. Try your best to get at least above 95% in each of these HWs (definitely possible). The answers for these HW questions are available on the internet but you should use those resources only as a means to check your answers and see where you went wrong.

Tutorials:
- For onsite students: attend tutorials and do worksheet given by TA
- For NIHK students: do 8 DSMs

Midterm Exam:
- For onsite students: 24 MCQ
- For NIHK students: Open-ended midterm with 120 marks in total.
- Very very difficult imo.
- Mean: 10.8/24 and SD: 4.2
- My score: 12/24. +0.3 SD

Finals:
- For onsite students: Do 40 MCQ.
- For NIHK students: Do 33 MCQ.
- VERY difficult.
- Mean: 17.26/40 and SD: 6.68
- My score: 24/40. +1 SD.

Letter grade: B+

I did not put in a lot of effort in this course and was still able to get B+. So my advice would be to do frequent exercise everyday, you will definitely get an A range grade since this courseâ€™s grading is really good.

Honestly I am pretty pissed because if I completed all the DSMs then I am sure that I would have gotten an A-. So future students, please complete the DSMs, they might not seem to contribute much to your final grade but trust me it can actually save you.
reviews.comment_workload: I would say the workload for this course is average. You just have to attend tutorials and do the HWs every week.

reviews.title: Decent Course for Introductory Physics

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Altman heavily relies on ppt during teaching and repeats everything written on the slides. One can simply read ppt and notes and get the general idea of the course. But if you want to see derivation of equations, explanation of abstract concepts, and live experimental demonstrations, then you should consider attending class.
The content is a comfortable extension to high school physics and students with a physics background should have no trouble learning. The calculus requirements are minimal because the emphasis is placed on applying the concepts instead.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm (2 attempt allowed): Conducted in a computer room where students enter numerical answers and select multiple choice on screen.

Final (written exam): Multiple choice only. (Mostly conceptual questions with a fair amount of calculation)

Exams are not too demanding and quite manageable for physics students. Midterms have only 5 questions so must be extremely careful when answering, but luckily you have two attempts.

Both midterm and final: Above 1 s.d. -> A
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments required
Questions from textbook which must be purchased to get online login code. Attend tutorials to get help if you need it.

reviews.comment_teaching: Cheung Man Fung is the best professor. He explained the theory very well. Even you are not good at physics, you can still understand it easily.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair.
My grade:
midterm : 84/100 (+1 SD)
final : 76/100 (+1.5 SD)
Finally, I got  A
For your reference, I just got level 4 in DSE physics but I have put many efforts into this course so I got A
midterm is fair, if you really put effort and practice more before it, not difficult to get +1 SD.
However, the final exam is super DIFFICULT this semester. I am sure that it is more difficult than that any other semester before.
The final exam includes some conceptual MCs which are not covered well in the lectures, which means you should read the textbooks by yourself to understand it thoroughly. Don't just think that you can calculate the questions and no need to understand the concepts, you can not survive in the final exam!!!
Good news is that this semester is the last online semester, when it comes to normal face-to-face lectures, the exam should be easier.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework of Mastering Physics every week. Each time need to spend around two hours to complete.

You have to buy the book and get the code for the assignment
No attendance will be taken in the lesson.
Attendance will be taken in a tutorial class.

reviews.author: hyleeay
reviews.title: Without phy and math background
reviews.comment_content: The content is of course good, you will learn about mechanics and have a view of what theremodynamics looks like. One very minor topic is about astronomy, but it was short topic so don't worriy about it. These topics are important if you progress your study on engineering as most engineering students need to learn thermodyanics in the future, I boldly guessed.
reviews.comment_teaching: He worries about time. The teaching should be fine for most students. But as I have weak background on physics and calculus, it's very difficult for me to keep up with the schedule.
reviews.comment_grading: I think it was fair because I did terrible at all and receive a D. I was glad that I passed the course. Physics is like another calculus course, if you are good at calculus, you should grasp the knowledge fairly easily.
reviews.comment_workload: One homework a week, hard to catch up if you have weak ground on physics and calcuus.

reviews.author: tt2sec
reviews.comment_content: An upgraded version of DSE Physics (force and motion)
reviews.comment_teaching: Attended inly the first lecture. Sh*tty English. I think it is better for you to learn it yourself, don't expect anything from the instructor.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair.
I have my mid-term and final above mean (+0.x SD) and result in a B. I expect a B+ though :(
I think you will get B range for mean and A range for +1 SD
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload
Weekly assignment with limited number of attend, but you can google to find the solution.

Attendance is required for tutorial
Try to attend all of them as some of the homework problem will be taught in the tutorial

reviews.author: Harinki
reviews.comment_content:
Quite hard for physics beginners. Probably need to put in extra hours to get a decent grade.

Would not suggest taking this course if you don't have to.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof was quite fast but overall wasn't bad.

Tutorials are a bit useless, would suggest using other online solutions to answer the homework.
reviews.comment_grading: A bit below mean for midterms, and almost 1 sd above for finals, overall B grade. Not bad but not great, definetly not good enough to be a GPA booster.
reviews.comment_workload: Not bad at all, although homework is a little tedious.

reviews.author: eugene1
reviews.comment_content:
This course builds on top of your DSE physics knowledge and adds some additional theories, equations, etc. Calculus is used to explain/prove theories and/or concepts, but are rarely used in homework and assessments. However, a basic understanding of calculus is required.

You are required to buy an online/physical version of the textbook because you need to do homework using the ebook system.

Attendance is not mandatory but there are quizzes in the tutorials (based on the tutorial exercises).
reviews.comment_teaching:
(Online teaching -- camera encouraged but not necessary)
The professor teaches in a lab. He frequently performs experiments on camera which helps you understand the concepts.

He also explains the concepts very well, sometimes using real-life examples or personal experiences. Very willing to answer your questions.

The TAs are not familiar with the teaching materials that the professor used, so they sometimes use a different method to solve problems. They might also not be able to answer questions about the notes.
reviews.comment_grading: The mean of the midterm score is really low (see attachment)
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly homework that takes at max 3-4 hours to complete. There are 1-2 "tutorial problems" in each homework which the TAs will give solutions to in the tutorial sessions.

reviews.author: aUsedNickname
reviews.title: Not a easy course
reviews.comment_content: Covers many topics. About two or three lectures for a completely new topic.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is fair. Professor Zeng has some strange accent quite but not a great problem. The prove of the formula is explained in quite detail.(Not useful to me though)The slide already tells everything.
reviews.comment_grading:
The syllabus of midterm exam mostly about the topics that you hv learnt in high school. But about half of the questions are about rigid body.(something about angular momentum or angular speed etc.) The final exam is a much big problem. There are too many formula. The mean score of final will be lower than midterm.
P.S. The questions are straight forward though.

It is impossible to memorize all formula. Make a note with all formula written on it (unless u dont want to get a good grade).

Midterm: Mean+ 0.x sd
Final: Mean + 1.4 sd
Grade: A- (I though I would get B range but turn out final save me)

P.S. You dont need to understand every, just apply the formula
reviews.comment_workload:
Totally affordable.
Weekly assignment with about 10 questions. Not very hard as you can google the question to find the answer.
Have midterm and final exam.
Pls join all tutorial as attendance is counted. The tutor may also held some polling which may affect your attendance mark(I guess).

reviews.author: Dipankar
reviews.comment_content: The content is basic 12th level CBSE and the should be fine if you are familiar with the topics, else you might need the practice and easily understandable if you enjoy physics
reviews.comment_teaching: I did not most classes, as it was my first semester but it is interesting prof used practical explanations and TAs were helpful
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fine, don't mess up homeworks as they can help you gain or lose quite a substantial amount of numbers when deciding your final grade I ended up with an A- , I did slightly above mean in both the finals and midterms.
Attendance isn't compulsory but you should attend if you are unaware of the concepts as the explanations are useful
reviews.comment_workload: Besides the weekly homework there isn't anything officialy you have to do but I suggest keep practicing the problems

reviews.author: Nathan Ma
reviews.comment_content:
The topics themselves are not too hard. The course only lightly touches the concepts and equations, so there is a large portion of the textbook which you do not need to read. However, there are more than 20 chapters that you have to study for this course, so it all balances out.

Topics include:
- Linear Mechanics (Newton's Laws; Energy; Spring)
- Rotational Mechanics (Rotational Motion)
- Waves (Mechanical; Sound)
- Thermodynamics (Heat; Thermal Properties; First Law; Second Law)
reviews.comment_teaching:
This lecturer has an acceptable English accent and can speak both Cantonese and Putonghua.

I could tell the lecturer has passion in teaching. The lecturer regularly emails students about his ad hoc consultation session periods. Before the mid-term and final exam, the lecturer also sets up extra consultations session periods. He definitely has heart in teaching.

My personal opinion is that the lectures are a bit boring, and that the lecturer should focus a bit more on other aspects instead. The lecturer focuses a significant portion of time on explaining how the physics equations are derived, which is rather useless if you simply want to get a good grade.

For those who are looking to major in Physics, or simply interested in how the equations are obtained, this lecturer is perfect for you.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading mainly emphasizes the mid-term and finals, with a small weighting on the homework and tutorial attendance.

I got B- in this course. My mid-term was a bit below mean; my final was a bit above mean. I have an easy 5 in DSE Physics, slept during most lectures, didn't do most homework seriously, and didn't study at all. You can use my results and background to get a general idea of the difficulty of the course.

Take note that due to COVID, this semester was fully online, so results may vary.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is ridiculous.

Each week, the course asks you to finish homework. Each homework consists of 8 to 12 questions. Each question has multiple sub-questions. The system predicts that you use 80-100 minutes to finish the entire set, but I personally took 2-3 hours to finish the homework set if I do it seriously.

Thankfully, you can Google the answers to some (not all) questions through copy-and-pasting. Of course, I don't suggest you to do so, as doing/understanding the questions definitely helps you during study. You should only do this trick when you don't have free time.

reviews.author: Jaa
reviews.comment_content: The content is not very difficult, partly similar to our DSE physics but a little bit harder.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is really nice and vivid. He is very willing to answer questions during the class and after class (through email), and is happy to interact with us.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is better than i imagined. I have missed 1 or 2 assignment and I got slightly below average for both mid term and the final exam. Yet I got a B- for the final grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is a little bit heavy for me, we have exercises to do every week.

reviews.author: FlyingPig
reviews.title: Hello
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly including mechanics, waves and also thermodynamics these 3 topics.
In the very beginning it started with secondary school level stuffs like Newton's law, momentum.
But then sth later on like angular motion, waves and almost all thermodynamics are new topics. Hard as well.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Coz it is zoom class in the whole semester so it's easy to ask question or see what the prof. write.
Prof. Chen put quite a lot lesson time on deriving the physics formula to help us fully understand how can it be used.
In my opinion he is not a bad professor coz he is willing to answer questions and also speak in a way that everyone can understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
A confusing part. So I just provide my marks for reference.
Full attendance in tutorial class.
Homework: about 91%
Mid-term: 19/30       Mean:11
Final-term: 25/42     Mean:17.8
I got an A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
kinda light workload. Just 1 online hw per week.
If you aiming a 100% in homework then there will be little more pressure coz few marks are deducted after each wrong attempt.

Also attendance counted in tutorial class, just answer the polling in zoom class.(counted no matter your answer is wrong or correct)

It is a subject that you must get reward if you study hard, so don't give up if you really struggling this course :P
