reviews.author: michaelak21
reviews.title: Fun course, but high workload
reviews.comment_content: Content is awesome. It is mostly classical mechanics and thermodynamics, and if you get the right teacher you probably will learn lots of applications from this course and some interesting phenomena in daily life that can be explained by classical mechanics and thermodynamics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Pak Wo Leung is an awesome teacher. Although it is taught online and he asked for some participation and for the face cam to be on for a couple of people, he teaches the course enthusiastically and with some fun experiments that he showed to the class.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is kinda rough. My friend got above mean for the midterms and finals (not above SD though) and still only got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: every week there will be homework from mastering physics, and also tutorial attendance which its scoring is based on a polling quiz in zoom.

reviews.author: Unk
reviews.comment_content:
Motions and Newton's laws
Work and energy
Conservation of energy and momentum
Rotation
Rigid body
Simple harmonic and damped oscillations
Forced oscillations
Standing waves and sound waves
Kinetic theory
The laws of thermodynamics

Pretty good content.
Quite easy before midterm, and after midterm the difficulty increases. The materials are easy but the exam are hellish, both midterm and final.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very very gooooooodd.. Professor Leung Pak Wo really enjoys teaching. Sadly it's online so not many interactions between professor and students. He used something like onenote to explain and he also did some experiments to show his point.. really cool !! Also, digital notes are provided in canvas, so you don't have to worry about not writing notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments 10%
Tutorials 5%
Midterm 35%
Final Exam 50%

I got:
Assignments and Tutorials all almost perfect
Midterm Exam  13..../30
Mean: 11.0; SD: 5.2
Final Exam  23.../42
Mean score: 17.8; SD: 7.6

Only got B.. Expected B+ but oh well
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is okayyy.. Homework every week with around 10 questions each homework. The questions are pretty hard, but you can always find the solution online. Slader,chegg, google is the key for good grade in HW. The HW is graded so be careful doing it. Attending tutorial is also necessary because there is a poll question each tutorial that is graded.

reviews.author: benbenLUCKYust
reviews.title: definitely A range if put effort!
reviews.comment_content:
Basically, it's some part of DSE physics (mechanics, mechanical wave and heat and gases) + M2 + more

Lectures:
1. Physical quantities, vectors & Motion in 2D
- projectile
2. Newton's laws of motion I
- Relative Motion
- Reference Frame
- Newton's Three Laws
3. Newton's laws of motion II
- Friction
- Circular motion
4. Work and kinetic energy
- work-energy theorem
- work done by a varying forceLinks to an external site.
5. Potential energy and energy conservation
- gravitational (mgh) and elastic PE
- conservative and non-conservative forces
6. Momentum, impulse and collision I
- impulse-momentum theorem
- conservation of momentum
- elastic, inelastic, and completely elastic collision
7. Momentum, impulse, and collision II
- elastic collision
- center of mass
8. Dynamics of rigid bodies I
- angular displacement, velocity and acceleration
- rotational kinetic energy and moment of inertia
9. Dynamics of rigid bodies I
- angular displacement, velocity and acceleration
- rotational kinetic energy and moment of inertia
10. Dynamics of rigid bodies III
- rigid body rotation about a moving axis
- work and power in rotation motionLinks to an external site.
11. Angular momentum
- conservation of angular momentum
- gyroscope
12. Gravitation I
- Newton's law of gravitation
- gravitational force and potential energy
- satellite motion
13. Gravitation II
- Kepler's laws of planetary motion
- spherical mass distribution
- apparent weight due to earth's rotation
- black hole
14. Periodic motion I - simple harmonic motion
15. Periodic motion II
- various types of SHM, pendulum
- damped and forced oscillations
- resonance
16. Wave motion and sound I
- mathematical description of wave
- power propagation
- reflection of traveling waves
17. Wave motion and sound II
- standing wave
- beat
- Doppler effect
18. Temperature and heat
- thermal expansion
- heat capacity and latent heat
- heat transfer
19. Thermal properties of matter I
- equation of state
- kinetic theory of ideal gas
20. Thermal properties of matter II
- heat capacity of gases
- molecular speed distribution
21. First law of Thermodynamics I
- first law of thermodynamics
- heat and work in thermodynamic processes
22. First law of Thermodynamics II
- typical thermodynamic processes
- heat capacities of ideal gas under different conditions
- adiabatic process of ideal gas
23. Second law of Thermodynamics I
- heat engines and refrigerators
- different forms of the second law
24. Second law of Thermodynamics II
- reversible processes
-Carnot cycle and engine
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof CHEN is from Hong Kong, but the accent is not dat heavy, and still recognizable. Kind of funny/strange as he sighs a lot. He's also nice and patient to answer people's questions. I think what's worst about him is dat his lectures are boring. If you can focus on him talking, you can still learn something.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fall 2020-2021: Quarantine!!!
I think the grading is not dat bad.
If you put effort into doing exercise and understanding proofs and the theory, you can get pretty good grade.

Assignments (10%) 94.58%
Tutorials (5%) 9.5/10
Midterm Exam (35%) 16.83/30
Mean: 11.0; SD: 5.2
Final Exam (50%) 29.16/42
Mean score: 17.8; SD: 7.6

Remarks: Luckily it's open book and online exam. I can use my cheat sheet. Those formulae are harder to memorize than those in HKDSE.

Eventually A-
reviews.comment_workload:
!!!If you are not interested in physics, you better watch out!!!
Personally speaking, the workload is not dat heavy, or maybe it's just me being too optimistic.

The assignments are just from online question bank. Have to do weekly.
Tutorial counts. Hv to attend because TA will have some polling questions that count.
As for the exams, just practice more when you are free. I did revision just two days before the final.

reviews.author: Angel light
reviews.comment_content:
See others. Cover basic things learned in High School plus more in-depth level content of heat. The content is deep but I feel that they didn't convey all that depth.
I did not love Physics more after learning this course.
The content is quite hard to understand deeply but you can still attain a fair grade if you did not understand it deeply. Sorry for my bad expression.
reviews.comment_teaching: I didn't attend many lectures, skip most after the midterm so no comments. Tutorials were quite good in explaining again the core concepts and compulsory.
reviews.comment_grading:
Finals 34.5/40
Midterm: 24.5/30
Still don't know the letter grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Web work, not heavy but it creates the feeling of stress.

reviews.author: Domoto295
reviews.title: Closely related to DSE Physics, only simple calculus is involved
reviews.comment_content:
The content is mainly DSE Physics (about 70%, first 3 modules of DSE syllabus) with Calculus added.

Syllabus:
Physical quantities, vectors & Motion in 2D
Newton's laws of motion
Work and kinetic energy
Potential energy and energy conservation
Momentum, impulse and collision
Dynamics of rigid bodies
Angular momentum
Gravitation
Periodic motion
Wave motion and sound
Temperature and heat
Thermal properties of matter
First law of Thermodynamics
Second law of Thermodynamics

Gravitation is similar to the DSE Physics elective 'Astronomy and Space Science'.
Some topics are new but quite easy to learn.
The amount of calculus is little and not challenging. Students with only basic calculus knowledge could also handle the math problems easily.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor has a typical mainland accent. He is willing to explain and answer students' questions.
Personally I think the teaching pace could be a bit faster.

Tutorials would take attendance by polling questions. Each tutorial would have 2 polling questions. Getting one of them correct would already give you full mark for that tutorial.
The tutorials are pretty useful as the review slides and exercises are well-organized. The TA is also very helpful. They would answer students' questions via email.
reviews.comment_grading:
Tutorials (attendance + polling) -5%
HW-10%
Mid-term-35%
Final-50%

I got 5* in DSE Physics and 5* in DSE M2.
Made so many careless mistakes in both midterm and final exams.
Finally got an A in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
About one assignment per week.
The assignments often require a pretty long time to finish, sometimes challenging, but they are very helpful for your understanding.
Better finish the supplementary problems on each topic before the exams, as they are often more challenging than the assignments.
As long as you read the textbook, do the exercises in the lecture notes, complete the assignments and supplementary exercises, you would be able to excel.

reviews.author: Error404
reviews.title: Difficult Course
reviews.comment_content:

calculus will be used to explain the concept

Prof Chen: He is good at explaining, however quite boring. Sorry professor but I nearly fall asleep during lessons

TA Martin: good at explaining, good English and good handwriting, he is a HKer who would answer your questions with Cantonese after lessons. Super good TA
reviews.comment_grading:

I am bad at physics, so i think this course has a good final grade (?)

DSE Physics Lv5

One HW per week
I am stupid so i spent about 4-5 hours per hw
i guess others can use 2-3 hours to finish it

one supplementary exercise is given per big topic

Doing more exercise would help.

potential energy and energy conservation
momentum
impulse and collision

reviews.comment_teaching: very clear and accurate. Uses whiteboard instead of ppt.
reviews.comment_grading: Maybe one of the worst grading courses in 1000-level.
reviews.comment_workload: weekly online assignments. You must buy a textbook in order to do those online assignments. There are around 10 questions in each assignment, which will only take you an hour or two to do, so the workload is pretty light.

reviews.author: Arnold hui
reviews.comment_content: Key topics include motions and Newtonâ€™s Laws, work and energy, conservation of energy and momentum, rotation, rigid body, simple harmonic and damped oscillations, forced oscillations, standing waves and sound waves, kinetic theory and the laws of thermodynamics.
reviews.comment_teaching: The overall teaching is good when it comes to teaching the materials that were taught during secondary school. However, when it come to new topics, I had no idea what am I learning. Even though the professor was good, the lecture content are difficult and hard to understand. Not to mention the big difference  between examination problems verses lecture examples
reviews.comment_grading:
Iâ€™m not sure if the headings are good or not ,but in my point of view, I would say itâ€™s quite good for me.

Assignments 10%

Midterm 35%
Final 50%

My score

19/45. Final (mean 20.7)
Full for hw and attendance
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light if you have a solid foundation of physics as you only need to submit an online hw once a week ( sometime prof will cancel the hw if he knows that we got loads of stuff to do in other courses!)

However, if you are not really good at physics, those online hw are gonna be your nightmare because the problems are not straightforward which requires a lot of thinking and calculation before getting to the answers.

reviews.author: Wilson Chiu
reviews.title: University Level Physics Course with Calculus
reviews.comment_content:
Physics - Mechanics
- Motions and Newton's laws
- Work and energy
- Conservation of energy and momentum
- Rotation
- Rigid body
- Simple harmonic and damped oscillations
- Forced oscillations
- Standing waves and sound waves
- Kinetic theory
- The laws of thermodynamics

Same as high school physics but with calculus included in it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is very elaborate and detailed. Conceptual understanding will be assured if you're paying attention to the instructors. However, they will not teach you the applications, and those will have to come with practice and careful thinking.

I had Professor Altman as my instructor, he's a humorous instructor who tries his very best to make the classroom environment lively and light hearted, but at the same time maintaining order to ensure that things do not get out of hand. My one criticism of him is that he tends to rely way too much on his presentation. It would be helpful if we got to see his step-by-step process on reaching the answer, and explaining it along the way, because at times I would get lost and would not understand why certain steps were conducted.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Midterm
50% Finals
20% Mastering Physics Online Assignments

25/30 Midterm
29.5/45 Final
95-100/100 Mastering Physics Assignments
Final Grade : A

The grade for the final examination was slightly altered as there were technical difficulties during the first section. Everyone got a lift in their grades, and only two out of the three sections were graded.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is okay as long as you don't stack it up. Online assignments will take about 1.5 hours each, however it is highly recommended to go do practice problems to properly prepare for the exams.

There will be a set of practice problems released along with the assignments, I would highly recommend doing them to consolidate your knowledge on the topic.

Grade: B (I am very lucky)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite high. You need to finish an online assignment every week. The assignments are quite difficult for me. Don't forget to finish your homework. They are very important. Also, the tutorials take attendance.

reviews.author: thebusranger
reviews.comment_content:
Extension of DSE physics (designed for students who are going for mech or civil)
First 13 chapters are force and motion(all topics in DSE will be taught again) with a little extension of M2 knowledge.
Then it comes to wave motion (4 chapters) (such as SHM, standing waves, which is the extension of DSE syllabus wave motion II)
Next it comes to heat and gas (3 chapters) (exactly the same as DSE syllabus with more chem knowledge plus a little bit about E3 in DSE physics)
Lastly is thermodynamics (4 chapters), basically new to all students and the most difficult among the whole course, laws of thermodynamics with their application will be taught
In general, the content is so huge for this course
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sheng Ping is a good instructor, although he has a strong accent. He always makes the class end early than scheduled. You should go for him if you want to learn quick.

Cheung Man Fung is also a good instructor, he explain the lecture with a lot of notes and explain it in details. However he always overrun and it may not be efficient for people having tight schedule like me.

Tutorial sucks, only for attendance. The TAs want to explain HW questions like pro, but failed ( youtube are way better)
reviews.comment_grading:
Good
I earn full mark for hw (10%) and attendance (5%)
Midterm 16/26 (mean 16.6, SD 5.8) (35%)
Final 12/27( mean 13.7, SD 5.3) (50%)
overall 58.76% (B)
I thought that I get a B-
but my friend said that he overall get 1 mark lower than me in final and get a B-......
However the exam questions are not straight forward (maybe because of online sem plus open book exam)
reviews.comment_workload:
Of course heavy la
You can find hw answer through sources, saving u a lot of time. But when it comes to exam, you still need to study and you will realize that you have entered hell. You need to be familiar with all the exercise in the hw (if u have time also take a glance at the book).
I think that lecture doesn't help us a lot, it only gives us the background of knowledge. The best way to make u success in this course is to watch youtube videos( I personally recommend the guy named organic Chemistry tutor)

reviews.author: hyacinth
reviews.comment_content: Topics on Mechanics, Wave Motion, Heat are included. The midterm focuses more on Mechanics. The calculus are just for explaining situation in a more in-depth manner and the topics are DSE topics, which might not be very hard to understand if you still have highschool physics in your head.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very interactive teaching in class with detailed explanations on the notes. He is quite humorous as a professor. There're experiment in class almost everytime and he also explains concepts with simple experiments himself. Just like throwing the golf ball explaining gravitational force.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading as the tutorials and homework also counts. I got 1s.d. below mean in the midterm 12/30. And during the final exam, I just get the mean and my final grade turns out to be B-, fair enough.
reviews.comment_workload: There are a lot of homework. It consists of around 8-12 questions each time. Some questions would be solved and covered in tutorials. However, for other questions, it requires a significant amount of time to understand. The statements for the question itself is quite long and some of them are quite advance to comprehend. Those concepts are more difficult than situations taught in class and hence have to devote more time in order to get a better grade.

reviews.author: Yat
reviews.title: Not to take at Year 1 first semester
reviews.comment_content:
Text Book
University Physics Volume 1 Ch 1-20 W/MasteringPhysics, Edition 14
Author: Hugh D Young        Publisher: Pearson  

Just image yourself to finish DSE and half AL in 1 semester, then it should quite clear of the content.
You better to be quite good at studying physics, or studying in general, before taking this course.

1. Physical quantities, vectors & Motion in
2D
- projectile

2. Newton's laws of motion I
- Relative Motion
- Reference Frame
- Newton's Three Laws

3. Newton's laws of motion II
- Friction
- Circular motion

4. Work and kinetic energy
- work-energy theorem
- work done by a varying force

5. Potential energy and energy
conservation
- gravitational (mgh) and elastic PE
- conservative and non-conservative
forces

6. Momentum, impulse and collision I
- impulse-momentum theorem
- conservation of momentum
- elastic, inelastic, and completely
elastic collision

7. Momentum, impulse, and collision II
- elastic collision
- center of mass

8. Dynamics of rigid bodies I
- angular displacement, velocity and
acceleration
- rotational kinetic energy and moment
of inertia

9. Dynamics of rigid bodies II
- calculation of moment of inertial
- torque

10. Dynamics of rigid bodies III
- rigid body rotation about a moving axis
- work and power in rotation motion

11. Angular momentum
- conservation of angular momentum
- gyroscope

12. Gravitation I
- Newton's law of gravitation
- gravitational force and potential energy
- satellite motion

13. Gravitation II
- Kepler's laws of planetary motion
- spherical mass distribution
- apparent weight due to earth's rotation
- black hole

14. Periodic motion I - simple harmonic
motion

15. Periodic motion II
- various types of SHM, pendulum
- damped and forced oscillations
- resonance

16. Wave motion and sound I
- mathematical description of wave
- power propagation
- reflection of traveling waves

17. Wave motion and sound II
- standing wave
- beat
- Doppler effect

18. Temperature and heat
- thermal expansion
- heat capacity and latent heat
- heat transfer

19. Thermal properties of matter I
- equation of state
- kinetic theory of ideal gas

20. Thermal properties of matter II
- heat capacity of gases
- molecular speed distribution

21. First law of Thermodynamics I
- first law of thermodynamics
- heat and work in thermodynamic
processes

22. First law of Thermodynamics II
- typical thermodynamic processes
- heat capacities of ideal gas under
different conditions
- adiabatic process of ideal gas

23. Second law of Thermodynamics I
- heat engines and refrigerators
- different forms of the second law

24. Second law of Thermodynamics II
- reversible processes
-Carnot cycle and engine
reviews.comment_teaching:
I didn't really attend lectures but they usually nice and helpful professors.
Tutorial sections were compulsory, where attendance would be counted, and each one would review certain topic in past lectures.

You could ask for help from the tutors, and they would always responds to you.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pearson online HW for abt every week with considerable amount of topic-related exercises.
Mid: 23/30
Mean: 20.7 High: 40 Low: 1

Final: 17.5/45 (Just below mean)
Mean: 18.8 High: 30 Low: 0

Grade: B+

Mid-term was all MCQ.
Not quite sure of how the grading works due to Final is taken online, with 3 parts, where only the highest part was counted and scaled.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is pretty huge, since there are 2 lectures every week and it more or less 1 chapter for 1 lecture. It takes quite fair amount of time to understand the concepts and finish the online  exercise in Pearson.

You either a physics machine, or you should expect yourself to spend really extra time and effort on mastering all the concepts and topics.

There were so many equations in different topics, that could be really confusing to actually remember but there were always ppl get full mark for mid and final; so I wouldn't say it couldn't be you.

reviews.author: ls0207
reviews.title: A mind blow course
reviews.comment_content: A deeper version of HKDSE physics with some calculus derives. Newton laws, mechanical energy, momentums, gravitation, and heat are just a deeper version than DSE, but the new contents: Dynamics of rigid bodies, simple harmonic motions, and wave motions are too difficult to handle.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Altman is a good professor that he does explain the concepts in an easy, funny way. He prepared different resources like videos and demonstrations to present the concepts. However, his tone is too sleepy so that you need to keep attention in order not to miss the messages.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: Around 10/10 (I can't check, but I completed all the homework and score not less than 90% on average) (10%)
Tutorial attendance: 100% (5%)
Mid-term exam: 19/30 (35%)
final exam: 20.5/45 (50%)
Total grade: 59.94% (B+)
reviews.comment_workload: Each week will have a piece of homework on mastering physics. However, the extra practices shouldn't be ignored in order to have a better understanding.

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: Good grade this semester
reviews.comment_content:
Before the midterm, the content covers classical mechanics. Most of them are taught in DSE Physics. This course will have a deep explanation of how those formulas work by using calculus and vectors. Explanation or the procedure to derive a formula is quite hard to understand but will not be examined.
The new topics including rigid body dynamics, angular momentum, SHM, wave motion and thermodynamics are quite hard especially the first 3.
Thermodynamics is relatively easy since you just have to remember the names of processes and how to use those formulas.
I strongly recommend reading the textbook, lecture notes list only the important points without much explanations. Reading textbook makes you understand more effectively.
A hardcopy is much better than soft copy if you won't study in 1114
reviews.comment_teaching: Very good Professor. He explains clearly with examples. Fluent English with not much accent. Sometimes he makes jokes in the lecture
reviews.comment_grading:
Unexpected good grade
10% hw
5% tutorial
35% midterm
50% final

Hw 10/10
Tutorial 9/10
midterm 28/30
final 26.5/45

Final grade: A

The difficulty of final exam is extremely high, with 3 parts and each part require to finish 15 questions in 50 minutes and you cannot go back. The loading time also reduce the time taking exam.
I once thinking I get B+/A- after the announcement of the scores. But eventually very good grade this year. Saves many students.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework: around 1 set per week
Those questions on Mastering Physics are actually some questions on the textbook. Since marks will be deducted once you entered a wrong answer. There will be a safety measure
that dividing your scores by 0.9 to generate your new score. Which means that you can get full marks if you score 90.
Do remember to ask GOOGLE. Yahoo Answer and Slacks are very useful.

Course content are quite hard. Though attendance is not required, If you miss a lecture, you cannot catch up.

I spent almost 2 weeks to revise final exam since those topics after midterm are completely new to me. Do remember that there is a bunch of NDS who learn these before. Hard work is a must to achieve good grades...

reviews.author: Winnie the Pooh
reviews.title: Altman is the best!!
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite interesting. Just a deeper explanation of the syllabus of HKDSE. Can handle it with HKDSE physics level 3 or above.
reviews.comment_teaching: Altman really is a good teacher. He explains things clearly and with a lot of examples. He does simple experiments every lesson and talks in a funny tone so the class wonâ€™t fall asleep.
reviews.comment_grading: Itâ€™s quite fair. Personally, I didnâ€™t do much revisions. Paying attention in Altmanâ€™s class and scanning through notes are what I did. Turns out that I got 16/30 in the midterm and 22/45 in final. And these get me a B:)
reviews.comment_workload: The only homework is mastering physics. Not too difficult. You can check on google if you get any problems or even get a chegg account. No problem!

reviews.author: Spencerr
reviews.comment_content: Basic physics knowledge.Content before midterm is the same with high school physics so was quite easy. It became harder after midterm.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor's teaching is quite intuitive and more understandable compared with other instructors. The lecture does not require attendance but his teaching helped a lot in understanding the materials.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was quite generous.
Midterm full mark
Final 36/45 top 10
A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Need to spend some time to understand the notes.
Tutorial is boring but attendance is needed.
There's a total of 10 homework. It is a little bit difficult but ta will go through some of the hard ones during tutorials.

reviews.author: æˆ®æŸ’
reviews.title: very difficult
reviews.comment_content: The content is not that difficult. Stuffs that most people had learnt in high school.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor has such a soothing tone. Maybe that's why I fell asleep for every lecture. Tutorials are way more important. Try to finish the assignment before tutorials so that you can ask TA questions instead of paying for chegg.
reviews.comment_grading: Got B- with scores around mean.
reviews.comment_workload: mastering physics is the worst. assignments every week, which normally takes about an hour or so to finish. The exams are around the same difficulty as mastering physics.

reviews.author: uha
reviews.comment_content: Basically physics stuff. But as a person who doesn't like physics, I found some content really difficult. (I've taken physics SL in high school)
reviews.comment_teaching: I really didn't like the way professor teach. He just used the board which I could barely see. The class is always full and unless you come 10 minutes early, you have to sit somewhere at the end. I had class right before this so I always had to sit at the back where I cannot see anything.
reviews.comment_grading: I guess grading is just fair. But I guess the exam is really difficult compared to the homework the professors give us.
reviews.comment_workload: weekly homework. It takes about 1~2 hours. If you don't know the answer, just search it up on the internet. there are bunch of sites that you can find the answers. But you must study and try to solve problems by yourself, unless you will be unsuccessful.

reviews.author: Evelyn!!
reviews.comment_content:
Basic physic knowledege.
target students who have learned the most basic knowledge in physics in high school. Students with more advanced physics background should consider taking 1312. 1112 employs a calculus-based approach. Students without knowlege of calculus should take 1111 instead.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mr Chen made the class easy and the class is always full. He is a passionate teacher. He put much time in proving the physical formula. It is depended on you whether it is good or not. In my opinion, I think it is better to put more effort in introducing the examples instead of proving the equations since most of us cannot understand how the  equations come. Doing more practices may be better for helping us to clarify the concept.
reviews.comment_workload: Average workload. do some pastpaer before the midterm and final.

reviews.author: The Fool
reviews.comment_content:
Mechanics
Physical Quantities, Vectors, and 2D Motion
Newton's Laws of Motion
Work and Kinetic Energy
Potential Energy and Energy Conservation
Momentum, Impulse, and Collisions
Dynamics of Rigid Bodies
Angular Momentum
Gravitation
Simple Harmonic Motion

Waves:
Wave Equation

Thermodynamics:
Temperature and Heat
First Law of Thermodynamics
Second Law of Thermodynamics
reviews.comment_teaching:
Overall, Dr. Cheung's teaching is clear. He explains and prove the theorem in the slides clearly prepares his own notes in addition to the formal lecture notes. His english is good and easy to understand.
Tutor's teaching is good. He replied the email quickly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment
Midterm
Final
Tutorial attendance
reviews.comment_workload:
light
mastering physics once a week

reviews.author: Pika
reviews.comment_content:
I found most of the content of this course really difficult to grasp, even though I studied physics in secondary school.
I had to rewatch lecture videos over and over again just to understand some concepts.

Still I think most of the stuff taught are pretty intriging. If you are interested in physics, I'm sure you're gonna enjoy this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Great teaching!
This is the most enjoyable course I've ever had because of Leung Pak Wo and his sense of humour. He explained concepts and theories very clearly and I really enjoy his experimental demonstrations during lessons, they helped keeping me awake.

Tutorial is ok,. Everytime, tutor would distribute a piece of note and taught you how to do two questions from homework.

I really appreciate the helpdesk this course provided us. Before midterm, you could go and ask the helpers(teachers or PG students) there to teach you. All helpers are nice and patient. And they definitely save my midterm.
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy workload for me.

Homeworks are really hard and stressful, especially when you only have 5 times to ans each questions (and marks will be deducted each time you typed in the wrong ans). It took me forever to finish one homework.

I spent approximately two weeks to do all the supplementary exercises as a way to revise for midterm, in the end I score just above the mean.

reviews.author: GYC
reviews.comment_content: Relatively easy for mainland student, but maybe not for local student.
reviews.comment_teaching: CHEUNG, Man Fung is a very good teacher, his explanation is quite easy to understand as long as you focus on listening. Sometimes there are in class experimental demonstration, quite interesting !
reviews.comment_grading:
Full marks (25/25) in mid-term& 31/45 in final, 100/100 of homework got A-

Midterm is easy but final is super hard for 90% of us I think.
reviews.comment_workload: If you want a higher score without a very good basis, you need to do more practice on the textbook. Generally it's fair.

reviews.author: angiechan
reviews.comment_content: It is about classical mechanics and thermodynamics. You need to have calculus knowledge to handle this course. It is similar to your high school physics but with more calculus in it.
reviews.comment_teaching: Depends on which professor, some of them are boring. The tutorials counts your attendance so remember to go to your tutorials every time.
reviews.comment_grading: The course is hard to get good grade if you do not study well. There will be two tests and one final exams. Cheat sheets are not allowed. For the tests there will be 10 mc questions.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite a lot. You have to do mastering physics every week. Whenever you answered a question wrongly, your marks will be deducted. So make sure the answer is correct before you submit it. There are limited chance for you to answer each question.

reviews.author: hsy1021
reviews.title: better to study it by yourself
reviews.comment_content: lecture contents are all about proving the equations with calculus method, which is very difficult to understand. I would prefer to study the notes and equation by myself rather than listening to the proves that made me more confused.
reviews.comment_teaching: quite boring because the lecture contents are difficult and I cannot catch up.
reviews.comment_grading:
fair. quiz performed badly (3 and 1 out of 10 respectively)
final is all mc questions, 25 out of 40. C+
reviews.comment_workload: light workload, every week one assignment from mastering physics. most answers can be found online by searching the questions directly on google.

reviews.author: Potter
reviews.title: Difficult but it is quite interesting and can get good grade
reviews.comment_content:
-More advance high school physic with calculus.
-Heat and Gases ,Force and Motion,Wave Motion (topics in DSE), å°¤å…¶Force and Motionæœéƒ¨åˆ†å€‹åŸºç¤æœ‰å¤ å¥½.
-New topics: rigid body(quite difficult, need some time to master it) , angular momentum( not to hard),  thermodynamics (tricky, you need to master the pv diagram and remember the sign convention of Q(heat flow) and W(work done by the system) clearly) , etc

Conclusion and useful advice: do more exercise on the homework system or simply retry the homework problems for revision and you will be fine for quizs and exams. Also,khanacademy has a lot of great video for this course. It's awesome for you to catch up and understand more if you find it very hard to understand the lecture.
reviews.comment_teaching: Though a bit local accent and tell you not to use electronic devices during class , it's very good overall. He often inspires you to think and asks thought-provoking questions. Better not to skip his lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
I thought I was gonna get B range during the rigid body lecture series( about half-way of the course), but I got A finally. Some topics are difficult but if you do a bit more practice and watch some videos for those topics, then you can get a good grade.

My grades:
Assignment: 9x% = full mark
Quiz 1(Raw): 8/10 (Mean is around 5-6)
Quiz 2(Raw): 9/10 (Mean is around 5 but lower than Quiz 1)
Final: 35/45
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly online homework(MasteringPhysics) containing challenging questions. Sometimes need 2-3 hours to finish

reviews.author: Hritvik
reviews.title: PHYS1112
reviews.comment_content: Mostly a review of High school physics. Topics covered include: mechanics, gravitation, heat, etc. IB students might find the content to be a bit more in-depth. For instance, the carnot cycle might be something new. It is interesting content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is easy to grasp, but most of the work has to be done by your self. Interesting questions are provided in class. The class notes are helpful but almost everything would be available in the given book.
reviews.comment_grading: Fairly graded. Not too harsh, not too easy. The homeworks are easy to score in. The final exam has tougher questions which are different from the type of questions given in the homework or the tests. Not enough time to finish all questions on time in the final exam. Try the past papers in order to increase your speed. It is easy to score full marks in homeworks and tests, so focus on the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly homework assignments of about 10 questions each. The online homework portal has a lot of fun questions but some of the questions can be quite challenging.

reviews.author: jmadiguna
reviews.comment_content:
Uses a lot of single variable calculus but sometimes includes partial differentiation and some differential equations. Also includes vectors.

Physics : Newton's Law, Energy, Momentum, Dynamics of Rigid Body, Angular and Linear Momentum, Gravitation, Periodic motion, Wave, Heat, Law of thermodynamics
reviews.comment_teaching:
2 Lectures a week, usually covering a chapter with a Homework assigned for the end of the week as well as a tutorial section that records attendance.

These confusing questions, however, were actually already given through the supplementary questions on each chapter, so if you do have time to do them, it is highly recommended.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two quizzes (around 40%), Finals, Tutorial attendance, and Homework ( one for each chapter )

Homework deducts points for each wrong attempt

The quizzes were 10 questions that were checked by computer, so make sure you have EXACTLY what the questions want you to say. There are no partial credits in the quizzes.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy

While the homework assignments weren't particularly difficult, they do require a bit of research to finish properly.

The two quiz / "midterms" are what make up the bulk of the workload, as preparing for these questions usually require you to practice a whole lot more when compared to the homework assignments. The final is also more difficult in that the last third of the course ( heat, thermodynamics, etc) make up the bulk of the questions and were never before tested, so you have no idea of what kind of questions to expect.

reviews.author: Chen
reviews.comment_content:
Originally I planned to take the course in first semester, however, it required one to pass or having calculus for enrollment that I could only take the course in spring.
Most of the content match to what I learnt in high school, the topics are listed below :
Motions and Newton's laws
Work and energy
Conservation of energy and momentum
Rotation
Rigid body
Simple harmonic and damped oscillations
Forced oscillations
Standing waves and sound waves
Kinetic theory
The laws of thermodynamics.
In all the topic above, only the laws of thermodynamics is the totally new topic to me, that I spend most of my time during final to catch it up, as for other topics, the basic knowledge learn in high school is quite enough to deal with them.
One thing to add on is that even though the course require one to have calculus skills, but most of the case were instructor deriving the equation and explain how the formula formed. Don't need to worry about this part too much.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor taught really well in my opinion. His pace for lecture was just right for me, a suitable speed that allow me to take the notes and listen to lecture. In the meanwhile, he always derive the formula and told the reasons behind the equation. Though these are not used in quizzes, but helped me in remember the idea behind.
reviews.comment_grading:
For midterm, the mean score was super high that only if you reach full mark that you could get more than 1 SD than mean score. As for the final, it contains the content for whole semester. Strangely, this time the part already covered by midterm was much more difficult than expected, that the paper didn't focus that much at thermodynamics like previous year.
Overall, the grading scheme is like:
Assignments: 10%
Tutorial: 5%
Midterm: 35%
Final: 50%
I got full mark in assignment and tutorial, 0.77 SD higher than mean in midterm, 1.29 SD higher than mean in final.
The grading is actually quite fair. I finally got an A.
reviews.comment_workload: The homework is an online grading system. Need to finish each week's work before each Sunday evening. As long as you pay attention in class you normally can solve most of the problem set in the website. As for some difficult ones, during tutorial, some of the TA will help explaining the problem.

reviews.author: tsetse
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching: prof han speaks in a flat and boring tone, which makes us sleppy. So i finally sit prof cheung's lecture and he is absolutely much better than han. Although cheung also just deliver his notes on whiteboard again at class, he gives a very logical and clear teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
fair grading

homework: 10% (a factor 10/9 has been applied to the score, the score is also truncated at 100)
tutorial attendance: 5% (only the highest 10 tutorial attendance score is counted)
midterm: 35%
final: 50%

me
homework: full mark
tutorial attendance:  full mark
midterm: 23/25 (average: 20.13/25, SD: 5.03)
final: 30/45 (average: 22.3/45, SD: 8.3)
grade: B+

both exams are MC. Midterm is easy and many people get full mark, but final is much harder.
reviews.comment_workload:
weekly mastering physics hw (10 mc)

it's acceptable but remember to do hw every week!!!

reviews.author: Zechidlin
reviews.comment_content: Classical mechanics and introduction to thermodynamics. Before the midterm most stuffs were learnt during high school except the rigid body part. This course covers  a lot but most contents are superficial and you only need to memorize certain formulae and know how to use them.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr.Cheung was a good instructor. He used his own handwritten notes that were clear and easy to follow, and was also passionate about teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Hw: 10%.Noxious mastering physics system.... I prefer written hw actually. This system has only few questions on it but requires 1.5hrs-2hrs each time to finish them. Not because the problems are difficult, but is due to the low-effectiveness of the computer-based hw system. The score will be normalized (*10/9) in the end in case of unexpected issues.
Tutorial attendance: 5%. Only counts ten out of twelve. Tutorial problems were easy and donâ€™t help too much.
Midterm:35%. VERY easy.. many people got full marks and the mean was about 20/25.
Final:50%. Adequate difficulty. There were few difficult questions but most were easy to deal with. Mean was about 22 or sth and sd....I forget.
Grades:
Hw and tutorial full. Midterm 24/25, final 38/45. I didnâ€™t revise before the final so  I only got 2 or 3 correct in last five questions that were related to refrigerators! So it is important to go through some memorial stuffs before the exams. Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Hmm, mastering physics is truly annoying. But the overall workload is still acceptable. Each week you only need about 2 hrs to finish all exercises. Extensive learning is recommended, for you will have a better understanding after doing some extra work.

reviews.author: Fickdeinemutter
reviews.comment_content:
Classical Mechanics, Circular Motion, Simple Harmonic Motion & Introductory Thermodynamics.

Stuff NOT taught at DSE Level, e.g. Non-uniform Circular Motion, Moment of Inertia, Angular Momentum, Simple Harmonic Motion, Wave Equation, Real Gas, Isothermal/Adiabatic Processes, 2nd Law of Thermodynamics etc. are compressed into THIS course.

It's necessary for those who want to do Physics at university, but may not be good for those doing others.

If you've taken any physical chemistry's courses before enrolling in PHYS 1112, you may find the thermodynamics' part a bit easier.

You need to be good at Calculus, or you would face some problems.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He doesn't teach well, but I can see that he is a devoted teacher. Many people commented poorly on him here, but I don't want to do so.

Learning is always yours, which shouldn't be relied on teachers all the time.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-Term: 35%
Final Exam: 50%
Online HW: 10%
Tutorial: 5%

Mid-Term's mean: 20.1/25 (Me: 21/25)
Final Exam's mean: 22.3/45 (Me: 24/45), SD: 8.3
Online HW's Mean: 92.06%
Tutorial: Unknown

For the Online HW, they claimed that a factor of 10/9 had been applied to the score when transferred from the MasteringPhysics' server.

For the Tutorials, the 1st two were waived. Only the highest 10 out of 11 were counted.
reviews.comment_workload:
Online HW is the worst torture.
Weekly.
Non-stop.

You've only FIVE chances for each question. You CANNOT change the answers following submission.

Rounding-off errors would also result in mark-deductions.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. WONG is quite poor in delivering lectures. He seemed unable to explain things clearly and he preferred to write some important points/steps on board with very little explanation. But he is quick in replying to emails and very patient and open to questions. He would randomly ask questions to those sitting in the front.
Prof. WANG is another way of teaching. He would talk through the entirety of the lecture without much interaction. He can explain things clearly and fully but one will have to follow him carefully or s/he will get lost quite soon.
reviews.comment_grading:
5% Homework
5% Attendance
20% Test 1 ( 10 short questions )
20% Test 2 ( 10 short questions )
50% Final Exam ( 45 mc ) ( I am glad the final exam is all mcq, at least I can choose random answers for most questions instead of typing some numbers you know that's 99% wrong )
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not huge, only 1 homework for about 15 questions per week and 2 exams. Additional exercises are optional but they might be helpful in preparing for exams. Formula sheets are provided so one will not have to remember all of the complex formulas.

it is quite fair for any one and

Workload is extremely high

Final exam is so difficult and you should concentrate on 45 mc in 3 hours which need many of your calculation.

reviews.author: elwc
reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus:
1. Physical quantities, vectors & Motion in 2D
2. Newton's laws of motion
3. Work and kinetic energy
4. Potential energy and energy conservation
5. Momentum, impulse and collision
6. Dynamics of rigid bodies
7. Angular momentum
8. Gravitation
9. Periodic motion
10. Wave motion and sound
11. Temperature and heat
12. Thermal properties of matter
13. First law of Thermodynamics
14. Second law of Thermodynamics

If you are good at DSE physics, it is not hard for you to get a good grade here. I think the most complicated topic is wave. Nevertheless and luckily, it is not a big topic here.

Materials needed: Lecture notes & Textbook
You must buy one textbook to get the code inside to activate an Mastering Physics account for homework... What a dumb idea

You must also attend tutorials as attendance counts to the course grade.

There are two midterms which are generally easy (only 10 MC questions each). You will have plenty of time to complete them. You can retake each midterm once for a higher score.

Final exam is harder and it looks more like a real exam. Don't get fooled by the difficulty of midterm.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cheung is great. His teaching is not boring. He is friendly and you will feel comfortable to ask him physics questions. He also provides online supplementary notes of deriving some equations when he does it in lecture. These can be reviewed on Canvas.

TA is ok.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair but I am not sure if it is éš grade
reviews.comment_workload:
Every week there is one online homework which normally takes you 0.5 to 1 hour to finish it because most of the questions are not hard. And in the tutorial sessions, you will get solutions for 20% to 30% of the homework. (But different TAs may teach different things in the tutorials.)

For midterm weeks homework, it will not be graded. Therefore in my opinion the overall workload is not heavy

reviews.author: davemaa
reviews.comment_content: Basically everything from senior high school.
reviews.comment_teaching: He explains clearly. He always gives you at least one live experiment in front of the class.  His accent is also good. He explains everything, from the formula to the theory. But he never explains any of the tests.
reviews.comment_grading: Quite hard to get a good score. Need to be careful in calculating and stuffs.
reviews.comment_workload: You need to do Masteringphysics every week. The score will be graded and put into your overall score. Your score will be deducted every time you enter the wrong answer.

reviews.author: Pollux
reviews.title: Good grade?
reviews.comment_content:
The content taught is very hard. In-depth physics than HKDSE. Basically I cannot follow the concepts well during lectures.
New concepts than DSE: rigid body, angular momentum, thermodynamics as well as differentiation/integration of DSE concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lectures are boring, his voices sounds like in a hurry (tbh there are a lot of stuff needed to be taught, 1/3 of DSE squeezed into half a year). The TAs in tutorial is nice, he explains the concept well. I picked up my concepts through tutorials. Therefore I seldom take lecture but always take tutorials (tutorials also counts attendance)
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments: 5%
Attendance: 5%
Test 1: 20%
Test 2: 20%
Final Exam: 50%

Assignments are webwork on Mastering Physics (you need to buy the licence). Fill in the blanks and MC, marks are deducted on wrong answers. However if you get 90% overall you will get 100% in assignments as the denominator is 90%.

Tests are 10 questions similar to webwork. Only final answer is marked. Marks are scaled upon difficulty.

Final is 45 MC.

My score:
hw&attendance: 100%
test 1 raw: 8/10
test 2 raw 9/10
final: 34/45

Overall: 86.44 A
reviews.comment_workload:
Webwork every week, 10 questions fill in the blanks and MC
2 tests and including retake is 4 tests
No midterm but it is split into test
Homworks are hard and you cannot get too many incorrect answers, so it is time-consuming

reviews.author: Umanilliti
reviews.comment_content: Basically DSE physics plus some A-level (e.g. angular momentum, thermodynamics)
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. CHEUNG teaches very well. Explain all the things in detail, if have any doubt, you can ask him in class or after class, he will explain to you again using other examples than in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Both online quiz ~90%
Final exam: 66.7%
The online quiz could take nearly 40~45% of your final grade. So just prepare well for that since you are not going to do well in the final. Midterm is actually already extremely easy.
reviews.comment_workload:
There will be 2 online quizzes, or midterm as you like.
One final, and homework every week. The homework is actually quite annoying, consider you would have it every week. But those are actually a quite useful exercise for your midterm. Though the Final is extremely hard, and the difficulty exceeds the supplementary exercise. (in which is hard already.) 33/45 could get A already.

reviews.author: IamMartin
reviews.comment_content: a lot of equation and theory needed to be remeber and it is really hard for a student that not good at physic to understand also the final exam is fxxking difficult
reviews.comment_teaching: fun and nice teaching is good but it is hard for me to understand what  the tutor is talking about
reviews.comment_grading: bad grade , i got c range even when i have a final result that higher than mean and median dont take this course if you are not really smart or work really hard on it
reviews.comment_workload: high workload, you need to finish the homework like u did on webwork and it is hard

reviews.author: Kai cheng
reviews.comment_content: In the first half of the course , it covers the physic taught in secondary school. In the second part, It covers the A-level physic and some M2 .
reviews.comment_teaching: In my seeciton , the professer provides lecture viedo , so i dont have to go to school .
reviews.comment_grading: I got all full mark quiz but only 70% in exam. I got a B+ finally .
reviews.comment_workload: It requires you to finish the online homework weekly and finish the tutorial as it counts attendance. Although some online exercise are optional , it is suggested to finish the homework on your own as it helps you to clear all the concepts .

reviews.author: Guy
reviews.comment_content:
There were mainly two parts, classical mechanics and thermal dynamics.

It was easy to follow for the classical mechanics part as most of the contents were seen in DSE physics. The only things new would be calculus and some out-of-syllabus content in DSE. But the calculus was easy enough for you to understand.

The thermal dynamics part was difficult. It became more and more challenging as the content went on.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor was pretty good. He could present clear teaching as he had a hong kong style accent. But he didn't like students using electronic devices in class. He would always ask questions in class. Just get prepared if you are playing with your phones because he would ask those students to answer his questions. Overall, he was a fun professor and it was not boring to attend the lessons.
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty accurate grading. For me, a student who had already forgotten almost all physics knowledge from the 2-year-ago DSE physics, I still got a C grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly online homework. It took so much time to finish.

reviews.author: Jo_harden
reviews.title: A course requiring hard work
reviews.comment_content: The content is not that difficult which mostly covers DSE physics topics. The exam will also consist of a few calculus questions. Exams are all MC or Short questions.(filling in the answer only)
reviews.comment_teaching: Cheung Man Fung's teaching speed is quite fast but I think it is just adequate for students with DSE M2 and Physics background. He will answer students questions in the lesson and discuss with the class. His hand written notes are useful for understanding physic concept.
reviews.comment_grading: I got 1 +1 SD in mid term and final and full marks in HW grade and tutorial attendence. Then, I got B+. I think A- is 1.5 SD.
reviews.comment_workload: A hardwork-pay course when u have to do exercise before exams.

reviews.author: Kkent
reviews.comment_content: It is mostly mechanics and a little bit of thermodynamics at the end. It is quite similar to high school level physics with some calculation involving calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Boong does not explain the materials clearly as he often skip steps and his pace is too fast for me. Although you can ask the professor for help after class or during office hours, I suggest you supplement your learning by studying the materials by yourself as all the lecture notes are provided online.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not too bad.

I got 5/10 on the first test and 7/10 for the retake (20%).
6/10 for test 2 (20%)
and 32/45 for the finals (50%)
I got B+ in the end which is okay considering my performance.
Make sure you do all the homework properly (5%) and attend all the tutorials (5%).
reviews.comment_workload: Just weekly homeworks posted on MasteringPhysics which accounts for 5% of your grade. Questions are not that hard in my opinion. If you find a question difficult, just ask during the tutorial session.

reviews.author: dlo00
reviews.comment_content:
Extremely hard course if you have little to no background in physics, especially since the content of the course is so broad, you won't have time to study each section in-depth.
You learn kinematics, forces, periodic motion, waves, torque, etc. The only part I was good at was thermodynamics, because I studied chemistry in high school.
The content of the quizzes and final exam is harder than the homework questions and I didn't have enough time to finish all of the questions on the final. Both the quizzes and final only have multiple-choice questions, which is a good thing because you can just guess, but also a bad thing because the questions require a lot of calculations so if you mess up just a little, you lose the entire question.
For the final, I only studied thermodynamics and only seriously answered thermodynamics questions; for other questions I just guessed.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is very enthusiastic about teaching, and does his best to keep students awake during 9 ams using jokes, anecdotes, and live demonstrations. He is also willing to stay behind after class and answer questions. However, he focuses more on concept rather than calculations so if you are looking to just pass the exams or if you are struggling with calculations and using the formulae you will want to invest your time in something other than the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was very beneficial to me, because I did poorly in this course yet still passed.
Homework (at least 90% on each assignment will give you full marks)
2 quizzes
Final exam
reviews.comment_workload:
Around 10 homework questions (for marks) each week on Mastering Physics, in addition to optional practice questions.
Just doing the homework questions isn't enough to get a satisfactory mark - you will want to spend extra time on studying, and especially on reviewing because there's so much content taught.
As well, the formula sheet given on quizzes and on the exam is limited and you will need to memorize formulae.

No need to attend lecture if you just want to get good grade. Doing some exercises in mastering physics is enough to obtain a good grade.

4. Attendance is counted in tutorials as a part of grade (5%)

reviews.author: namreh
reviews.title: Good grade if work hard
reviews.comment_content:
For those who study DSE before, the course is much more difficult than DSE. The contents are much more advanced. You have to skillfully apply your M2 knowledge into this course.
Only reg this course if you are confident in both physics and M2. Otherwise, it is quite tough to do this course.
And this course requires a compulsory textbook to activate the Mastering Physics platform where you do the exercise. So a brand-new textbook is a must.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Excellent teaching. Both of them are enthusiastic in teaching students. They are very willing to answer questions from students. The notes provided are also well-written.
Lecture videos are provided on Canvas.
But the tutorial is useless, completely a waste of time. The TAs are reluctant to answer questions. I did ask them some questions, and they asked me to go to physics help desk.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grades if you work hard.

There are 2 tests (20%, 20%), 1 final (45%), tutorial (5%), assignments (10%). No midterm.
Final is 45 MC. Each tests contains 10 questions.
Most people could get full marks in tutorial and assignments. But the mean of the tests and final is very low. Test 1 and Test 2 around 5.5/10. Final 24.1/45 SD 7.7.
If you work hard (finishing the supplementary exercise), you could easily get A range. Coz most people do not even touch those supplementary exercise.
reviews.comment_workload:
Expect to do 10 questions on Mastering Physics every week, all of which counts towards the grade and they are not easy.
But if you want to get a good grade, you must do the supplementary exercises. But personally I believe some of the exercise are too difficult. To finish these exercise, you have to at least spend 3 hours every week in this course.

reviews.author: Never Social
reviews.title: All good except MASTERING PHYSICS
reviews.comment_content:
Mech and thermo
Refer to other posts for detailed content
Nothing too hard, you'll be forced to buy the textbook anyways, just refer to it and khan academy if lectures don't suffice.

2 tests. Pick your own time in the assigned week. Computer generated values in a library of question, your score will scale according to the difficulty of the questions.

Attendance mark for tutorials.

Online homework done on MASTERING PHYSICS. Literally cancer. Homework website that make students google every question on chegg or yahoo answers because clicking anything will take away some mark. That shit buggy as fuck. Over time you got paranoid, it senses your weakness then bam. You'll get it wrong every time. Suggestion: Do the questions in your textbook beforehand. They're more or less the same.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecturer is a funny guy. Shame that the role of a lecturer aren't apperent for easy course, by nature.

That tutorial dude bring different musical intrument in class, some are for teaching purposes, but some, I think just for his entertainment lol. Hell, I just launch my Celeste everytime.

20% each test, 45% final, 10% hw, 5% tut attendance, said the guy over at the next review.

test 1 9/10

hw 7.5/10 (screw this)

A

reviews.author: ayf
reviews.comment_content:
Textbook:
University Physics by Young and Freedman (14th Edition)
(Including access code for Mastering Physics, an online platform for weekly homework)
I highly recommend buying the e-book instead of the hard copy. Itâ€™s a little bit more expensive, but you can use it for PHYS1114. To be honest, the hard copy is quite heavy.

Syllabus (24 lectures):
Mechanics (15 lectures)
  - Newton's laws
  - Work, KE and PE
  - Collision and momentum
  - Rotational motion and moment of inertia (*)
  - Angular momentum and energy (*)
  - Gravitational force and energy
  - Kepler's laws, apparent weight and black holes (*)
  - Simple harmonic motion (*)
  - Real pendulum, damped and forced oscillation (*)
Waves (2 lectures)
  - Transverse waves, power and reflection
  - Standing waves, beating and Doppler effect (*)
Thermodynamics (7 lectures)
  - Thermal expansion and heat (*)
  - Ideal gas law
  - Heat capacity of gas and energy (*)
  - First law of thermodynamics and types of thermodynamics processes (*)
  - Second law of thermodynamics, engine and refrigerator (*)
(*) new topics for DSE students


For DSE Physics students:
The first half of the course should be rather easy if you have studied physics (I mean seriously) in high school, as most topics about mechanics are already covered in DSE. The first quiz only covers lectures 1-7, up to collision and momentum, all within DSE syllabus. Be careful and you should be able to get a relatively high score. The lecturer will do a lot of integration during lesson to derive and explain some theorem. But no need to worry too much about the derivation because understanding the concepts (when and why to use calculus) is more important. Using only your high school knowledge is enough for most cases in homework or even the quiz.
TL;DR: Be relax during lecture and be careful during the quiz

The second quiz mainly focuses on rotational motion, gravity and periodic motion, covering lectures 8-15. It is more difficult than the first quiz because these topics are new, and you will need more revision and exercise to absorb the concepts well. You can no longer rely on high school knowledge. I highly recommend you try the supplementary exercises on Mastering Physics if you are aiming high. Although most of them are more difficult than the actual quiz, they will surely help you fully understand all the new concepts and build your confidence.
TL;DR: Try supplementary exercise to understand new concepts

The final exam is quite challenging I would say. The questions are more difficult than the previous quizzes and you also need to revise all the topics at the same time, including 1/3 of the topics that are not tested before. Questions in the exam are harder than your homework, so you should focus on lectures 16-24. You will need a lot of time/effort to absorb all the concepts without mixing them up. (SHM vs Wave motion, first vs second law of thermodynamics) As I said, I HIGHLY recommend the supplementary exercises on the website. Some of them may be very challenging and some are even out of the exam syllabus, but them will help you learn much more effectively than merely revising the textbook. (Disclaimer: there are TONS of exercises on the website, about 20 long questions per topic. You should plan your time wisely to finish them)
TL;DR: DO NOT REVISE AT LAST MINUTE and try to do more supplementary exercises
reviews.comment_teaching:
Tian Wenâ€™s lectures are quite enjoyable. Even though he is a little bit clumsy and my section is always lagging behind the other sections, he would still try his best to teach as thoroughly as he can, to make sure students can understand the concepts better. He may not have the best explanation or best presentation I would say, but he would reiterate stuffs from the previous lecture sometimes and he is trying hard to make his lectures easy to follow and understand. And even if you have doubts, if you ask him after the lesson, he is willing to explain again or even rephrase it in various ways to help you.

If you often have troubles in understanding the concepts in lectures, maybe you should try reading the textbook before each lecture, it helps a lot. Donâ€™t expect sitting in the lecture without ever studying the notes or textbook will help you absorb all the contents. Notes taking is important.

Sometimes he would crack a joke about the concepts he is explaining. Only if you understand the concepts would you understand his jokes. But not all his students appreciate his humour, I think?

TL;DR: humorous, helpful and passionate lecturer, but you should also pay effort to learn better
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme:
Assignments: 10%
- Mastering Physics online exercises, ~10 questions every 1-2 weeks. Most of them are relatively easy, but the system is quite tricky to use (buggy I would say) Anyways, no need to be too worried when you get some questions wrong (due to system bugs or not), getting over 90% score in each assignments will give you a full mark in this part, because the final score will be scaled by 10/9. Remember to finish on time.

Tutorials: 5%
- You need to attend the tutorial lesson of about 1 hour long each week. The tutor would just tell you to finish your homework there. Fortunately, my tutor takes attendance in the middle of each lesson and therefore being late is not catastrophic.

Test 1 and 2: 20% each
- Each tests consists of 10 mc questions and you need to finish them in an hour in a computer room. The questions are quite easy and the grading scheme is fairly lenient because you can retake each test once, and the system will take the highest score from the following calculation methods:
1. First take * 100%
2. First take * 50% + second take * 50%
3. Second take * 80%
At the end of the semester your raw scores will be adjusted according to the difficulty of the questions in your tests, therefore your actual scores should be higher than the raw scores.

Final exam: 45%
- There are 45 mc questions and you are required to finish them in 3 hours. They all carry equal marks and marks will NOT be deducted for wrong answers. However, the questions are quite hard and you should be careful and well prepared as I said above.


Statistics:
Test 1 first take (Raw):
- Mean: 5.70 / 10
- SD: 2.30
Test 1 second take (Raw):
- Mean: 5.89 / 10
- SD: 2.21
Test 2 first take (Raw):
- Mean: 5.28 / 10
- SD: 2.50
Test 2 second take (Raw):
- Mean: 5.23 / 10
- SD: 2.17
Final:
- Mean: 24.32 / 45
- SD: 7.696
- Max: 44 / 45
- Min: 6 / 45

My grade:
- Assignments (10%): 10 / 10
- Tutorials (5%): 5 / 5
- Test 1: 9 / 10
- Retake 1: 10 / 10
- Adjusted Test 1 (20%): 10 / 10
- Test 2: 9 / 10
- Retake 2: 9 / 10
- Adjusted Test 2 (20%): 9.99 / 10
- Final (45%): 43 / 45
- Overall: 98.0 / 100  (A+)
reviews.comment_workload:
The only homework is the online assignments each week. The questions are quite easy and there are only less than 10 questions in each assignment. You should have enough time to finish it in each tutorial session if you understand the basic concepts. Even though the questions are the same for all students, the data in each question is randomly generated for each student. If you want to ask for your friends' help, make sure you plug in your own data.

Actually the workload is quite light, however I think most of the students would agree that the Mastering Physics system is not so user-friendly and you should expect some strange answers or some confusing sign conventions appearing in your homework. Very often you will find your answer wrong only because of the "intelligent" design of the system.

Another strange policy in this course is that it forces you to attend the tutorials every week, which is a waste of time for most students. The online assignments can be done at home but now they require you to commute to UST every week. I don't quite understand why. For students who are more capable, they may have already finished the work at home, and they will be just siting in the tutorial lesson hanging out with friends. For students who are not so capable, the tutorial session is not long enough for the tutor to help them one by one, while they are struggling with different questions in different sets of homework. But anyways the workload of this course is rather low and okay I would say.

TL;DR: Strange homework system and strange tutorial policy, but very light workload

reviews.author: Luweegee
reviews.title: Definitely not an easy A course
reviews.comment_content:
Generally a calculus approach to the topics you've learnt in DSE and also some extra stuff (previously in AL). Content load is about DSE Topics 1~3 + Extra Stuff crammed into a semester

===Topics (L = Lecture No.)===
L1: Vectors & 2D Motion
L2~3: Newton's Laws of Motion
L4~5: Kinetic Energy & Potential Energy
L6~7: Momentum & Collisions
--------------QUIZ 1-----------------
L8~10: Dynamics of Rigid Bodies
L11: Angular Momentum
L12~13: Gravitation
L14~15: Periodic Motion
--------------QUIZ 2-----------------
L16~17: Wave Motion & Sound
L18: Temperature & Heat
L19~20: Thermal Properties of Matter
L21~22: 1st and 2nd law of thermodynamics

This course will let you re-learn all the stuff from high-school, but with concepts of calculus. You'll see differentiation (including partial derivatives!!) and integration in formulas, and use of cross products. However, you just need simple algebra when dealing with problems. Calculus is only required in derivation of formulas in class and some questions.

I think this course is quite good and interesting since it teaches some university foundation physics like thermodynamics (You'll see it everywhere). But if your physics is not too good then probably you wanna avoid this as the questions can get frustrating.

I would say this course can be demanding as the content is difficult. If your physics foundation in high school is good, then you should do good :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
===General Teaching===
Generally I don't really like that this course is deduction-themed. All the professors will spend MOST of the time deducing formulas instead of problem-solving, which is equally important. The deduction part is the MOST difficult among the whole course. But trust me, you can do equally well if you can use the formulas correctly without knowing any deductions.

===Professor's Teaching===
Professor Jo's teaching is fine. He talks in a rather soft voice which may be hard to listen. His pronunciation is fine, but can be more clear. I literally took 16 lectures to understand a phrase he used always, which is "F equal ma" =_=. He usually have demonstrations in classes but sometimes they fail to work. You can clear some concepts during class as he'll give extra explanation so it's best to attend all classes

===TA's Teaching in Tutorials===
Yang Shuo (The TA) is literally THE CRAPPIEST TA UST CAN HAVE. He just freaking stands in front of a computer and stares at the screen and teaching NOTHING. Sometimes he'll walk around and stalk behind you. Don't expect to learn anything from him! You need to raise your hand to find him, and sometimes he can't just freaking explain why I did the question wrong.

Also, attendance is recorded so there's no escape :)  I hear that other TAs are fine and they teach you how to solve questions
reviews.comment_grading:
===Grading scheme===
Homework - 10%
Tutorial Attendance - 5%
Test 1 - 20%
Test 2 - 20%
Final Exam - 45%

[Raw scores of the tests will be adjusted according to the relative difficulty of the questions]
===Raw Score Statistics===
Test 1 (First-take): Average - 5.70 ; SD - 2.30
Test 1 (Re-take): Average - 5.89 ; SD - 2.21
Test 2 (First-take): Average - 5.28 ; SD - 2.50
Test 2 (Re-take): Average - 5.23 ; SD - 2.17
Final: Average - 24.1 ; SD - 7.7 ; Range: 6~44

===My scores===
Homework - 10/10
Attendance - 5/5
Test 1 - 9/10 [First take: 9/10 ; Re-take: 8/10] â€”> 10/10 after adjustments
Test 2 - 10/10 [First take: 10/10]
Final - 38/45
-------
Final score: 93%
Grade: A+

===Tests (20% x 2)===
Tests are held regularly and non-cumulative. You sit in front of a computer to complete 10 questions for 1 hour. Most of them require you to input a number for answer, and there are around 2~3 MCs. Usually there are 1~2 challenging question that takes you quite some time. Be sure to check for any silly mistakes!
Re-take policy - Highest score is recorded from one of following:
1. First take
2. Average of first and second take
3. Second take * 80%

===Final (45%)===
45 MC questions and CLOSED BOOK. (Have formula sheet provided) It mainly covers the content not covered in tests 1 and 2. Around 40% of questions are related to thermodynamics and gases (L18~22), and they are DIFFICULT. There are 2 questions that require you to derive equations (one using calculus). The professors claimed that they will have 25% questions each for L1~13, L14~17, L18~20 and L21~22 respectively, but there are some deviations from the final paper.

===Homework (10%)===
You are forced to buy a textbook to obtain licensing key for online homework system "MasteringPhysics". You need to complete around 6~10 questions EACH WEEK for the topics just have been taught. (Except for the test weeks, they are not graded). I think they will round off your score to 10/10 if you score 9X% in total for your homework. (Someone says your MasteringPhysics score is multiplied 110% to become your final homework score)

===Tutorials (5%)===
Just show up on time and answer a PRS question. You can leave right after checking attendance (if your TA is shitty lol)


I think you need to be hard-working to get good grade (especially do a lot of questions and recite how to approach that question). If you do slightly above mean I think you get B- or B (not really sure)

By the way, there's a policy to ban any Mainland students from enrolling this in FALL semester only. So, I think the mean in fall semester is a bit lower.
reviews.comment_workload:
Average workload. Can get a little bit more demanding if your physics base knowledge is not good enough. The workload mostly come from doing homework and revising for tests and exams (which were held per 3~4 weeks).

===Homework===
Doing MasteringPhysics is ABSOLUTELY FRUSTRATING. They deduct 10% mark for every incorrect answer. Sometimes they deduct you marks for something stupid like missing minus sign or slightly off number. The questions are also quite difficult and you need to copy the whole stupid question to Google to find answers. You got to repeat this torture each week :)

In order to complete Mastering Physics assignments, you have to buy the textbook: University Physics 14th edition and get a code for mastering physics.

Completing assignments every week will be very burdensome and tired after all. Still, it is important to know question types before you take any tests.

reviews.comment_content:
no easy
