reviews.author: No
reviews.title: little effort->good, study really hard->should be an A
reviews.comment_content:
Physics from high school + more definition and explanation
some new topics which is not really difficult
reviews.comment_teaching: definition, steps to obtain the formula, when and how to use the formulas, some small experiments. You may say that's boring but I think it's good enough for a physics lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Well, to be honest, i didn't study much in the mid term and the final. But always remember to do the online homework.

10% online homework
30% midterm
60% final

Online homework: easy, you can check you're answers online with those model answers, search the book name and you'll find it ;) lol

midterm: I go through all the notes and the online homework again. Calculus is not that important, you don't need to derive the equations. But always know when to apply which formula and it's not that hard. I don't really know how to answer all the questions. It's good enough to know like 70-80% of them.

Final: Similar to midterm, just more questions and cover more topics. Yes, to be honest i didn't revise much. I don't know how to attempt all the questions. If you're hard working and do most of the exercise in the book and the non graded exercise in the online homework site, I bet you will be so much better than me.    

Overall, I got a B+. Important point to note is always take this course in the fall semester. It would be so much better, all the mean will be lower because of some reason, you know.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework is not that difficult when you have the model answers with steps to check and understand it. Do it with a partner or you're friends. EASY.

Do some more sample question and you'll be so good( which i didn't do at all)

So you say workload? Light to Very light, it depends on how high you want to achieve.

reviews.author: YSA
reviews.comment_content:
Topics include:
Physical quantities, vectors & Motion in 2D
Newton's laws of motion
Work and kinetic energy
Potential energy and energy conservation
Momentum, impulse and collision
Dynamics of rigid bodies
Angular momentum
Gravitation
Periodic motion
Wave motion and sound
Temperature and heat
Thermal properties of matter
Laws of Thermodynamics
The content was quite excessive and difficult for an introductory, Common Core course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor explained concepts well, but the lectures were a bit boring and monotonous. The professor and TAs are always open to any questions and doubts though and are very helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 10%
Midterm: 30%
Final: 60%

But the distribution was different for different sections (L1, L2, etc.) and also changes from term to term.
The grading is quite hard as a lot of the students have already covered the course contents during high school and get very high marks.
reviews.comment_workload:
The main work is the weekly online homework assignments to be submitted by the end of every Sunday. The homework consists of 8-10 questions, mostly calculations, which take a long time to complete.
Apart from that constant revision is needed to stay on track, as you cannot just revise before the exams because the content is too much.
Again the workload and assignments are different for different sections, I think some sections had 2 or 3 monthly "tests" instead of a mid-term exam.

reviews.author: ceo
reviews.comment_content: This course talks about topics such as Mechanics, Waves and Thermodynamics, and a lot of them has been covered in high school. Although the course name has 'calculus', it actually doesn't require much calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: Although Prof. Jo talked a bit slow, he managed to reveal the details as clearly as possible. Worth attending to his lectures!
reviews.comment_grading:
This course is a good grade course.
Mid-term: full mark
Final: 38/45
A+
The mean is around B I think.
reviews.comment_workload:
Mid-term, final and MasteringPhysics.
MasteringPhysics is a little bit annoying, as it has homework almost every week. There are also some supplementary exercises, which you do not need to hand in, to have more practices on the topics.

reviews.author: patrick330602
reviews.comment_content: Basically, it's the name. Physics plus calculus. it's basically the physics class you will have in you high school with addition of Calculus involving in it. I have to say it's pretty hard.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mr. Jo is not really good. Although I know he taught a lot for a certain day, I cannot really understand what he is really talking about, I have to look back the video.
reviews.comment_grading: The tests are pretty hard. Don't expect too much on the test.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not heavy. You will get a homework per week, and they are fairly easy.

reviews.author: Chisino
reviews.title: You should put more time
reviews.comment_content:
It covers a little bit of the HKDSE physics, maybe the topic is the same, such as heat, mechanics, wave, etc.
The contents it cover is harder and wider, so be careful.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Leung is a great professor, he teach physics with his passions and i didn't feel bored when i was attending his lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: Trust me, it is not that difficult to get a good grade, most of the students got B range, and if you did more exercise, A range is so close..
reviews.comment_workload: Mastering Physics is the only thing to do in my lecture session, if you do it promptly after it had been released, you will find that it is a easy job.

reviews.author: july
reviews.title: good course to reg:)
reviews.comment_content: not difficult to understand but the questions in the exam are sometime quite complicated. The tutorial section is super useful, if you are planning to study this course by just read the notes, then you better go to the tutorial every week to check if your concept is correct or  not. I don't remember the name of my tutorial's instructor, but she is good, explain things very clear and she even will have a small review about the stuff taught every week. So actually just attend the  tutorial section is enough already.

But you don't need to worry much since it will have lecture video for this course so you don't really need to take the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: this course's grading is not bad, i think it is because most of the people are like me, don't really know how to solve those questions, haha
reviews.comment_workload: every week have around 10 questions to do online, the Mastering physics, but if you ask ur friend or seniors, you can find the sources of it and that 10 questions could be done in around 15mins or 30 mins if you take your time.

reviews.author: oneonejin

reviews.author: s123
reviews.comment_content: The book is good enough as a study material but additional youtube videos may be required as all concepts are not covered in lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching: LEUNG, Pak Wo- good teacher, interactive
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading for test's in L3 and L4 is bad
mcq or numerical input test's and losing marks is really easy
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly graded hw.
L3 and L4 have test 1 and test 2 instead of mid terms. they also have re test to improve grades and take mean of both test if retake has a higher score than test.

reviews.author: cdbn
reviews.title: Good Course
reviews.comment_content: Good content with lecture note provided. This course managed to provide deeper understanding for physics based on high school physics and added in calculus element which is crucial for further study in engineering major.
reviews.comment_teaching: Instructor paid much effort to provide best teaching, but sometimes the progress was too fast so many students couldn't manage to cope.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grade with wide A range.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly assignment with around ten questions. As long as we do revision and pay attention in class, the questions are easy and can score full marks easily.

reviews.author: coho
reviews.comment_content: The first 10 lectures are similar to dse , then the other 13 lectures are new. The content are not too complicated if you have spend time on it doing the online homework and tutorials.
reviews.comment_teaching: Pretty good ascent, but not helping with the teaching.  Although you know every word he said, you just can't get the idea. So i just went to class a few times.
reviews.comment_grading: Surprisingly good grade. Only having 70% in the final  got me an A.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much, just one online homework every week with 5-8 questions. Not hard to get all correct with source.

reviews.author: Sweetheart
reviews.comment_content: Topics are really similar to high school physics. Just more conceptual, maybe.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For me lectures are so so boring and i dont understand a thing.
Tutorials are much better. L3 L4 tutorials are different from that of L1 L2 L5 L6 ( tutorial attendance are graded + 2 tests before final instead of one midterm). Both of the teaching systems have their +-
L3 L4 provide a retake for each test. But that means 4 tests in a term. It can be quite hectic if you have other midterms going on as well.
reviews.comment_grading: Depends on how good you are. But achieving the mean =C+ .They said fall term mean tends to be lower than spring.
reviews.comment_workload: Masteringphysics assignments due every Sunday. If you have the answer key or you're good in physics i think you can finish the hw in an hour.

reviews.author: swdk
reviews.title: very good Grade but heavy workload
reviews.comment_content: The contents before the mid term include mainly DSE mechanics. Contents after the mid terms include all topic of the book excluding fluid mechanics.( including some new topics in waves,Doppler effects, gravitation(astronomy elective in DSE), moment of inertia, Angular  momentum)
reviews.comment_teaching: Cheung Man Fung is a good teacher. His teaching is clear and concise. I really enjoy his lectures. I would really recommend attending his lectures as he uses his own notes which in my opinion more clear and concise the lectures on the course webpage.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is quit Good. I got A+ in the course, which helps a lot towards my GPA.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is unbelievably high. This Years course in lecture 3 and 4 are crazy(we the Ginny pig of the new physic structure apparently).  We got two quiz in replace of the mid term. Each quiz will have two chances (the score is counted average if the second take is higher). Which mean that there are 4 quiz in total (in 4 weeks) which is very time consuming.

The tutorial in L3 and 4 are taking attendance, so you cannot skip those class.

The course also include a weekly homework which count towards 5% of the final grade

reviews.author: Spaceship
reviews.title: æ²’æœ‰æœ€å¥½gradeï¼Œåªæœ‰æ›´å¥½grade
reviews.comment_content: Nothing to learn except for thermodynamics (in which only the basics of it is taught). Don't be fooled that this course is for students with calculus backgrounds, there was not a single question regarding integration/differentiation in the midterm and final exams. Students with 5** in physics are strictly recommended to take PHYS1312, where they can actually learn physics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Chen is generally good at explaining physical concepts  and is proficient in English, Cantonese and Mandarin alike. However, his classes are quite boring and he's humorous in an awkward way in his demonstrations. Still, he knows the common mistakes students tend to make (eg. messing up "work done on" and "work done by") and gives good emphasis on them.
reviews.comment_grading: EXTREMELY good grades, to an extend that it's UNFAIR for students getting >2sd or taking other courses. You only need to be above mean ~0.75sd to get A range. In fact, I have never seen a better-grade 1-level course than this up to my knowledge. (This is only true for fall sem though.)
reviews.comment_workload: Nothing to do except mastering physics, in which you only need to get 90% to obtain full marks for hw. It is a piece of cake. However, I've heard that the mastering physics problems in L3&L4 tend to be much more stressful than those in other sessions.

reviews.author: sgargaa
reviews.title: High school stuff
reviews.comment_content: The content was basically the same stuff that we did in high school, with topics like kinematics, rotation, sound, waves and thermodynamics.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is definitely among the best professors that I have had in this university. He spends a good amount of time on all the required concepts in the course, and a good amount of time on the questions. he has a very understandable accent and he did a great job in my opinion.
reviews.comment_grading:
Tutorials 5% Attendance in tutorials were compulsory.
Homework 5% on Mastering Physics.
Midterm-1 15%
Midterm-2 15%
For the two midterms, the course had a very interesting rule. For every midterm you could take a re-test, without any penalty. If you scored more in the real test, then that score would be counted as the final one. However, if you score more on the re-test, then your final score would be the average of the two.
Example- If you score 10/15 in the real test, but 8/15 in the re-test, then your final score is 10. However, if you score 8/15 in the real test and 10/15 in the re-test, then your final score is 9.
reviews.comment_workload: Even though you would have done everything before, and there is nothing that you would have had to do extra here, yet since you did all these topics in high school in 1 year and here, in only 1 semester, hence it was difficult to cope up and you could feel the professor running through the topics at times. The midterm and final examinations are really hard, and very conceptual.

reviews.author: TCheung
reviews.title: Best PHYS common core
reviews.comment_content:
Key topics includes: Newton's laws of motion, Momentum, Rigid bodies, Gravitation, Periodic motion, Wave and Heat.

More than a half of the topics is in the syllabus of DSE. Although there is the word "calculus" in the course name, you can just ignore it.

As a business student, I have studied both PHYS1002, 1003 and 1112. I think PHYS1112 is the easiest course among the three common cores. In fact, I found there were a number of business students taking this course too.
reviews.comment_teaching:
A good local professor. Detailed explanation and clear pronunciation of English compared to other physics professors. It was quite lively and interesting when he was answering questions after class using Cantonese.

The pace of teaching, however, was very slow that he explained everything in details even some of them are just simple concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade. The mean was extremely low in the FALL semester because nearly no mainland is here.

Homework  10%
Midterm  30%
Final  60%

Formula table is provided in both the midterm and final, though not all the formulae are included. But there is no need of reciting the formulae, because you can easily derive most of them when you need them. Those formulae that are difficult to derive are already given in the formulae table.

Midterm above 1.6 SD, Final above 1.8 SD
-> A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload compare to the core courses, only a few on-line homework is required (around 5 to 7 questions), which will take you about half to an hour each week.

The marks of the homework will be adjusted by a factor of inverse 0.9, so most of the students got full marks after adjustment. Since you can try the answer for several times, it is easy to get the credits.

reviews.author: legendarychriz
reviews.title: A course which helps you to clear the concepts in force and motion
reviews.comment_content:
It mainly talks about Force and Motion in physics.
Wave is WAY MORE DIFFICULT THAN THE PAST
You will also learn about moment of inertia in this course.

It is easy for students who did good in physics at past.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Extremely good professor. There will be some demonstrations during the lecture, and the professor himself is able to explain the concepts in force and motion clearly.
Also, the professor can maintain a good learning atmosphere, and encourage us to think more about physics.
Don't skip classes because it is fun to attend his lectures!!!
reviews.comment_grading:
For students who get lower than level 5 in DSE, better be careful. It is because there will be tons of people having level 5* or 5** in DSE physics. To them, this course is a piece of cake, they are able to score extremely high marks in exams. If you want to get B or above while you are not good enough in physics at secondary schools, pay extra effort.

There are 9 lectures, L3 and L4 have different grading policy.

As a student in L3,

Grading in L3, L4
TUTORIAL ATTENDANCE 5%
homework 5%
Mid term 30% (In the form of 2 quizzes)
Final Exam 60%

Also, students enroll in L3, L4 will receive different versions of homework.
reviews.comment_workload: There will be assignments each week. You can do supplementary exercises if you wish to. If you forget to do on time, you will receive 0 mark in that assignment even if you finish afterwards.

reviews.comment_workload: simply no workload

reviews.author: Arange
reviews.comment_content: This course first introduces force and motion which you have learnt in high school. Other topics include gravitation, wave, optics, heat, thermodynamics. It covers a lot of topics in physics but it will not let you study the topics in a deeper way.
reviews.comment_teaching: He teaches quite good with one to two experiments performed by him in class. However, the lecture is quite boring. It is easy to fall asleep. You can choose not to attend the lecture if you are familiar with those topics since he just talks about the proof of some formulas. For the tutorial, the problems given are useful and can be used for practice. There are also some PRS questions in class but they are not counted in grade.
reviews.comment_grading: It involves one midterm, one final and homework. Be careful that there are usually many students getting full mark in both midterm and final. If you want to get a range, you need to work very hard.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of the homework is quite heavy since it needs to be handed in once a week. This course will use a platform called mastering physics but the questions in homework are quite challenging. You have a few chances to attempt the questions. If you answer the question wrongly, the mark of that question will be decreased by 10 out of 100.

reviews.author: Ricky
reviews.comment_content:
Thermodynamic, mechanics and sound wave with calculus.
Something like physics in DSE, but with some calculus calculation.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very few practical calculations in the lectures, mainly proof of formulae.
Tutorial will deal with practical problems mainly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-Term and Final Exam are all MCQs. They will be a little bit harder than the HW.
HW is counted towards final grading for ~10%
Study PHYS1112 in Fall is recommended since the grading in spring is really poor.
reviews.comment_workload: There was online HW every week. The questions were basically questions in the textbook, but with some changed parameters. The number of trials of questions are limited and marks will be deducted if your answer is wrong.

reviews.author: DST
reviews.comment_content:
Basic dynamics and thermodynamics are included. The wave and thermodynamics parts are a little bit confusing at first but with practice, one can do them proficiently.
Tutorial classes are not very popular, because they are simply doing exercises.
The help desk service is quite helpful though, where you can get some one-to-one help from teaching assistants.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. WONG is quite poor in delivering lectures. He seemed unable to explain things clearly and he preferred to write some important points/steps on board with very little explanation. But he is quick in replying to emails and very patient and open to questions. He would randomly ask questions to those sitting in the front.
Prof. WANG is another way of teaching. He would talk through the entirety of the lecture without much interaction. He can explain things clearly and fully but one will have to follow him carefully or s/he will get lost quite soon.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 35%
Final 55%
Homework 10%
The exams are quite simple, with only MC questions and plenty of time. There were some hard questions but in general they are similar to the difficulty of the questions in textbooks. Calculators are allowed but only simple ones. One will have to be careful since there are many high-performing students and one or two simple mistakes can be dangerous.
The online homework adopts the MasteringPhysics system, and you will have to buy a textbook(255HKD) for the access code. Better be careful with its operation since every time you give an incorrect answer, 10% mark of that question will be deducted.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not huge, only 1 homework for about 15 questions per week and 2 exams. Additional exercises are optional but they might be helpful in preparing for exams. Formula sheets are provided so one will not have to remember all of the complex formulas.

reviews.author: Libo
reviews.title: PHYS1112
reviews.comment_content:
If you are reading this, you are either a) Planning to choose this course, which is required in your curriculum so you don;t have a choice or b) you are enrolled in this course and are panicking.
  Take a deep breath, everything will be OK, I'm here to help.

For those without M1/2: (Or calculus background)
  Let's face it, the teaching quality in UST MATH1012 is so bad it's close to non-existent. You are probably ill-prepared for a Physics course that is oriented around calculus. Things can get really scary really quick here.
  Calm down.
  Here's the thing, this amount of calculus involved in this course is really not high. There is almost no chance that you will ever face any difficult calculus problem. Most of the integration/differentiation (If there is any) that you will face are very easy. All you need to do is to set up the equation and you will be fine.
  So what about vectors?
  You will encounter most of the vectors in the first few weeks of the course. The rectangular coordinates that you were once familiar with will be changed to vectors, and it can get uncomfortable.
  But again, the vector calculations in this course are not difficult, and all you have to do is to spend a few hours to understand what the notations mean and you are all set. If you still find it difficult, search youtube for "Organic Chemistry Tutor Vectors". The video might seem to be very elementary and basic, but that's pretty much all you are ever gonna need!
  Still not convinced? In the Midterm/Final Exam this semester, not a single question involve vectors/integration/differentiation calculations (Maybe there was one or two, but I can't remember, so it can't be that bad.. right?)
reviews.comment_teaching:
=Cheung Man Fung= (Professors)
  Cheung Man Fung is really not a bad teacher. The problem is, he is very smart, and he assumes that everyone is as smart as him.
  If you are not super good at Math or Physics, chances are, you will find Cheung Man Fung's lectures very difficult to understand. You are most likely not going to understand a thing in the lectures and it will leave you questioning your life.
  It's fine. It happens to the best of us.
  The main reason why his lectures are so difficult to understand is that he spends a lot of time talking about the DERIVATION of the formulas.
  When it comes to dealing with the exams, there's really no need to understand those derivations (Well.. unless you are aiming for a guaranteed A+ and want to get the highest mark in the whole class... In that case it would be better if you understand the derivations). The reality is, the exam questions don't require you to know how the formulas are derived. You just need to know how to use those formulas and when to use them.
  I not saying that you should skip all the lectures and ignore the derivation (you can if you want). My recommendation is to try your best to understand the derivations. It is provide you with a slightly better understanding of the topic. If you can't, that's fine. Don't spend too much time in it. The focus is knowing how to use the equations.

=Liu Bin= (TA)
  Why... Just... why???
  He is a sh_t teacher. There is no question about it. The students know it, he knows it, we all know it.
  He does not try to explain the concept, he does a poor job teaching. No one pays attention in his class. We are just there because we need to take attendance. He is perfectly aware of this. He could not care less.
  My advice: Quit trying to be a TA, go do the Physics research that I'm sure he is good at, and learn how to pronounce the word "square".
reviews.comment_grading:
Good Grading.
  Midterm: 25/26
  Finals: 22/27
  Homework: 100% (Raw score is 86.5, after conversion it became 100. I have no idea how it worked. I am not going to question it.)
  Tutorial Attendance: 100% (Though I spent almost all my lectures watching Youtube)
  Final Grade: A.
  Good Enough.
  I have attached the Finals and Midterm Histogram for your reference.
reviews.comment_workload:
=Homework=
  The homework will count 10% of your course grade. It is multiplied by 1.1, so a 90ish mark will give you a full mark in the final grade.
  The workload from the homework is not high. Google is your friend. Slander is also your friend.

=Exams=
  As I have said before, the focus is knowing when to use the formula and how to use them. The only way to achieve this is by practicing, a lot.
  Do the supplementary exercises on the Mastering Physics Webpage first. Those are the essentials but will not be adequate for you to get a good grade.
  To get a good grade, do the exercise at the end of each chapter of you Pearson textbook. If you don't know how to do them, copy the questions and search them up in google. For 90% of the questions, you can find the full solution in Slander.
  The workload is heavy. There is no question about it.
  In particular, the difficulty of the final Exam is not comparable to the midterm. If you are going after an A grade, make sure that you have at least 5 day (No, 3 days are not enough) devoted to PURE practicing.
  To sum up, this course is a good chance for you to reflect your life choices, and think about why you didn't get into CUHK when you have the chance.
  Aiiii.... the sweet sweet taste of regret.

reviews.author: hsicat
reviews.comment_content:
-Physical quantities, vectors & Motion in 2D
-Newton's laws of motion
-Work and kinetic energy
-Potential energy and energy conservation
-Momentum, impulse and collision
-Dynamics of rigid bodies
-Angular momentum
-Gravitation
-Periodic motion
-Wave motion and sound
-Temperature and heat
-Thermal properties of matter
-First law of Thermodynamic
-Second law of Thermodynamics
reviews.comment_teaching: I can feel that Professor CHEUNG is pretty passionate about teaching. He organized his own hand-written lecture notes as teaching material (the key points are well-organized though it's a little messy) and his teaching is clear and easy to understand. He is willing to answer students' questions after class. And when there is an experiment demonstration, he sometimes let us try the experiment in person after the lecture too.
reviews.comment_grading:
For me
midterm 25/28
final 32/39
hw about 95% above for each problem set
tutorial 8/8
finished 8 DSM
I got an A.

Btw tutorial counts attendance. If you attend the session and completed the worksheet you will get 1 point. If you only attend the session and hand in a blank worksheet with your name on it, you get 0.75. The three tutorial sessions with the lowest point won't be counted so it means that you can skip three sessions.
reviews.comment_workload: 1 HW set per week and there are about 8-12 questions in a HW problem set and most of the problem sets are announced two weeks or more before ddl. It's not very time-consuming to finish a problem set (maybe at most 2-3 hr?). There are also supplementary problem sets (not graded) and DSM (can be counted as bonus) for practicing. Overall, for the necessary part, it is not too hard to handle.

reviews.author: mbdp
reviews.comment_content: It includes two parts: mechanics and heat. the latter one is harder for me because i learned a few about it before.
reviews.comment_teaching: I didn't really listen to the lecture. The professor was talking about how formulas came from and sample questions were underestimated, it only makes you better understand the theories but i have no idea how to use them.
reviews.comment_grading: i'm not sure about it. mine is not bad.
reviews.comment_workload: workload is large, mainly because you have to do your homework once a week, including 10+ questions, which are difficult for me even after having the lecture.

reviews.author: scyeung
reviews.title: An honor course in disguise
reviews.comment_content:
Basic mechanics, wave, thermodynamics.

Some problems in mechanics, especially rotational motion which is foreign to most year 1 students, are quite difficult. It also makes the mid-term paper harder than the final paper in this semester.

Overall, I feel like the content covered is quite broad for year 1. However, if you read the textbook, you'll find that HKUST already cut some topics like shock waves, mean free path etc. I am not sure about the syllabus so I spent a lot of time reading topics that are not tested, so that's probably one reason why you should attend lectures.

You must attend tutorials in this course, as it counts towards your course grade. The tutorial is quite useful, in my opinion.

Although there are a lot of content, the exam are not set to be very difficult. They are all mc questions with about 20% of questions being difficult questions. You should have no problem scoring a good score if you know the fundamentals well.
reviews.comment_teaching: Only attended two lectures for personal reasons.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is absolutely amazing. A score of 22/26 in midterm and 36/40 in final with missed assignments gave A+. Many people got A-range, I guess there should be 25% A-range, which is the maximum amount for an non-honour course.
reviews.comment_workload: Pretty heavy workload for those who want to get A+.

reviews.author: Peepeepoopoo
reviews.title: Lenient grade but need to send more time on this course.
reviews.comment_content:
A lot of content were covered in a short period of time. Although most of the topics are covered in DSE, the content is much more difficult and we have to use calculus to derive formula.
Having lectures and doing assignments are not enough for us to understand the syllabus fully. Need to spare a lot of time for self studying to understand this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructor uploads his hand written notes before the class. He then writes an almost identical notes with us during the class with a few examples added. Since he writes notes with us, it was quite easy to follow.
However, we still need to read the ppt ourselves after class to fully understand the content.
reviews.comment_grading:
Originally:
Homework Assignments:10%
Tutorials (Class Participation*):5%
Midterm:35%
Final Exam:50%

However, due to covid, the scheme "Make the Midterm to be optional and take the higher score of (Midterm scaled to 35% + Final scaled to 50%) OR (Final  scaled to 85%)" was used


I didn't attend any lectures and only scanned through some of the notes a day before the exam. However, I finished all the assignment on time and have a full participation for tutorials.
Grade in the end: C-
The grade was quite lenient as I expected a F.
reviews.comment_workload:
No attendance on lectures, but have attendance foe tutorials.
There is an assignment each week on MasterPhysics.

reviews.comment_teaching: Altman explained the concept very clear, especially in Thermodynamics, which I think is the most difficult part in this course. And he taught in the right pace so to me it is easy to follow. Also, the lecture notes made by Altman is quite good. It provides sufficient calculations and explanations on each formula and concept. Altman is also willing to answer questions after class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments 10%
Tutorials 5%
Midterm 35%
Final Exam 50%

->Which means the exam results are the real game changers of the course. Actually I think my effort on studying for the final exam saved my grade in this course.

Midterm: 6/30
Final: 19/42

Final Grade:C
reviews.comment_workload:
An assignment per week, to be handed after 2 weeks. They've got a help desk session for assignments, which is generally helpful (albeit in some occasions, the TA can't understand the questions well). Leave spare time for the help desk in case you stuck on some assignment question. There's also a email Q&A running on weekdays, but my opinion is that the email Q&A is less useful than the help desk session.

Harder supplementary assignments are also available, and personally, they should be attempted (by all means) to increase your understanding. That's what I did for a week before the final exam.

Just find the solutions on Chegg, they are very useful

reviews.comment_content:

1. Newton's laws of motion I and II
2. Work and kinetic energy

7. Angular momentum

10. Wave motion and sound I and II
11. Temperature and heat
12. Thermal properties of the matter I, II
13. First law of Thermodynamics I, II
14. Secon law of Thermodynamics I, I
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is inspiring. I love him though. Attend his lecture! He will do a lot of interesting experiments.

24/24 mean: 10.8
Final
37/40 mean: 17.1
Homework
Almost full marks
Grade: A+
If you have learned physics competition before, it shouldn't be difficult for you.
reviews.comment_workload: There is a lot of homework to do. Although it is helpful for you to understand the content, it is very time-consuming. The exams are all multiple questions, so you don't have to prepare for the long questions.

reviews.author: suen__
reviews.title: hard course with
reviews.comment_content: physics with calculus proofing and learning how to derivative those eqt.
reviews.comment_teaching: I saw the prof do many experiments (according to my frds) and it got hearts in teaching students. He strongly advised students asking questions no matter in lesson or after lesson. He is quite fun at all. it is a fortunate of this course because it is so boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
It's game of luck. there are 24 mc in mid term and 40 mc for final.
it looks not heavy at all. but not to mention over 40% of the question I could not make it. lmao. I spent plenty of times guessing the answer.  
but I pass mean of both exam for one sd which getting me a B+
I actually don't think I can get a B for this course as I really don't know what's the exam is talking about , the notes etc.
I think it is suitable for all people if you are aiming B or above just do the exercise of the book is enough.
btw this course doesn't take attendance but please takes most of the tutorial as I counts for 5% grade.
for me I skip all the lesson and just watch the notes and do the exercise.it helps me pass through most basic question but those question with star just leave them alone if you are aiming for B is enough.
reviews.comment_workload: heavy workload with weekly homework. homework content is h

reviews.author: beraknonstop
reviews.title: hard course
reviews.comment_content: Pretty interesting, but very hard because of the calculus part. All of the topics are from high school. Just the questions are very hard. Tutorials are pretty interesting. The instructor is very kind because he gives the answers for the homework part.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Cheung MF is a very good instructor. Likes to demonstrate in front of the class. Other professors are bad.
reviews.comment_grading: No idea, they did not specify about this. Got both mean minus SD for mid and final term, ended up getting a C+.
reviews.comment_workload: Homeworks every week, pretty hard questions but it would be very helpful if you have chegg.

reviews.author: Tsugumi
reviews.title: HARD
reviews.comment_content: IF YOU CAN'T GET DSE LV 5 OR ABOVE AND PAY EFFORT ON IT, U WON'T GET A GOOD GRADE
reviews.comment_teaching:
THE TEACHING IS GOOD, PROF IS FUNNY AND THE STUFF HE TAUGHT IS INTERESTING. HOWEVER, I WILL FEEL BORING IN HIS CLASS TOO, I BELIEVE IT IS MY BAD.
HOWEVER, THIS PROF WILL TEACH SOME KNOWLEDGE FROM OTHER COURSES (e.g. PHYS1002), BUT IT ONLY CONTAIN A SMALL PART OF IT.

reviews.title: Take it or leave it
reviews.comment_content: The address covers exceptionally fundamental concepts of Physics and I assume all of them are very simple for understudies in the event that they examined a bit more assist in tall school. The educators conveys official address notes and educators composes key focuses on whiteboard step by step whereas giving point by point clarification, but you have got to be exceptionally centered on what he is talking almost since this physics teachers talks a small fast, which moreover appears that he includes a clear rationale of what he is instructing.
reviews.comment_teaching: Educating is very clear. It is fundamental to go to the instructional exercise sessions since TA's instructing is way better than the teachers. reviews.comment_grading: Hard grading
reviews.comment_workload:
Very overwhelming I think. Each week acing material science, indeed you have got source, you still require at slightest one hour to wrap up. There are 12 homework and each hw is around 10-12 questions.
As for the homework, about 1 hour every week since 99% of the questions have full answers on the internet if you google around hard enough.
Midterms and finals, if you have done the above, spend more time going over the notes (you should write your own), focus on thermodynamics for the final in particular.

reviews.comment_content: The physics taught in this course is fairly basic for someone with a strong background in physics, however the questions that are asked are completely different in comparison to those discussed in the tutorials
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture notes are not really useful, and the professor doesn't explain the concept thoroughly with much practice which results in a lot of self study and really tough finals
reviews.comment_grading: The final exam was not at all similar to the questions discussed in class which lead to a low mean thus putting students with no background at a disadvantage

reviews.author: marcong2000
reviews.comment_content: The first half of the course is about HKDSE physics, so no worries about this part. But do pay close attention to the second half of the course as it will to teach you new topics such as thermodynamics. You might want to practice more for the later parts.
reviews.comment_teaching: This course is hard. But what makes things worse is the professor. I would not say Professor Leung is "that" bad. But comparing to online videos from Youtube, Khan Academy, and Numerade, it's just worse. You can definitely do a good job even though you don't attend his lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: Lenient grading for my semester. Got an A+ despite expecting an A-. One thing about this course's grading tho. You will get a grade that is linear to your effort paid in this course. No free lunch
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for this course really depends on what grade you would like to get. If you are aiming for an A range, you will have to complete more than the HW. Completing the supplementary exercises is definitely a must. If not, say, you only aim for a B range, simply doing the HW problems as well as the past papers will do.

reviews.comment_workload: little

reviews.author: aiikooo
reviews.comment_content:
General physics. Topics include motion laws, gravitation, simple harmonic motion, temperature and heat, etc.

3 hours of lecture and a 1-hr tutorial each week. Attendance is only taken during tutorials, not lectures.
A midterm and a final.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His lectures follow the syllabus and the lecture notes posted on canvas. He tries his best to make sure that his pace is ok for us to follow. Great English and clear explanations. Outside class, he's easy to reach by e-mail and we can always contact him for a meeting during his office hours.

Unfortunately I got a tutor whose English is a bit hard to understand. He uses fast methods to solve the questions and sometimes I can't keep up.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair. We have 5 attempts for each question in the weekly homework so as long as you don't fail all attempts it shouldn't be much of a problem.

The midterm and final exams are both multiple-choice.
reviews.comment_workload: One homework (around 9 questions) each week. The homework is online. They're good for practice and some of the questions are discussed in the tutorial session. But they will be more burdening once you're in the midterm season or final season because it does require quite an amount of time and effort.

reviews.author: fl0ra
reviews.title: The A+ range is wider than my expectation
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers a wide range of topics, some of which may be new to year 1 students such as dynamics of rigid bodies, simple harmonic motion, wave & sound as well as thermodynamics. But no worry. The content never went into depth since the schedule was quite tight.
Besides, even though the course claims that it employs a calculus-based approach, students with basic differentiation and integration techniques can easily handle it. If you are taking MATH1013 or 1014, I believe the calculus part is not a problem.
reviews.comment_teaching:
There are 2 lectures (not compulsory) and 1 tutorial (attendance counted) each week.

Prof. CHEUNG is excellent! He can explain the concepts in a clear way. Sometimes he will prove the formulas employing mathematical methods, which I really appreciate because it indeed contributed to my understanding. He will release the hand-written supplementary notes on canvas in addition to the lecture notes. The supplementary notes are well-organized and include a few exercises with detailed solutions.
(btw, Prof. CHEUNG is handsome XD especially when he is totally devoted to the demonstration. I have never seen a professor so serious about the demo, which is really cute lol)

As for the tutorial, basically, it is a waste of time. The exercise they hand out in the tuto is much easier than the exam. sometimes the TA help the students with some difficult homework questions
reviews.comment_grading:
assignments 10%
tutorials attendance 5%
midterm 35%
final exam 50%

both midterm and final are MC
The midterm was rather easy. 20% of students got full marks.
mean: 20.13/25
SD: 5.03

However, the final was crazy!  If you think that you can work out the problems if you have attended the lectures, done homework on your own and even finished all the exercise in the textbook, YOU ARE WRONG! There were total of 45 MC questions and many of them were much difficult than the homework, the textbook exercise, and even the sample paper! my suggestion is don't struggle with those difficult questions and get the easy one correct.
mean: 22.3/ 45
SD: 8.3

me:
midterm 25/25
final 36/45
assignment and tutorial full marks
I thought I probably only got A because my final grade was not that high(about 20 students' score>= mine) and there were only about 310 students enrolled in spring terms. But surprisingly it was an A+! So I believe the A+ range was relatively wide even in the spring term. Perhaps 5%. If you are looking for a high grade, PHYS1112 is a good choice.

the final score of the assignment will be multiplied with a factor of 10/9, which means you only need to score 90/100 to get the full mark.
reviews.comment_workload:
I give it a C because the homework system is so annoying. I can hardly believe that a system that costs each student hundreds of HKD is so slow, time-consuming and out of date. There are on average 9 questions each week and you have to pay extra attention to the rounding, units, up/down case and so on. There will be a deduction for each wrong answer and you will lose all the points after 5 attempts.
Go through the lecture notes and supplementary notes several times until you clearly understand the concepts is necessary for a good grade. The lecture notes are a brief summary of the textbook, so there is no need to read the textbook unless you are still confused with some concepts. Homework and supplementary exercise on the homework system are enough. Nothing too hard.

reviews.author: eltonmiao
reviews.title: High workloads and need to pay effort
reviews.comment_content: All about force and wave. First half is very manageable if you studied High school physics. Second half is completely now for high school physics student. Should focus more in the second half.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is a good professor with very good English as he is not Chinese. I attend all the lessons for the first half of semester until I became lazy. He also conducted some experiments during the lecture.
Tutorial lesson is useless in my opinion. People just sit there and wait for IPRS. Only teach two questions about mastering physics homework.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment: 10%
Tutorials: 5%
Midterm: 35%
Final: 50%

Personally:
Assignment 10/10
Tutorials  5/5 (90% of tutorial continued towards final grade)
Midterm  23/25
Final 27/45
reviews.comment_workload: High workload for sure. Reading the textbook for at least twice can get you a passing grade. I personally read the textbook during every lectures for the first half of semester. Didnâ€™t do that for the second half which lead to my poor final result.

reviews.author: Alanx
reviews.comment_content:
Not far from HKDSE Physics syllabus but with some deeper and more detailed content especially in the topics of wave and heat
Calculus is sometimes required to derive the equations but the calculus required in exam is simple
reviews.comment_teaching: CHEN Tian Wen is one of the best instructor I experienced in my first semester. Fluent and good English which is quite easy to listen to. There are many demonstrations, one for each lecture on average. We had finished the syllabus one lesson less than scheduled so he arranged an extra tutorial to us instead. Quite a capable and responsible instructor.
reviews.comment_grading:
First quiz 20%: 8/10   Mean 5.56   SD 2.44
Second quiz 20%: 7/10   Mean 5.18   SD 2.59
Final 50%: 29/45   Mean 21.7   SD 7.8
Grade: A-
I think I am just around 1 SD above mean overall.
reviews.comment_workload:
One assignment per week, not too easy sometimes but people always find ways to get the answer.
You also need to buy an expensive barcode to complete HW.
I heard some of my friends' tutorial lessons are mandatory but not the case for all the lecture section.

reviews.author: Lyndon
reviews.comment_content: The teaching contest is strictly closed to the syllabus
reviews.comment_teaching: Strong Chinese accent, for a common course, it is really difficult to teach more things out of class. So it is relatively meaningless to talk about the quality of teaching.
reviews.comment_grading: Quite fair compared to your effort. Just like other common courses, the ratio of getting different grades is fixed.
reviews.comment_workload: Some regular homework are assigned weekly. And you can find all the solutions by means of Chegg or some manuals. In order to get a  good grade, a relatively big workload should be imposed.

reviews.author: I Want 1st Hon!
reviews.title: Nice grade for Fall term if you work hard enough, Nice Lecturer too!
reviews.comment_content:
I can compare it with HKDSE PHYS.
HKDSE PHYS helps, but not too much.
You must get at least both 3 in PHYS and M1/M2 in order to enter this course.

You will use some calculus, so you should work hard on it. It is recommended that you do most of the textbook chapter exercises.

It is easy to say that there are a lot of things you haven't learnt in HKDSE, you have to work so hard and try to do more exercises, so that you can get a better and a better grade.

Overall, useful content!
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lessons are quite exciting.
The teaching is effective and he uses his own notes to teach. He writes on the whiteboard and teaches.

He explains some phenomenons and derives many formulas, which can be clearly understood.

Dr. Cheung will teach quite fast so you should have a strong foundation in Maths/M2. You should not miss any lessons because you will miss a lot of things he teaches.

He demonstrates experiments and then explains why it happens, and also he derives equations to support his explanation.

You may ask questions after classes. He is very nice and he explains precisely and clearly to you.

He is passionate in teaching. You should try to sit in the front and learn more :)
Definitely give an 'A'.

Tutors are good but not extremely good, but he explains things well. Maybe everyone is sleepy at 9am...
reviews.comment_grading:
You must attend all tutorials (5%) because he said he would take attendance in tutorials after add/drop period!! (It counts in your grades)
No attendance taken in lectures.

Pre, Post surveys can gain you each 1% grade.

You must buy the University PHYS Textbook(<$300), Keep the student access code carefully because you need it to register an account for Mastering Physics online HW (5%)!! Mean is 92.9/100, lowest is 5/100

You must also finish a compulsory online mastering physics HW each week, as it counts in your grades.

Both quizzes (each 20%): mean ~5.5, SD: ~2
6/10 (mean 5.6), 6/10 (mean 5.5) in the first and retake of the 1st quiz;
8/10 (mean 5.3), 6/10 (mean 5.3) in the first and retake of the 2nd quiz.

Final (50%): 25/45, mean 21.8; SD: 7.8  
In L4-L6, the mean is 22.3, and the highest is 43

Grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Just do exercises when you are free. Don't waste time! Otherwise, you may end up a bad grade, e.g. C range.
Don't bother to think it is lucky in spring semester, since I heard some terrible score even they got higher score than me.

I have been working hard on the exercises for a long time (~6 hours every exercises).

reviews.author: ff

reviews.author: birdy
reviews.comment_content:
Classical Mechanics:
Physical Quantities, Vectors, and 2D Motion
Newton's Laws of Motion
Work and Kinetic Energy
Potential Energy and Energy Conservation
Momentum, Impulse, and Collisions
Dynamics of Rigid Bodies
Angular Momentum
Gravitation
Simple Harmonic Motion

Waves/Acoustics:
Wave Motion and Sound

Thermodynamics:
Temperature and Heat
Thermal Properties of Matter
First Law of Thermodynamics
Second Law of Thermodynamics


Simple in the beginning of the semester because most topics have been taught in high school. However, wave and thermodynamics are new topics and need much efforts to master.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. XU was like always reading the content from slides and his voice made me sleepy. However he is really friendly and will explain very explicitly if you raise up a question. Therefore I seldom attended lectures after a few weeks. I would see self-learning from textbooks and slides (the prof is only reading the slides anyway), and doing homework is enough for getting a good grade.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite good.

Got full points in tutorials and homework (with bonus). Only get about 2~3 answers wrong in midterm and final.

Finally got A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
A little bit heavy but acceptable.

Every week, you have two lectures (1.5h for each, but you can choose not to attend), one tutorial (50min and compulsory), and a homework (usually takes 3~5 hours).

You can tell that there are really lots of hw problems, but they are good for self-learning and practice. You will find exams quite easy if you take those hw problems seriously and accomplish them well. It is time-worthy.

reviews.author: Jatin
reviews.title: Course review
reviews.comment_content:
If you are reading this, you are either a) preparing to enroll in this course because it is a requirement for your curriculum and you have no other option, or b) currently enrolled in this course and feeling stressed.
  Breathe deeply; everything will be fine; I'm here to assist.
If you don't have M1/2: (Or a background in calculus)

  Let's face it, UST MATH 1012's instruction is so subpar that it is practically nonexistent. For a calculus-based physics course, you are probably not well-prepared. Here, things can quickly become extremely ominous.
  Settle down.
The amount of calculus required for this course is actually quite low. You have a very slim chance of ever encountering a challenging calculus problem. Mostif there is any, will be very simple in terms of integration and differentiation. You just need to set up the equation, and everything will work out.
  What about vectors, then?
  In the first few weeks of the course, you will come across the majority of the vectors. You'll be switching from the familiar rectangular coordinates to vectors, which can be unsettling.
But once more, the vector calculations in this course are not challenging; all you need to do is spend a few hours getting to grips with the notations, and you'll be good to go. If you're still having trouble, look up "Organic Chemistry Tutor Vectors" on YouTube. Although the video may appear very simple and straightforward, but that is really all you will ever need!
  Not yet persuaded? This semester's midterm and final exams did not contain a single question that required performing calculations involving vectors, integration, or differentiation (I may have missed one or two, but it can't be that bad, can it?).
reviews.comment_teaching:
(Professors) Cheung Man Fung
  Really, Cheung Man Fung isn't that bad of a teacher. He is extremely intelligent, but he thinks that everyone is equally intelligent, which is a problem.
  The chances are that you will find Cheung Man Fung's lectures extremely challenging to understand if you are not particularly strong in math or physics. The lectures are probably not going to make any sense to you, which will make you reflect on your life.
  It's okay. Even the best of us experience it.
  He spends a lot of time discussing the DERIVATION of the formulas, which is the main factor contributing to the difficulty of understanding his lectures.
  There is really no need to comprehend those derivations when dealing with the exams.
  (Except if you want to earn the highest grade in the class and are guaranteed an A+; in that case, it would be preferable if you understood the derivations.) In actuality, it's not necessary to understand how the formulas are arrived at to answer the exam questions. You simply need to be aware of how and when to apply those formulas.
  I'm not suggesting that you ignore the derivation and skip all the lectures (although you are free to do so). My advice is to make every effort to comprehend the derivations. It will give you a little more insight into the subject. If you are unable to, it's okay. Don't linger there for too long. Understanding how to use the is key.
(TA) Liu Bin
  Why... Simply... why?
  He is a terrible educator. There is no disputing it. He knows it, the students know it, and we all know it.

  He does a poor job of teaching and makes no attempt to explain the idea. Nobody in his class is paying attention. Our only purpose in being there is to take attendance. He fully understands this. He doesn't give a damn.
  My recommendation is to stop trying to be a teaching assistant and instead focus on the physics research that I'm sure he is good at. Also, learn how to pronounce the word "square."
reviews.comment_grading:
Good Marks.
  18/26 at midterm
  Results: 16/27
  homework: 100% (The converted score, which was originally 86.5, is 100. I don't know how it functioned. I won't be challenging it.)
  Attendance at all classes: 100 (Even though I watched YouTube for the majority of my lectures.)
  Finally, a B.
  Just right
  For your reference, I've included the finals and midterm histograms.
reviews.comment_workload:
=Homework=
  Your course grade will include 10% of your homework. A 90-ish mark will give you a full mark in the final grade because it is multiplied by 1.1.
  There is not a lot of homework to complete. Your ally is Google. Slander is also a friend of yours.


Exams are centered on knowing when to use the formula and how to use them, as I've previously stated. This can only be accomplished by diligent practice.
Start by completing the add-on exercises on the Mastering Physics website. These are the necessities, but they won't be sufficient for you to receive a good grade.
  Complete the exercise at the conclusion of each chapter in your Pearson textbook to earn a good grade. Copy the questions and google them if you're not sure how to answer them. Slander contains the entire answer to 90% of the questions.
  It's a lot of work. There is no disputing it.

  Particularly, the final Exam's difficulty is not comparable to the midterm's. If you want to get an A, be sure to dedicate at least 5 daysâ€”3 days are insufficientâ€”to PURE practicing.

reviews.author: cfszeto
reviews.comment_content: PHYS 1111 and PHYS 1112 target students who have learned the most basic knowledge in physics in high school. Students with more advanced physics background should consider taking PHYS 1312. PHYS 1112 employs a calculus-based approach. Students without knowledge of calculus should take PHYS 1111 instead. Key topics include motions and Newtonâ€™s Laws, work and energy, conservation of energy and momentum, rotation, rigid body, simple harmonic and damped oscillations, forced oscillations, standing waves and sound waves, kinetic theory and the laws of thermodynamics. For students under the 4-year degree only. Students without the physics prerequisite but have taken PHYS 1001 or equivalent, and/or without the mathematics prerequisite but have taken MATH 1013/ MATH 1020/ MATH 1023 or equivalent may seek instructorâ€™s approval for enrolling in the course.

reviews.author: K_manifold
reviews.title: Basically self study under Prof. Han
reviews.comment_content: If you are local, secondary school physics should let you ignore the first half of course. If you are from mainland, then basically all you have to learn is to apply simple calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Han is an eminent researcher who leads a research team. And so he is very busy. It is VERY UNDERSTANDABLE that he does not have time to prepare for simple lectures aimed at Year 1 students.

So he just read powerpoints and attempt to explain those ideas to us poor Y1 students who are nothing compared to his glorious research effort that is uncomfortably interrupted by mundane tasks of teaching.

I beseech the university to relieve Prof. Han of the burden of teaching and let him focus his effort on research where his talent can be maximally expressed.
reviews.comment_grading: I missed half of my homework and I got A.
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly homework that can be done within 120 mins.

Tutorial attendance is recorded through a poll.

reviews.author: CCWS
reviews.comment_content:
-The level of difficulty is acceptable before the mid-term
-There are lots of new things after mid-term. Better start self-study earlier. Otherwise, you may not be able to catch up.
-Although the course name is General Physics with Calculus, most of the questions use simple calculation only.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I like prof. Zeng's teaching style, very interactive and interesting.
You need to catch up the teaching speed because the content is a bit challenging after the mid-term.

-Quite good

-Need to catch up the teaching
-HW once a week, very annoying
